questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents with symptoms of flu-like illness, including fever, sore throat, and fatigue. Further investigation reveals a positive HIV serology. Which of the following chemokine receptors primarily facilitates the entry of HIV into CD4+ T cells?
questions.solution: CORRECT OPTION :- B) CCR5 , CXCR4 EXPLANATION :- CCR5 and CXCR4 both act as coreceptors for a viral envelope(gp120) glycoprotein of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the cause of AIDS, and thus facilitating the entry of HIV into CD4+ T cells. Chemokines: Chemokines are classified into four major groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the proteins: C = Cysteine ; X = Any amino acid

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation. Which of the following chemokines is primarily responsible for recruiting neutrophils to the airways in COPD exacerbations?
questions.solution: CORRECT OPTION: A) IL-8 Explanation:   Interleukin-8, is a potent chemokine involved in the recruitment of neutrophils to sites of inflammation, particularly in response to bacterial and other microbial infections.   In COPD exacerbations, increased levels of CXCL8 are observed in the airways, contributing to the recruitment and activation of neutrophils, which exacerbate airway inflammation and tissue damage. MCP-1(OPTION B): monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), primarily recruits monocytes and macrophages to sites of inflammation. It is not primarily responsible for recruiting neutrophils to the airways during exacerbations SDF-1(OPTION C): CXCL12, also known as stromal cell-derived factor 1 (SDF-1), is involved in stem cell homing and lymphocyte trafficking. It primarily attracts lymphocytes, monocytes, and hematopoietic stem cells but is not a major chemokine involved in recruiting neutrophils to the airways in COPD exacerbations. RANTES(OPTION D): CCL5, also known as regulated on activation, normal T cell expressed and secreted (RANTES), attracts T cells, eosinophils, and basophils to sites of inflammation. While it contributes to the inflammatory response, it is not primarily responsible for recruiting neutrophils to the airways in COPD exacerbations.

questions.question: Which of the following mediators is responsible for cancer cachexia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) TNF-alpha Explanation: TNF-alpha is an inflammatory cytokine produced by macrophages and monocytes. Key roles include:   WBC recruitment, vascular leak in acute inflammation   Appetite suppression (via action on the hypothalamus), cancer cachexia   Fever induction (along with IL1, IL6)   Maintains granulomas in granulomatous diseases (eg. Tuberculosis) IFN-gamma (Option B) : IFNg is secreted by NK and T cells. Its key role is stimulating macrophages to kill phagocytosed organisms and form granulomas. IL-8 (Option C): IL-8 is a major chemoattractant for neutrophils in acute inflammation. TGF-beta (Option D): TGF-beta is predominantly involved in wound healing, stimulating angiogenesis and fibrosis. It is an anti-inflammatory cytokine.

questions.question: A 20-year-old male is prescribed naproxen for a musculoskeletal injury. What is naproxen’s mechanism of action?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Cycloxygenase (COX) 1 and COX-2 inhibition Explanation:   Arachidonic acid (AA), derived from phospholipids, is metabolized by cyclooxygenases (COX-1, COX-2) to form prostanoids (prostaglandins, thromboxane).   COX-1 is a constitutive enzyme, predominantly involved in various homeostatic mechanisms in the body, while COX-2 is predominantly involved in inflammation.   Prostaglandins are responsible for vasodilation (PGD2, PGI2) and pain (PGE2) in inflammation.   Naproxen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). The predominant action of NSAIDs is via COX-1 and COX-2 inhibition, resulting in analgesia and anti-inflammatory effects which is required in this case of musculoskeletal injury..   One major adverse effect of NSAIDs is gastric irritation, including ulcers and bleeding. This occurs due to the loss of gastroprotective PGs i.e. PGE2 formed by COX-1. Thus, in patients with previous history of gastric ulcers, selective COX-2 inhibitors may be used - celecoxib, etoricoxib, etc.   Lipoxygenase acts on AA to form leukotrienes. Leukotrienes have clinical significance in atopy and mediate anaphylaxis and bronchoconstriction. Zileuton (LOX inhibitor) and montelukast (LT receptor antagonists) are therefore used in asthma and allergic rhinitis but have no anti-inflammatory action (Option A).   PGF2 is a prostanoid formed by cyclooxygenase. However, it has no role in inflammation. Rather, it causes smooth muscle contraction. Thus PGF2alpha analogue (carboprost) may be used to induce labor or as an abortifacient (Option D)

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a high fever, chills, and malaise. He reports feeling unwell for the past few days and has noticed redness and swelling around a cut on his forearm. On examination, the healthcare provider observes a localized area of erythema and induration at the site of the wound. Which of the following events is a crucial step in the activation of the complement system in response to the patient's initial condition?

options.A: Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes
options.C: Cleavage of C3 into C3a and C3b
options.D: Cleavage of C5 by C5 convertase

questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: C) Cleavage of C3 into C3a and C3b EXPLANATION: Complement system is a plasma derived mediator of inflammation. Other plasma derived mediators of inflammation are Coagulation/Cloting and Kinin pathway. The complement system can be activated by three pathways: Classic al path wayTriggered by the binding of C1 to an antibody (IgM or IgG) that has combined with the antigen. Activated by Ag-Ab complex. Alternat e pathw ayTriggered by microbial surface molecules (e.g., endotoxin or lipopolysaccharide [LPS]), complex polysaccharides, cobra venom, and other substances in the absence of an antibody. Lectin pathwa yThe plasma mannose-binding lectin binds to carbohydrates on microbes and directly activates C1.   The cleavage of C3 into its active fragments, C3a and C3b , is the critical event in the complement system and serves as a central step in all three complement activation pathways. The image below shows an overview of the complement pathways.

questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: A) 1-iii, 2-iv, 3-ii, 4-i EXPLANATION:   Anaphylatoxins: C3a, C4a, and C5a.   Opsonins: C3b.   CR2/CD21/C3d: Complement receptor for EBV entry into cells (T cells/macrophages)   CD55: Decay accelerating factor. It accelerates the dissociation of C3 convertase, inhibiting all 3 pathways.

options.A: Teichoic acid is an initiator of the alternate complement pathway.
options.B: The first complement protein to be activated is C1.
options.C: The C3 convertase of the alternate pathway is C3bBb.
options.D: Properdin deficiency involves the alternate pathway.

The complements involved in the alternate pathway are:   Free C3 in the serum.   Factor B.   Factor D.   Properdin. questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset swelling of her face, lips, and tongue. She reports a history of similar episodes occurring intermittently since childhood, often triggered by stress or trauma. On examination, she appears anxious and has marked swelling of her lips and tongue, with difficulty speaking and swallowing. There are no signs of urticaria or pruritus. Her vital signs are stable. Which of the following deficiencies is seen in this condition?

options.B: Deficiency of C1, C2, C3, C4

questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: C) Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation of the patient with sudden-onset swelling of her face, lips, and tongue with similar episodes in the past, triggered by stress and trauma is suggestive of hereditary angioneurotic edema. It is caused due to deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of non-pitting, non-pruritic swelling of the skin and mucous membranes.   C1INH (C1 esterase inhibitor) blocks the catalytic function of C1.   Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor leads to elevated plasma levels of bradykinin leading to angioedema, and excessive activation of C1 results in a decline in plasma C4 and C2 levels.   Swelling in HAE commonly affects areas such as the face, lips, tongue, throat, and extremities and can lead to airway compromise if it involves the upper respiratory tract.   Triggers for HAE episodes can vary but commonly include stress, trauma, hormonal fluctuations (e.g., menstruation), and certain medications (e.g., estrogen-containing contraceptives) Complement deficiency Pathway(s) involved Disease (pathology) Properdin (Option A) Alternative pathway Increased susceptibility to encapsulated organisms (Neisseria) C1, C2, C3, C4 (Option B) C1, C2, C4- Classical pathway C3- Common pathwaySLE, glomerulonephritis, pyogenic infections C5-C9: Membrane attack complex (Option D)Common deficiency Disseminated Neisseria infection( gram negative bacteria)

questions.question: Which of the following deficiencies is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: B) CD59 EXPLANATION: A clinical presentation of a patient with hemoglobinuria, pallor, jaundice, anemia, elevated LDH, and flow cytometry showing deficiency of certain proteins on the surface of red blood cells would be suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which is due to the deficiency of CD59.   PNH is a rare acquired hematologic disorder characterized by a mutation of the PIG-A gene .   This mutation results in a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)- anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells.   This deficiency leads to the absence of important complement regulatory proteins, such as CD55 aka DAF (decay accelerating factor) and CD59 aka RIML (reactive inhibitor of membrane lysis) , which normally protect red blood cells from complement-mediated destruction.   Consequently, red blood cells become sensitive to lysis by the complement system , particularly during periods of physical stress or following sleep.   PNH is characterized by a triad of hemolysis + pancytopenia + venous thrombosis.   Other symptoms include hemoglobinuria, fatigue, pallor, jaundice, abdominal pain, and recurrent infections.   Flow cytometry (the gold standard for diagnosis): Shows the absence of CD55 and CD59. Factor H (Option D):   Complement Factor H is a circulating glycoprotein that inhibits the alternative pathway by promoting the cleavage and destruction of C3b and the turnover of the C3 convertases.   Factor H deficiency is associated with an atypical form of hemolytic uremic syndrome and age-related macular degeneration.

questions.question: Pain during inflammation is mediated by?
questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: D) Bradykinin EXPLANATION: Bradykinin mediates pain during an inflammatory response   Bradykinin is produced from the cleavage of high-molecular-weight kininogen by the action of kallikrein.   It is a potent mediator of inflammation and pain , released in response to tissue injury and trauma .   It acts on its receptors to induce vasodilation , increase vascular permeability , and stimulate the release of other inflammatory mediators.   These actions contribute to the characteristic signs of inflammation, including redness, swelling, heat, and pain.   Additionally, bradykinin can directly activate nociceptors (pain-sensing neurons), leading to the sensation of pain.   The action of bradykinin is short-lived because it is quickly inactivated by an enzyme called kininase.   Bradykinin has been implicated as a mediator in some forms of allergic reactions, such as anaphylaxis. (S er ot o ni n) ( O pt io n A)Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) , is a neurotransmitter and vasoactive substance produced primarily by enterochromaffin cells in the gastrointestinal tract. It regulates mood, appetite , and sleep , as well as gastrointestinal motility and platelet aggregation . In the context of inflammation, serotonin released from platelets and mast cells can contribute to vasodilation , increased vascular permeability, and smooth muscle contraction . Its role in inflammation is less prominent compared to other mediators like histamine and bradykinin. (L e u k ot ri e n e s) ( O pt io n B)Leukotrienes are lipid mediators synthesized from arachidonic acid metabolism, primarily by the 5-lipoxygenase pathway. They play a significant role in the pathogenesis of asthma and allergic reactions by inducing bronchoconstriction, increasing vascular permeability , and promoting the recruitment of inflammatory cells to the site of inflammation. (I nt er le u ki n- 1) ( O pt io n C)Interleukin-1 (IL-1) is a proinflammatory cytokine produced by various cells, including macrophages, monocytes , and dendritic cells , in response to infection, injury, or inflammation. It plays a central role in the inflammatory response by inducing fever, activating immune cells , and promoting the production of other cytokines and inflammatory mediators. However, IL-1 is not a primary mediator responsible for the localized symptoms described in the clinical scenario, including pain, swelling, erythema, and warmth following a traumatic injury.

questions.question: Which substance plays a role as a mediator in chronic inflammation?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - TGF-beta:   TGF-β plays a crucial role in regulating immune responses, cell proliferation, differentiation, and tissue repair.   In the context of chronic inflammation, TGF-β is involved in tissue repair and fibrosis.   It promotes the production of extracellular matrix components and inhibits the activity of immune cells, contributing to the resolution of inflammation but also leading to tissue remodeling and fibrosis over time. Incorrect Options: Option A - IL-1:   IL-1 is a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in the initial phase of inflammation.   IL-1 helps recruit immune cells to sites of infection or damage and promotes the production of other inflammatory mediators.   It is associated with acute inflammation. Option B - TNF-α:   TNF-α is involved in systemic inflammation and is part of the acute phase response.   TNF-α helps mediate the recruitment of immune cells to inflammation sites and stimulates the production of other cytokines and adhesion molecules.   TNF-α is associated with acute inflammation. Option D - None

questions.question: An acute inflammatory response is not seen in which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Apoptosis:   Apoptosis is a controlled and orderly process of programmed cell death.   It does not induce an acute inflammatory response but rather leads to the removal of dying cells by phagocytosis without provoking an intense immune response. Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and D can trigger an acute inflammatory response.

questions.question: Which of the following cells are located in the centre of the lumen in a venule?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - RBCs:   Red blood cells (RBCs) are the primary cells found in the center of the lumen in a venule. They are responsible for transporting oxygen from the lungs to the tissues and returning carbon dioxide from the tissues to the lungs. In the circulatory system, RBCs tend to be centrally located within the lumen of blood vessels, including venules, due to the flow dynamics and their non-adhesive nature. Incorrect Options Option A. Lymphocytes   Lymphocytes are white blood cells involved in the immune response. They typically adhere to the endothelial cells lining the blood vessels or are found in the peripheral blood, but they are not centrally located within the lumen of venules. Option C. Neutrophils   Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that play a key role in the body's defense against infection. Similar to lymphocytes, they are more likely to be found near the vessel walls, especially during inflammation, rather than in the center of the lumen. Option D. Platelets   Platelets are small cell fragments involved in blood clotting. They are generally found close to the vessel walls where they can quickly adhere to sites of injury to form clots and stop bleeding, not in the center of the lumen.

questions.question: Which of the following causes vasodilation?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Histamine:   Histamine is a potent vasodilator released during allergic reactions and inflammation. questions.question: Which of the following is involved in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Inflammasome:   Inflammasomes are multiprotein complexes found within cells of the innate immune system.   When activated by various danger signals, including necrotic cell debris, inflammasomes assemble and activate caspase-1, which leads to the processing and release of pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1 β and IL-18.   While the primary function of inflammasomes is not the direct recognition and clearance of necrotic cells, their activation in response to necrotic cell debris can contribute to the induction of inflammatory responses and the clearance of necrotic cells by attracting immune cells. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are not involved in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells.

questions.question: Which of the following is an opsonin?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - C3b:   C3b is a component of the complement system. Option D - C6: C6 participates in the formation of the membrane attack complex, which helps destroy pathogens.

questions.question: Match the following with their correct terms. 1 Exon i Non-coding region 2 Intron ii One of the alternate forms of a single gene occupying a given position in a chromosome 3 Locus iii Coding region 4 Allele iv Location of a gene on the chromosome 1 Exon i Non-coding region 2 Intron ii One of the alternate forms of a single gene occupying a given position in a chromosome 3 Locus iii Coding region 4 Allele iv Location of a gene on the chromosome
questions.solution: Correct answer: A) 1-iii, 2-i, 3-iv, 4-ii Explanation: Exon :   An exon is a coding region of a gene that contains the genetic information necessary for producing a functional protein. Intron :   An intron is a non-coding region of a gene that intervenes between exons.   During gene expression, introns are removed from the pre-mRNA molecule through splicing, which allows exons to be joined together to form the final mRNA transcript before translation into a protein. Locus :   A locus refers to the specific location of a gene or DNA sequence on a chromosome. Allele :   An allele is one of the alternate forms of a single gene occupying a given position in a chromosome , which can lead to different traits or characteristics.   Alleles can be dominant or recessive.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male from a tribal area of Madhya Pradesh presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. On examination, he appears pale, and jaundice is noted. Laboratory investigations reveal low hemoglobin levels and increased reticulocyte count. The peripheral blood smear shows numerous sickle-shaped erythrocytes. What is the most likely molecular mechanism underlying the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Correct answer: B) Missense mutation Explanation: The clinical presentation of a tribal male with the above-mentioned clinical features and sickle-shaped RBCs in the peripheral smear suggests sickle cell disease. A missense mutation (type of point mutation) is the underlying mechanism in the pathogenesis of this disease. Point mutation:   A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base.   Types: Missen se mut ationIt can be: Sickle cell anaemia. This point mutation involves substituting adenine for thymine at the sixth codon of the β-globin gene (GAG to GTG) , replacing glutamic acid with valine in the β-globin chain of haemoglobin. This single nucleotide change results in the formation of abnormal haemoglobin molecules (HbS) . Nonse nse mu tation (Option D)Change of an amino acid to a chain terminator or stop codon. (UAA, UGA, UAG) Example: Beta thalassemia This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. Chromosomal translocation (Option A) involves the exchange of genetic material between non-homologous chromosomes. E.g. Chronic myeloid leukemia- t(9;22). A frameshift mutation (Option C) is a type of genetic mutation that results from the insertion or deletion of nucleotides in a DNA sequence, causing a shift in the reading frame during translation. questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of frequent episodes of unexplained bleeding and easy bruising. His maternal grandfather had severe hemophilia A, but his mother is unaffected. The patient's father has no history of bleeding disorders. Upon further investigation, it was discovered that the patient's maternal grandmother is a carrier of the hemophilia A gene. Given his family history, which type of genetic inheritance pattern is most likely responsible for the expression of hemophilia A in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct answer: C) Pseudodominance Explanation : Pseudodominance occurs when a recessive allele appears to be expressed in the heterozygous condition due to the limited number of crossovers between linked genes.   In pseudo dominance, a heterozygous individual (carrier) for a recessive allele exhibits the phenotype of the homozygous recessive individual due to the absence or inactivation of the dominant allele.   In this scenario, the patient's maternal grandmother is a carrier of the hemophilia A gene and has one normal X chromosome and one X chromosome with the mutated gene.   If the normal X chromosome is preferentially inactivated in her cells, she may exhibit the phenotype of hemophilia A, even though she is heterozygous for the condition. This phenomenon results in the appearance of hemophilia A in her descendants, leading to pseudo-dominance. Another example of pseudo-dominance is red-green colour blindness.

questions.question: A 6-month-old male infant presents to the pediatric clinic with failure to thrive, recurrent respiratory infections, and hepatosplenomegaly. Upon further examination, the infant also displays signs of skeletal abnormalities including bowed legs and frontal bossing. Lab investigations reveal pancytopenia with markedly decreased platelet count. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Gaucher disease. What is the pattern of inheritance and underlying genetic defect leading to this disorder?

options.A: Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the CFTR Gene
options.B: X-linked Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene
options.C: Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the HEXA Gene
options.D: Autosomal Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene

questions.solution: Correct answer: D) Autosomal Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene Explanation : Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism caused by mutations in the glucocerebrosidase - GBA1 gene. Three clinical subtypes of Gaucher disease have been distinguished:   Type I: Chronic non-neuronopathic form.   Type II: Acute neuronopathic form, also known as infantile acute cerebral pattern.   Type III: Intermediate between types I and II. MORPHOLOGY:   In Gaucher disease, glucocerebrosides accumulate massively within phagocytic cells throughout the body, forming distended cells known as Gaucher cells.   These cells, found in various organs including the spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lungs, exhibit a fibrillar cytoplasm resembling crumpled tissue paper.   They stain intensely positive with periodic acid–Schiff staining. Wright stain - Crumpled tissue paper Hematoxylin and eosin stain Other Diseases with Autosomal Recessive inheritance patterns: DISORDERS (Pasta Fried Chawal/ Big Fax) P - Phenylketonuria A - Alkaptonuria S - Sickle Cell Anemia Ta - Thalassemia Fried - Friedreich's Ataxia C - Cystic Fibrosis H - Hemophilia C, Homocystinuria, Hemochromatosis A - Alpha 1 Antitrypsin Deficiency W - Wilson Disease A - Albinism, Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia L - Lysosomal Storage Disease, Glycogen Storage Disease Big -Bloom Syndrome Fa - Fanconi Anemia, Ataxia Telangiectasia X - Xeroderma Pigmentosum (Big FAX) is also known as DNA repair defects Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the CFTR Gene (Option A): Cystic fibrosis (CF) is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene. (chromosome 7) X-linked Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene (Option B): Gaucher disease is not associated with X-linked inheritance; instead, it follows autosomal recessive inheritance. Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the HEXA Gene (Option C)   Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the HEXA gene, resulting in deficient activity of the enzyme β-hexosaminidase A   There are two isoenzymes of β-hexosaminidase: Hex A, consisting of two subunits, α and β , and Hex B, a homodimer of β-subunits.   Tay-Sachs disease, the most common form of GM2 gangliosidosis, results from mutations in the α-subunit locus on chromosome 15 that cause a severe deficiency of hexosaminidase A Features of Tay Sachs disease: Onion skin appearance Cherry red spot

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly, failure to thrive, and hypotonia. The infant has a cherry-red spot on the macula and exhibits poor startle reflexes on physical examination. Further evaluation reveals foam cells in the bone marrow. What is the diagnosis and associated enzyme deficiency?

options.A: Diagnosis: Niemann-Pick disease type A, Enzyme Deficiency: Acid sphingomyelinase
options.B: Diagnosis: Tay-Sachs disease, Enzyme Deficiency: Hexosaminidase A
options.C: Diagnosis: Gaucher disease, Enzyme Deficiency: Glucocerebrosidase
options.D: Diagnosis: Metachromatic leukodystrophy, Enzyme Deficiency: Arylsulfatase A

questions.solution: Correct answer: A) Diagnosis: Niemann-Pick disease type A, Enzyme Deficiency: Acid sphingomyelinase Explanation :   Niemann-Pick disease types A and B are related disorders characterized by lysosomal accumulation of sphingomyelin due to an inherited deficiency of sphingomyelinase.   Type A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement, marked visceral accumulations of sphingomyelin, progressive wasting and early death within the first 3 years of life.   In contrast, patients with type B disease have organomegaly but generally no central nervous system involvement. Patients usually survive into adulthood.   Affected cells become enlarged, due to the distention of lysosomes with sphingomyelin and cholesterol, imparting foaminess to the cytoplasm. Image : Niemann-Pick disease in the liver. The hepatocytes and Kupffer cells have a foamy, vacuolated appearance due to the deposition of lipids. Electron microscopy confirms that the vacuoles are engorged secondary lysosomes called zebra bodies . Image : Zebra bodies

questions.question: Sarah is a 3-year-old girl who is brought to her pediatrician by her parents due to concerns about her development. Her parents report that Sarah has been experiencing a loss of previously acquired skills, such as hand skills and language, stereotypic hand movements and seizure episodes . What is the mode of inheritance?
questions.solution: Correct answer: A) X-linked dominant Explanation: The clinical manifestations in the patients point to Rett Syndrome. It has X-linked dominant inheritance. X-linked dominant disorders are genetic conditions caused by mutations in genes located on the X chromosome. Unlike X-linked recessive disorders, which affect males more commonly due to having only one X chromosome, X-linked dominant disorders affect both males and females.   All fathers that are affected by an X-linked dominant disorder will have affected daughters but not affected sons.   However, if the mother is also affected then sons will have a chance of being affected, depending on whether a dominant or recessive X chromosome is passed on. When the son is affected, the mother will always be affected. Examples of X-linked dominant disorders ( Mnemonic : RAVI-C):

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Kyphoscoliotic EDS - Autosomal Recessive Explanation:

questions.question: What type of inheritance pattern is associated with hypertrichosis pinnae?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Holandric Explanation: Hypertrichosis, characterized by excessive hair growth on ears, is a rare genetic condition that can be associated with genes located on the Y chromosome. Since the Y chromosome is only present in males and is passed from fathers to sons, holandric traits are exclusively observed in males and are inherited from fathers.

questions.question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to excessive bleeding after a minor injury. His mother reports that his grandfather also had similar bleeding episodes. Laboratory tests reveal a deficiency in factor IX. What is the mode of inheritance for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct answer: C) X-linked recessive Explanation: Factor IX deficiency, associated with Hemophilia B, is an X-linked recessive disorder that predominantly affects males, as evidenced by the family history. X-Linked Recessive :   The gene for Hemophilia B is located on the X chromosome.   Males (XY) express the disorder if they inherit the affected X chromosome since they lack a second X for compensation.   Females (XX) can be carriers if they inherit one affected X chromosome, often showing no symptoms due to the normal allele on the other X.   Affected males cannot pass the disorder to sons but can pass the affected X to daughters, making them carriers. X-linked Recessive (WISE ABCDEFGH) Wise- Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome AB- Hemophilia A, B B- Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia . C- Chronic Granulomatous Disease, Red Green Color Blindness D- DMD, BMD E- Lesch Nyhan Syndrome F- Fabry Disease, Fragile X Syndrome G- G6PD Deficiency H- Hunter Disease

questions.question: A young male patient presented with recurrent episodes of acute neurologic dysfunction, cognitive changes, muscle weakness, and lactic acidosis. There is a family history of similar conditions depicted in the pedigree chart below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct answer: A) MELAS Explanation: MELAS -Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes:   The most common mutation observed in MELAS is in the gene encoding mitochondrial tRNA-leucine (MTTL1).   MELAS follows a unique non-Mendelian pattern of inheritance called maternal inheritance, as mitochondrial DNA is derived entirely from the ovum.   Affected mothers and daughters transmit the disease to both male and female children, whereas the affected sons don't transmit the affected DNA. (Mother to all, Father to none.)   The most common mitochondrial disease is MELAS.   The most common mitochondrial Myopathy is CPEO (chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia) Gonadal mosaicism   A genetic condition where a mutation is present in the ovaries or testes, but not in other cells of the body.   This can cause a parent to pass on a genetic condition to their children without developing it themselves. MERRF-Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (Option B) also follows the maternal inheritance pattern. Affected individuals have myoclonus (seizure disorder), and myopathy and are characterized by ragged red fibers on muscle biopsy with Gomori methenamine stain.

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis of a 5-year-old child with hyperphagia, delayed milestones, and growth retardation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Prader-Willi syndrome Explanation: Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) affects the SNORP gene on chromosome 15q.   PWS is due to paternal deletion and maternal imprinting of the given gene.   Subset of PWS can also occur due to maternal disomy   Clinical features: Mental retardation Short stature Hypotonia Obesity (due to increase levels of ghrelin)   Mental retardation   Short stature   Hypotonia   Obesity (due to increase levels of ghrelin)   Mental retardation   Short stature   Hypotonia   Obesity (due to increase levels of ghrelin) Obesity, almond shape eyes, down-turned mouth and straight borders of inner legs, Straight borders of ulnar side of hands and scares from skin picking, Active and healing skin lesions on scalp Angelman syndrome (Option A) has a similar genetic basis to PWS but is caused by absent maternal expression of 15q11-q13, involving the UBE3A gene, while the paternal allele is imprinted.   Clinical manifestations (Mnemonic- SARI ) S eizure A taxia Mental R etardation I nappropriate laughter (These patients are called happy puppets)   S eizure   A taxia   Mental R etardation   I nappropriate laughter (These patients are called happy puppets)   S eizure   A taxia   Mental R etardation   I nappropriate laughter (These patients are called happy puppets) Fragile X syndrome (Option C) is an X-linked dominant disorder characterized by classic phenotypic features (tall, long, narrow face with prominent jaw and forehead, large ears, deep-set eyes, macroorchidism).

questions.question: Which of the following does not show the same pattern of inheritance as Leber hereditary optic neuropathy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Fragile-X syndrome Explanation:   Fragile-X syndrome shows X-linked Recessive > X-linked dominant inheritance.   Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is characterized by permanent loss of vision in young men due to progressive, bilateral optic neuropathy. LHON demonstrates mitochondrial inheritance.   Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited solely maternally. Thus, females with causative mtDNA may transmit the disease to all offspring. However, the disease's expression is variable due to heteroplasmy (the combination of both mutant and wild DNA in offspring).   Mitochondrial diseases thus affect organs with prominent aerobic metabolism. Skeletal muscle (myopathy) and nervous system involvement are common. Some other examples are:   Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)/ Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS)   Leigh syndrome   Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS)   Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF)   Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP)   Primary coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) deficiency

In Introns/ Non coding region: Fragile X syndrome - CGG Friedreich ataxia - GAA Myotonic dystrophy -CTG   Fragile X syndrome - CGG   Friedreich ataxia - GAA   Myotonic dystrophy -CTG   Fragile X syndrome - CGG   Friedreich ataxia - GAA   Myotonic dystrophy -CTG   In Exons/ Coding region: Huntington's disease - CAG (Mnemonic- Hunter in a Cage)   Huntington's disease - CAG (Mnemonic- Hunter in a Cage)   Huntington's disease - CAG (Mnemonic- Hunter in a Cage)

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with brief, abrupt, involuntary movements of his arms and face for the last 2 months. A history of Huntington's disease in his father, who was diagnosed at 40 years of age and passed away at the age of 50, is found. What is the mechanism behind this patient’s earlier presentation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Anticipation Explanation: The given case scenario describes a young male with Huntington’s disease who has manifested the disease at a younger age than his father.   HD is a trinucleotide repeat disorder (CAG) that is characterized by psychiatric disturbances and choreoathetosis early on, with cognitive disturbance and death later.   HD is characterized by anticipation. Anticipation refers to the phenomenon whereby a genetic disease manifests earlier and is more severe in subsequent generations.   It is typically seen in trinucleotide repeat disorders due to increased trinucleotide repeats in the genome of subsequent generations. Examples of diseases showing anticipation include: Autosomal Dominant Autosomal Recessive Multiple spinocerebellar ataxias Friedreich’s ataxia – GAA Huntington’s disease – CAG repeats X-linked Myotonic dystrophy – CTG Fragile X Syndrome – CGG Congenital dyskeratosis – TTAGGG (telomere repeating sequence) Others Crohn’s disease Behcet’s disease Mosaicism (Option B) refers to the presence of two genetically different cell lines in the same individual, which results in variable phenotypic expression. An example is Turner syndrome. Imprinting (Option C) refers to a phenomenon where one copy of the gene is silenced via epigenetic mechanisms (e.g., methylation), and the other copy is expressed. Examples are Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes. Non-penetrance (Option D) - This is a scenario where the patient has a disease-causing mutation but does not have the phenotype or disease. An example is a BRCA1 mutation-positive female who never develops breast or ovarian cancer.

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of developmental delay and seizures. She is very jovial, has microcephaly and is diagnosed with happy puppet syndrome. What is the genetic basis for this child’s diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Imprinting Explanation: The given clinical scenario likely describes Angelman syndrome.   Angelman syndrome (AS) and Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) are examples of genetic imprinting, a phenomenon where one copy of the gene is silenced via epigenetic mechanisms (typically methylation) while the other is deleted/ mutated.   In AS, the paternal 15q11-q13 region is imprinted, while the maternal region is deleted/ mutated. In PWS, the opposite is true.   Implicated genes in UBE3 in AS and SNORP in PWS. Robertsonian translocation (Option B) is characterized by the amplification of a sequence of three nucleotides.   This refers to the fusion of the long arms of two acrocentric chromosomes. Unbalanced translocation can result in the loss of genetic material, causing diseases like Down syndrome and Patau syndrome. Trinucleotide repeats (Option C) is characterized by the amplification of a sequence of three nucleotides.   This refer to an excessive and unstable number of trinucleotide copies, which may cause diseases like HD, FXS, etc. Monosomy (Option D)   This refers to the loss of one chromosome from a pair. One prominent example is Turner’s syndrome (46XO).

questions.question: Which of the following explains a single mutant gene leading to different end effects in sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution: Correct answer: C) Pleiotropy Explanation: A single mutant gene leading to many end effects is called pleiotropism , whereas mutations at several genetic loci producing a similar phenotypic effect are called genetic heterogeneity.   Sickle cell anemia is an example of pleiotropy with a single gene mutation causing multiple physical effects.   The mutation produces hemoglobin S (HbS) , which makes red blood cells prone to hemolysis.   Additionally, it can lead to complications like splenic fibrosis, organ infarcts, and bone pains.   All these diverse effects on different organs stem from the initial issue of HbS production. Variable penetrance (Option B) refers to a condition where individuals inherit the mutant gene but are phenotypically normal. Variable expressivity (Option A) refers to the phenomenon where individuals with the same genetic mutation display different levels and types of symptoms or traits.   For example, with Marfan syndrome, one person might experience primarily skeletal issues while another could have serious cardiovascular problems, but all these are due to a single primary defect i.e. mutation in the gene FBN1 encoding fibrillin-1.

questions.question: A group of researchers studying genetic material noticed the presence of both wild-type and mutated mitochondrial genomes in different mitochondria of the same cells. What does this finding indicate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Heteroplasmy Explanation: The presence of both wild-type and mutated mitochondrial genomes in different mitochondria of the same cell is called heteroplasmy.   A minimum number of mutant mtDNAs must be present in a cell to give rise to a disease.   This is called the “threshold effect.” Trinucleotide expansion (Option C) is characterized by the amplification of a sequence of three nucleotides. Copy number variation (CNV) (Option A) is a molecular phenomenon in which nuclear genome sequences are repeated, and the number of repeats varies between individuals of the same species.   They contribute to human population diversity. Imprinting (Option D) refers to selectively inactivating a gene's maternal or paternal allele, also known as transcriptional silencing.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presents with intentional tremors, cerebellar ataxia, and intellectual disability. His father had similar symptoms at 60 and died due to aortic dissection. The patient's son started showing tremors and has an intellectual disability and aggressive behavior. Additionally males of the family have large ears and mandibles. What condition is most likely affecting him?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Fragile X syndrome Explanation:   Fragile X Syndrome (FXS) is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males and the second most common cause overall after Down syndrome. It results from a trinucleotide expansion mutation in the FMR1 gene.   The FMR1 gene on the X chromosome contains CGG repeats. In FXS, these repeats amplify, leading to a full mutation (200-4000 repeats) in affected individuals.   Fragile X–-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome: A progressive neurodegenerative syndrome affecting carrier males, occurs when CGG repeat is between 55-200.   Fragile X-associated primary ovarian failure: Premature ovarian failure in carrier females, leading to menstrual irregularities and decreased fertility   Intellectual disability: IQ = 20-40   Physical phenotype: Includes a long face with a large mandible, large ears, and macroorchidism (enlarged testicles).   Neurological and neuropsychiatric manifestations: Epilepsy, aggressive behavior, autism spectrum disorder, anxiety disorder, and hyperactivity.   PCR-based detection of CGG repeats is the method of choice for diagnosis, replacing cytogenetic methods.

questions.question: A one-month-old infant presents with developmental delays and physical features such as a prominent occiput, low-set ears, clenched hands with overlapping fingers, and a small mouth with a protruding tongue. Heart murmurs and rocker-bottom foot deformity are also noted. Which syndrome is the most likely cause of these features?
questions.solution: Correct option: D) Edward syndrome Explanation: Edward syndrome is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18- Trisomy 18. Features:   Low birth weight   Closed fists with overlapping fingers   Rocker-bottom feet   Microcephaly   Micrognathia   Cardiac and renal malformations   Mental retardation   95% of cases die in the 1st year of life   Noonan syndrome (Option A) is associated with mutations in the PTPN11 gene and typically presents with characteristic facial features, congenital heart defects, and short stature.   (Male counterpart of Turner's syndrome)-Noonan syndrome differs from Turner syndrome by having decreased IQ (normal in Turner) and normal fertility (decreased in Turner).   Down syndrome results from Trisomy 21 (Option B) and is characterized by intellectual disability, characteristic facial features, and various congenital anomalies.   Patau syndrome , or Trisomy 13 (Option C) , is associated with multiple physical abnormalities such as cleft lip and palate, congenital heart defects, and severe intellectual disability.

questions.question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for delayed milestones. Upon examination, the pediatrician notices several physical features, including upward-slanting eyes, a flat facial profile, a protruding tongue, and a single palmar crease. Which type of inheritance is definitely not present in this child?
questions.solution: Correct option: D) Autosomal recessive inheritance Explanation: The modes of inheritance of Down’s syndrome are as follows.   Meiotic Nondisjunction of chromosome 21 (95%) (Option A): This is associated with advanced maternal age. In most cases, the nondisjunction occurs in the Ovum.   Robertsonian Translocation (4%) (Option B): This is not associated with the mother's age. Translocation occurs via the long arm of other acrocentric chromosomes, like Chr. 22/14. There is some degree of familial inheritance in such translocations.   Mitotic Nondisjunction (1%) (Option C ):This leads to mosaicism, in which few of the cells are triploid, and few are normal.

questions.question: A 6-month-old child has recently passed away after a long ICU stay. Examination reveals microphthalmia and microcephaly. Other known diagnoses included ventricular septal defect, polycystic kidney disease, and omphalocele at birth. What is the chromosome involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Chromosome 13 Explanation: The given scenario describes Patau syndrome or Trisomy 13. Clinical features and associations include   Rocker-bottom feet   Severe intellectual disability   Keyhole/ Coloboma (eyes)   Microphthalmia, microcephaly, holoprosencephaly   Cleft lip/palate   Polydactyly   Congenital heart disease   Renal defects-Polycystic kidney disease   Umbilical hernia,Omphalocele Defects occur due to impaired mesoderm fusion in the midline. Affected children usually pass away before one year of age. Screening may establish prenatal diagnosis - low hCG, PAPP-A in 1st trimester.   Trisomy 21 is Down syndrome . Patients can live well into adulthood. (Option A)   Trisomy 18 is Edward syndrome . Similar to PS, patients typically pass away early in life. Clinical features include prominent occiput, rocker-bottom feet, intellectual disability, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, low-set ears, micrognathia (small jaw), omphalocele, and myelomeningocele. (Option B)   XYY syndrome (Jacobs syndrome) is a rare, sporadically inherited disorder. Features include intellectual disability and tall stature. (Option D)

questions.question: A 30-year-old tall male patient presents to the clinic for fertility treatment. He undergoes testing and is found to have low sperm counts. He has a history of diabetes, and a physical examination reveals gynecomastia, small testes, and minimal facial and body hair. What chromosomal abnormality is most likely causing this condition in the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) 47,XXY Explanation:   Based on the above clinical scenario, the patient can be diagnosed with Klinefelter syndrome.   Klinefelter syndrome is male hypogonadism resulting from two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes.   Karyotype: The most common is 47, XXY, from meiotic nondisjunction; some have mosaic patterns (e.g., 46, XY/47, XXY).   X chromosome genes: Some genes escape inactivation, leading to uneven dosage compensation and overexpression. 45, X (Turner syndrome) (Option A) : In females, one X chromosome is absent, leading to short stature. 47, XXX (Option C) : Triple X syndrome in females, characterized by tall stature and potential learning or behavioral issues. 47, XYY (Option D) : XYY syndrome in males, associated with tall stature but typically without significant physical features of hypogonadism.

questions.question: An 18-year-old girl presents to the clinic due to the concern that she hasn't started menstruating yet. The girl has a short stature and a webbed neck. Physical examination reveals a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Turner syndrome Explanation:   Turner syndrome is characterized by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism in phenotypic females. The image below shows karyotyping in Turner syndrome. Mullerian agenesis (Option B) is a condition where the uterus and upper part of the vagina are underdeveloped or absent, leading to primary amenorrhea. It does not typically include the physical features seen in Turner syndrome. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (Option C) can cause primary amenorrhea but is not associated with the physical features seen in Turner syndrome. 47, XXX syndrome (Option D) may lead to tall stature but is not typically associated with the specific physical features and primary amenorrhea seen in Turner syndrome.

questions.question: A 3-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, short stature, a heart murmur, and characteristic facial features, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct answer: A) Noonan syndrome Explanation:   The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Noonan syndrome, which is typically caused by mutations in genes such as PTPN11, SOS1, and RAF1.   Noonan syndrome is characterized by distinctive facial features, including wide-set eyes, a large head, a drooping face, short stature, developmental delay, and heart defects.   The presence of a heart murmur, along with characteristic facial features and developmental delay, is highly suggestive of Noonan syndrome.   Additional clinical factors may include easy bruising or bleeding, dry skin, sensorineural deafness, and lymphedema, which can aid in the diagnosis.   Genetic testing can confirm the presence of mutations associated with Noonan syndrome. Williams syndrome (Option C) is unlikely due to the absence of characteristic facial features and the uncommon presentation of a heart murmur. Turner syndrome (Option D) is unlikely in a male patient and is characterized by specific physical features not present in this case.

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with tall stature and long limbs, along with a history of frequent joint dislocations. Upon physical examination, he exhibits long fingers ,sunken chest, and an echocardiogram shows a dilated aortic root. Considering these clinical features, which of the following genes are commonly mutated in this condition?
questions.solution: CCorrect answer: A) FBN 1 Explanation: Marfan's syndrome is due to mutation in Fibrillin (FBN) 1 Gene on chromosome 15 Revised Ghent's Criteria: 1. Family history (Autosomal Dominant) 2. Clinical features 3. Fibrillin 1 Gene analysis. Clinical Features: Marfan D isease The most common Clinical Manifestation is Skeletal Abnormalities. questions.question: A couple seeks medical advice after their daughter presents with frequent nosebleeds and easy bruising. Lab investigations reveal prolonged bleeding time, prolonged aPTT, and a normal PT. A detailed history and a pedigree analysis were obtained, suspecting a genetic disorder. Based on the pedigree chart, what is this condition's most likely inheritance pattern?
questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: B) Autosomal dominant EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation of a female with frequent nosebleeds, easy bruising, prolonged bleeding time & aPTT, and normal PT is suggestive of Von Willebrand disease. The pedigree chart shows a vertical transmission pattern with no skipping of generations and is suggestive of autosomal dominant inheritance. Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern:   The mode of transmission is vertical . An affected person has an affected parent.   There is a 50% chance of the dominant trait being transmitted to offspring.   Both males and females are equally affected. Examples of autosomal dominant disorders: Mne mon icDisease HeH ereditary spherocytosis H ereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia H ereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC/Lynch syndrome) HasH untington’s disease H ypertrophic cardiomyopathy AA utosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease VeryVon Willebrand disease V on Hippel Lindau syndrome Do min antD ystonia myotonica O steogenesis imperfecta M arfan’s syndrome I ntermittent porphyria N F-1 & 2 A chondroplasia N oonan syndrome T uberous sclerosis Pow erfulP seudohypoparathyroidism Fath erF amilial adenomatous polyposis Li F raumeni syndrome F amilial hypercholesterolemia

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of unsteady gait and frequent falls. Upon further inquiry, it is revealed that he has experienced progressive difficulty with coordination and balance over the past few years. His parents report a similar history in his older sister, who is now 15 years old. Interestingly, the parents are both asymptomatic, but the boy's maternal uncle was diagnosed with a similar condition in his late 20s. What is the most likely inheritance pattern seen in this condition?
questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: D)Autosomal recessive EXPLANATION: The progressive difficulty with coordination and balance in both siblings, along with the maternal uncle's being affected, suggests Friedreich's ataxia (A repeat expansion of the trinucleotide GAA (guanine-adenine-adenine), typically in the gene's first intron, is the leading cause of this disease) a pattern consistent with autosomal recessive inheritance. In this scenario, both parents are likely carriers of a defective gene responsible for Friedreich's ataxia, and each sibling has inherited two copies of the defective gene , resulting in the development of this disorder. Autosomal recessive inheritance:   Autosomal recessive disorders require both copies of the gene (one from each parent) to be affected for the condition to manifest. questions.question: A 25-year-old male has been complaining of painless, progressive central vision loss in both eyes over the past few months. He reports a family history of similar visual problems, with his maternal grandfather and maternal uncle experiencing sudden vision loss in their 20s. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes bilateral optic disc pallor and central scotomas on visual field testing. The patient denies any systemic symptoms or significant medical history. What is the inheritance pattern seen in this condition?
questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: D) EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation, along with the family history of sudden vision loss in multiple maternal relatives, is highly suggestive of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) , a maternally inherited mitochondrial disorder affecting the optic nerves. Mitochondrial inheritance:   A unique feature of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is maternal inheritance.   This peculiarity exists because ova contain numerous mitochondria within their abundant cytoplasm, whereas spermatozoa contain few, if any.   Hence the mtDNA complement of the zygote is derived entirely from the ovum.   Thus, mothers transmit mtDNA to all their offspring , male and female.   Daughters transmit the DNA to their further progeny.   Properties: mtDNA encodes enzymes involved in oxidative phosphorylation , mutations affecting these genes exert their deleterious effects primarily on the organs most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation such as the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys. Each mitochondrion contains thousands of copies of mtDNA, and typically, deleterious mutations affect some, but not all, of these copies. Thus, tissues and individuals may harbor both wild-type and mutant mtDNA, which is known as heteroplasmy. A minimum number of mutant mtDNAs must be present in a cell or tissue before oxidative dysfunction causes disease. This is called the threshold effect. Mitochondria and their contained DNA are randomly distributed to the daughter cells during cell division. Thus when a cell containing normal and mutant mtDNA divides, the proportion of the normal and mutant mtDNA in daughter cells is extremely variable. Therefore the expression of disorders resulting from mutations in mtDNA is quite variable.   mtDNA encodes enzymes involved in oxidative phosphorylation , mutations affecting these genes exert their deleterious effects primarily on the organs most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation such as the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys. questions.question: A 45-year-old woman has been newly diagnosed with breast cancer. Histopathological analysis of the tumour reveals invasive ductal carcinoma. Which diagnostic method is most appropriate for detecting HER2/neu amplification in this patient?
questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: B) Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) EXPLANATION:   FISH uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions.   In the case of HER2 testing, FISH directly visualizes HER2 gene amplification by labelling the HER2 gene with a fluorescent probe.   HER2 protein overexpression is virtually always caused by amplification of the region of chromosome 17q that contains the HER2 gene.   The increase in HER2 gene copy number is detected by fluorescence in situ hybridization using a HER2-specific probe (red signal), which is typically co-hybridized to tumour cell nuclei with a second probe specific for the centromeric region of chromosome 17 (green signal), allowing the chromosome 17 copy number to be determined.   FISH can be used for testing: Chromosomal translocations Deletions Amplifications FISH cannot detect point mutations.   Chromosomal translocations   Deletions   Amplifications   FISH cannot detect point mutations.   Chromosomal translocations   Deletions   Amplifications   FISH cannot detect point mutations. Immunohistochemistry (IHC): (Option A) IHC involves staining tissue samples with antibodies specific to HER2/neu protein. While widely used for HER2 testing, it does not directly measure gene amplification Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) (Option C ) PCR amplifies DNA sequences, including the HER2 gene, from tumour samples. It can detect gene amplification but It is not commonly used for HER2 testing in breast cancer patients. Western Blotting (Option D) Western blotting detects specific proteins in a sample but does not directly measure gene amplification. It is not commonly used for HER2 testing in breast cancer patients.

questions.question: Which technique is specifically designed to detect copy number variations (CNVs) in the genome by comparing patient DNA with a reference DNA sample?
questions.solution: Correct Answer : B) Comparative Genomic Hybridization (CGH) Explanation: Comparative Genomic Hybridization (CGH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique used to detect copy number variations (CNVs) in the genome, including microdeletions and microduplications. It involves comparing the patient's DNA with a reference DNA sample, often labelled with different fluorescent dyes, to identify gains or losses of genetic material. Schematic for Comparative Genomic Hybridization : Uses of Comparative Genomic Hybridization:   Detection of Copy Number Variations (CNVs) : Identifies gains and losses of DNA segments.   Diagnosis of Genetic Disorders : Detects chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., microdeletions, microduplications) linked to developmental and congenital disorders (e.g., Williams, DiGeorge syndrome).   Cancer Genomics : Identifies chromosomal imbalances in cancer cells, including gene amplifications or deletions (e.g., in breast cancer, and gliomas).   Prenatal Screening : Detects chromosomal abnormalities in fetuses, such as Down syndrome and other congenital defects.   Assessment of Structural Variations : Identifies larger structural changes (e.g., duplications, deletions, inversions, translocations).   Neurodevelopmental Disorders : Identifies CNVs linked to conditions like autism spectrum disorders.   Genomic Research : Provides insights into the genetic basis of diseases by identifying recurrent CNVs in patient populations.   Personalized Medicine : Identifies genetic alterations that guide targeted therapies, particularly in cancer. PCR: Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is used for amplifying specific DNA sequences and is not specifically designed to detect CNVs. (Option A) DNA sequencing: DNA sequencing is used to determine the precise order of nucleotides in a DNA molecule and is not primarily focused on detecting CNVs. (Option C) Southern blotting: Southern blotting is a technique used to detect specific DNA sequences, often related to gene expression or mutations, but it is not tailored for CNV detection. (Option D)

questions.question: Identify the type of inheritance?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Autosomal Dominant Inheritance:   In autosomal dominant inheritance, a single copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the trait or disorder.   The trait or disorder will be present in every generation, as affected individuals pass the mutated gene to their offspring.   Individuals with one affected parent have a 50% chance of inheriting the trait.   For example, if a parent has a dominant genetic disorder like Huntington's disease, there's a 50% chance their child will inherit the disorder. Incorrect Options: Option B - Autosomal Recessive Inheritance:   In autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) are required to manifest the trait or disorder.   Carriers of a single mutated gene are usually healthy but can pass on the mutation to their offspring.   The trait or disorder might skip generations if carriers do not have affected children.   When two carriers have a child, there's a 25% chance the child will have the disorder, a 50% chance of being a carrier, and a 25% chance of having neither the disorder nor being a carrier.   An example is cystic fibrosis. Option C - X-Linked Dominant Inheritance:   X-linked dominant inheritance involves a mutated gene on the X chromosome.   A single copy of the mutated gene on one of the X chromosomes is sufficient to cause the trait or disorder in females (since they have two X chromosomes) and in males (who have one X chromosome).   Affected fathers pass the disorder to all their daughters, but not to their sons.   Affected mothers have a 50% chance of passing the disorder to both sons and daughters.   An example is Rett syndrome. Option D - X-Linked Recessive Inheritance:   X-linked recessive inheritance also involves a mutated gene on the X chromosome.   Males are more commonly affected because they have only one X chromosome.   Carrier mothers (with one normal and one mutated X chromosome) can pass the mutation to their sons (who get their X chromosome from the mother) and to half of their daughters (who inherit the mutated X chromosome).   Carrier fathers pass the mutated gene only to their daughters, who become carriers.   An example is color blindness.

questions.question: A 30-year-old pregnant woman who has the thalassemia trait visits the clinic for genetic counseling. Her husband is also confirmed to have the thalassemia trait. Considering their genetic background, what is the likelihood of their next offspring having thalassemia?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - 25%:   When both parents are carriers of the thalassemia trait (heterozygous), the Punnett square analysis shows that there's a 25% chance for their offspring to inherit two mutated copies of the gene (one from each parent), resulting in thalassemia. There is a 50% chance of inheriting one normal and one mutated gene (being a carrier like the parents), and a 25% chance of inheriting two normal copies of the gene. Incorrect Options: Option A - 100%: This would mean that all of their offspring would definitely have thalassemia, which is not the case. Thalassemia is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder, meaning that both copies of the gene need to carry the mutation for the disorder to manifest. Since both parents have thalassemia trait, they each carry one normal copy of the gene and one mutated copy. Therefore, there is a chance that their offspring may inherit one normal copy from one parent and one mutated copy from the other, resulting in carrying the thalassemia trait, but not necessarily having thalassemia. Option B - 50%: This would imply that each offspring has a 50% chance of having thalassemia. While it's true that each child has a 50% chance of inheriting the mutated gene from either parent, the probability of them having thalassemia depends on both copies of the gene being mutated, which is less likely. Option C - 75%: This would suggest that there's a higher likelihood of having thalassemia than not. However, the probability of an offspring having thalassemia is not this high. It's important to remember that the trait they both have is the heterozygous form (thalassemia trait), which means they each have one normal gene and one mutated gene. This significantly reduces the probability of their offspring having thalassemia

Affected males do not pass the mitochondrial gene to their children, and they do not have affected children. Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and C are incorrect. questions.question: With which pattern of disease inheritance is consanguinity associated?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Autosomal Recessive:   Consanguinity refers to a close blood relationship between the parents.   Autosomal recessive diseases are more likely to occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples.   This is because the parents may both carry a single copy of a recessive gene mutation, and when they have children together, there is an increased chance of both parents passing on the mutated gene, resulting in the expression of the disease phenotype in the offspring. Incorrect Options: Option B - Autosomal Dominant:   Autosomal dominant diseases can occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples, but they are not specifically associated with consanguinity.   Autosomal dominant diseases can also arise from de novo mutations or occur in non-consanguineous families. Option C - X-Linked Recessive:   X-linked recessive diseases are inherited through the X chromosome.   Although consanguinity can increase the likelihood of inheriting X-linked recessive diseases, it is not the characteristic pattern associated with consanguinity. Option D - X-Linked Dominant:   X-linked dominant diseases can also occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples, but they are less common and not specifically associated with consanguinity.

questions.question: All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - PML-RARA:   ATRA is a medication derived from vitamin A and is used as a differentiation therapy in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia, a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).   APL is characterized by the presence of the PML-RARA fusion gene, resulting from a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17 [t(15;17)].   This translocation fuses the promyelocytic leukemia (PML) gene on chromosome 15 with the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) gene on chromosome 17.   The PML-RARA fusion protein blocks the normal differentiation of myeloid cells and contributes to leukemogenesis.   ATRA acts by binding to the RARA portion of the fusion protein, promoting the differentiation of leukemic cells into mature granulocytes.   It helps to restore normal hematopoiesis by inducing the terminal differentiation and apoptosis of leukemic cells. Incorrect Options:   ATRA is not used in the treatment of options B, C, and D.

questions.question: A family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Autosomal Dominant:   There is male-to-male transmission of disease; hence, it should not be X-liked.   Every generation is affected; hence, it is the dominant pattern. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the Mendelian mode of inheritance?

options.A: 2/3 rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal dominant
options.B: 1/3 rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal recessive
options.C: Every 5 th patient is X-linked recessive

questions.solution: Correct Option D - Every 10 th patient is Y-linked Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following disorders is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Rett Syndrome:   Rett syndrome is a rare genetic disorder inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.   Rett syndrome primarily affects females, although in rare cases, it can affect males as well.   It is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene, which is responsible for producing a protein that is essential for the normal development of the brain.   The loss of function of this protein leads to a disruption in the development of the nervous system, resulting in the characteristic symptoms of the disorder.   The symptoms of Rett syndrome typically appear around 6-18 months of age and can include a loss of developmental milestones, a loss of purposeful hand movements, a loss of speech, and the development of repetitive hand movements.   Other features of the syndrome can include breathing irregularities, seizures, scoliosis, and cognitive impairment.   Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern; affected mothers have a 50% chance of passing the mutated gene to each of their children. Incorrect Options: Option B - Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy:   Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an inherited disorder that is caused by mutations in the DMD gene, which is located on the X chromosome.   DMD is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. Option C - Huntington's Disease :   This disorder is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Option D - Tuberous Sclerosis:   Tuberous sclerosis is an inherited disorder that is caused by mutations in either the TSC1 or TSC2 genes, which are located on chromosomes 9 and 16, respectively.   The disorder is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

questions.question: The SRY gene is present on:
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Y-Chromosome Short Arm:   The SRY gene is found on the short arm of the Y-chromosome.   The short arm of the Y-chromosome is referred to as the Yp.   The SRY gene is found on the Yp11.3 region. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: The below-given ANA pattern on IF is seen; identify the pattern.
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Centromeric:   The centromeric pattern is characterized by staining around the centromeric region of chromosomes.   This pattern is associated with autoantibodies targeting centromere proteins, particularly centromere protein B (CENP-B).   It is most commonly seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, or CREST syndrome. Incorrect Options: Option A - Nucleolar:   The nucleolar pattern refers to the staining of autoantibodies within the nucleoli, which are specialized structures inside the nucleus involved in ribosome biogenesis.   This pattern is often associated with autoantibodies targeting nucleolar antigens, such as fibrillarin, nucleolin, or nucleophosmin.   The nucleolar pattern is frequently seen in autoimmune conditions like systemic sclerosis and mixed connective tissue disease. Option B - Speckled:   The speckled pattern appears as multiple discrete speckles throughout the nucleus.   It is the most common ANA pattern and can be associated with a variety of autoantibodies targeting different nuclear antigens.   Examples of speckled pattern-related autoantibodies include antibodies against extractable nuclear antigens (ENA), such as Smith (Sm), ribonucleoprotein (RNP), and Sjögren's syndrome-related antigens (SSA/SSB).   The speckled pattern can be found in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Sjögren's syndrome, and other autoimmune conditions. Option D - Diffuse:   The diffuse pattern refers to a uniform distribution of staining throughout the nucleus.   It is often a non-specific finding and does not indicate a specific autoimmune disease or autoantibody.   The diffuse pattern can be seen in various autoimmune diseases as well as in non-autoimmune conditions.

questions.question: What is the interpretation of the given pedigree chart?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Autosomal Dominant:   Every generation is affected; hence, it is the dominant pattern, i.e., autosomal dominant. Incorrect Options: Option A - Incomplete Penetrance:   Incomplete penetrance refers to a situation where an individual carries a gene mutation associated with a certain trait or condition but does not actually express the trait or condition. Option C - Autosomal Recessive:   An autosomal recessive inheritance pattern occurs when an individual needs to inherit two copies of a gene mutation, one from each parent, to express the trait or condition.   In a pedigree chart, autosomal recessive traits appear in a skipped generation pattern. Option D - Pseudo Dominance:   Pseudo dominance can occur when an autosomal recessive trait appears to be inherited in a dominant pattern due to the presence of consanguinity (intermarriage between close relatives) or a high frequency of carriers in a population.

questions.question: All of the following are used to detect abnormal gene sequences, except?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Flow Cytometry:   Flow cytometry is a technique used to analyze and measure certain characteristics of cells or particles in a fluid suspension.   It is commonly used for cell counting, cell sorting, and assessing cell characteristics such as size, granularity, and surface markers.   Flow cytometry does not directly detect alterations in DNA sequence. Incorrect Options: Option A - FISH:   FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) is a molecular cytogenetic technique used to detect and visualize specific DNA sequences on chromosomes or within cells. Option B - RFLP Analysis:   RFLP (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism) analysis is a technique used to detect variations in DNA sequences by digesting DNA samples with specific restriction enzymes.   RFLP analysis can provide information about genetic variations. Option C - Pyrosequencing:   Pyrosequencing is a DNA sequencing method that measures the release of pyrophosphate during DNA synthesis.   It allows for the identification of specific nucleotides and can be used to determine the sequence of DNA.

questions.question: A girl presents with short stature, a webbed neck, thick calves, a shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and an increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Turner syndrome:   Turner syndrome, also known as monosomy X, is a genetic disorder that affects females.   It occurs when one of the two X chromosomes is partially or completely missing.   The characteristic features of Turner syndrome include short stature, a webbed neck, thick calves, a shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and an increased carrying angle. Incorrect Options: Option B - Down syndrome:   Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is a different genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. It is characterized by distinct facial features and an intellectual disability. Option C & D - Patau syndrome & Edward syndrome:   Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) and Edward syndrome (trisomy 18) are both chromosomal disorders caused by the presence of an extra copy of either chromosome 13 or chromosome 18, respectively. They are associated with severe developmental abnormalities, intellectual disabilities, and multiple organ system defects.

questions.question: The mother of a 12-year-old girl was worried that her daughter is shorter when compared with her classmates. On examination, the child has a webbed neck, a low hairline, and a shield-shaped chest. A provisional diagnosis of Turner syndrome was made. Which of the following is a likely finding to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Bilateral small streak ovaries:   This is a hallmark feature of Turner syndrome.   Due to the absence or underdevelopment of normal ovarian tissue, individuals with Turner syndrome typically have streak ovaries, which are fibrous structures devoid of functional follicles.   This leads to ovarian insufficiency and infertility. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are not seen in Turner syndrome.

questions.question: A boy was diagnosed with a medical condition that is believed to have been passed down from his grandmother to his father, and now to him. What is the pattern of inheritance in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Autosomal Dominant:   Autosomal dominant inheritance occurs when the gene responsible for the condition is located on one of the autosomes (non-sex chromosomes), typically on one of the numbered chromosomes.   In this pattern of inheritance, a single copy of the gene is sufficient to express the trait.   If the boy inherited the condition from his grandmother and his father, it indicates that the gene is on one of the autosomes and is dominant. Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.solution: Correct Option A - Autosomal dominant:   There is male-to-male transmission of disease; hence, it should not be X-liked.   Every generation is affected; hence, it is the dominant pattern. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.question: A karyotyping image is given below. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such patients?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Gynecomastia and Long Limbs:   The karyotyping image shows an extra copy of the X chromosome, indicating the presence of Klinefelter syndrome (47XXY).   Klinefelter syndrome is a chromosomal disorder that occurs in males due to the presence of an additional X chromosome.   Clinical features of Klinefelter syndrome: Gynecomastia Long limbs Infertility: Klinefelter syndrome is the most common cause of male hypogonadism and infertility.
