questions.question: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome, except:
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Microorchidism:   Fragile X syndrome is not associated with microorchidism.   However, it is associated with macroorchidism.   Macroorchidism becomes more evident during puberty and is a characteristic finding in males with fragile X syndrome. Incorrect Options: Option A - Trinucleotide mutation in FMR-1 gene:   Fragile X syndrome is caused by an expansion of CGG trinucleotide repeats in the FMR-1 gene.   This expansion leads to a decreased production of fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP), resulting in the characteristic features of the syndrome. Option B - Mental retardation:   Intellectual disability is a hallmark feature of fragile X syndrome.   It can range from mild to severe and is often associated with learning difficulties, speech and language delays, and behavioural challenges. Option D - Large everted ears:   Individuals with fragile X syndrome commonly exhibit large, prominent ears that are described as everted.

questions.question: Alpha-1 antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of which enzyme?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Elastase:   Elastase is an enzyme that breaks down elastin, a protein found in elastic tissues such as the lungs and blood vessels.   Alpha-1 antitrypsin is a potent inhibitor of elastase, preventing its excessive activity and protecting tissues from damage. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is most commonly associated with Down syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Alzheimer disease:   Alzheimer disease is the most commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome.   The accumulation of beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the brain, characteristic of Alzheimer disease, occurs at an earlier age and progresses more rapidly in individuals with Down syndrome. Incorrect Options : Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about stem cells?

options.C: They can divide without any regulatory stimulus

questions.solution: Correct Option C - They can divide without any regulatory stimulus:   Stem cells are undifferentiated cells that have the ability to differentiate into specialized cell types and self-renew through cell division.   Their division and differentiation are tightly regulated by various internal and external signals.   Stem cells require specific regulatory stimuli and signals to initiate and control their division. Incorrect Options: Option A - They can differentiate:   One of the defining characteristics of stem cells is their ability to differentiate into different cell types.   Depending on their potency, stem cells can give rise to a wide range of specialized cells in the body. Option B - They can replicate:   Stem cells can undergo self-renewal through replication.   This means they can produce identical copies of themselves during cell division, ensuring the maintenance of a stem cell population. Option D - They can regenerate damaged tissues:   Stem cells play a crucial role in tissue regeneration and repair.   They have the ability to differentiate into the specific cell types needed for tissue repair and can replace damaged or lost cells.

questions.question: What is the mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from color blindness?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - XLR:   The mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from color blindness is typically X-linked recessive (XLR). Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which chromosome is involved in myotonic dystrophy?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Chromosome 19:   Myotonic dystrophy is caused by an expansion of CTG trinucleotide repeats in the DMPK gene, which is located on chromosome 19.   This genetic mutation leads to the production of an abnormal form of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) and results in the characteristic symptoms of myotonic dystrophy. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which amino acid is necessary for the production of nitric oxide in the blood vessels?
questions.solution: Correct option B: Arginine:   Nitric oxide (NO) is a critical signalling molecule involved in various physiological processes, including vasodilation in blood vessels.   Arginine serves as the precursor for nitric oxide synthesis in the body.   When arginine is converted to nitric oxide, it undergoes enzymatic conversion by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS).   This conversion process involves the oxidation of arginine and the release of nitric oxide. Incorrect options: Options A, C, and D are not directly required for the formation of nitric oxide in the blood vessels.

options.B: Evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues Explanation:   Infiltration of cancer cells into adjacent structures is a key characteristic of malignancy.   The presence of invasion indicates aggressive tumour behaviour and increases the risk of metastasis to lymph nodes and distant organs. questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis of a patient with a painless, slowly enlarging mass in the right parotid gland region that is well-defined and heterogeneous, with both epithelial and mesenchymal components present in the biopsy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Pleomorphic adenoma Explanation:   Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumour of the salivary glands, often found in the parotid gland.   Pleomorphic adenoma, also known as a mixed tumour, typically contains epithelial components (such as glandular cells) and mesenchymal components (such as myxoid stroma, islands of cartilage, or bone). Mucoepidermoid carcinoma (Option B): It arises from the epithelial epithelial lining of the ducts and acini within the salivary glands, characterised by a mixture of mucin-producing, squamous, and intermediate cells. Acinic cell carcinoma (Option C): Acinic cell carcinoma is primarily an epithelial tumour arising from the acinar cells of the salivary glands. Warthin tumor/ Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum (Option D): It arises from the epithelial cells lining the ducts of the salivary glands, particularly the parotid gland and is characterised by cystic spaces lined with oncocytic epithelial cells and surrounded by lymphoid stroma.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female presents with pelvic pain and irregular menstrual cycles. She undergoes surgical resection of the mass, and histopathological examination reveals a tumour composed of mature tissues derived from multiple germ layers, including hair, teeth, and sebaceous material. Based on the histopathological findings described, which of the following tumours is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Teratoma Explanation:   Teratomas originate from totipotent germ cells (capability to differentiate into any cell type) present in the ovaries, testes, or abnormal midline embryonic rests.   Microscopic examination of the tumour confirms the diagnosis by identifying tissues derived from all three germ layers: Ectodermal tissue (epithelium and neural tissue), Mesodermal tissue (muscle, fat, bone, cartilage), and Endodermal tissue (thyroid tissue, gastrointestinal epithelium)   Ectodermal tissue (epithelium and neural tissue),   Mesodermal tissue (muscle, fat, bone, cartilage), and   Endodermal tissue (thyroid tissue, gastrointestinal epithelium)   Ectodermal tissue (epithelium and neural tissue),   Mesodermal tissue (muscle, fat, bone, cartilage), and   Endodermal tissue (thyroid tissue, gastrointestinal epithelium) Serous cystadenoma (Option B):   Lined by a single layer of cuboidal or columnar epithelium, often with cilia, resembling fallopian tube epithelium. Mucinous cystadenoma (Option C):   Lined by tall, mucin-secreting columnar epithelium without cilia, resembling intestinal or endocervical epithelium. Granulosa cell tumor (Option D):   Shows Call-Exner bodies (small, eosinophilic, rosette-like structures) and coffee bean-shaped nuclei, characteristic of granulosa cells.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with chronic heartburn and difficulty swallowing. questions.question: Which of the following features is not a characteristic of anaplasia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Intact basement membrane Explanation: An intact basement membrane is not characteristic of anaplasia. Anaplastic cells, which exhibit aggressive behaviour and loss of differentiation, often invade surrounding tissues, leading to disruption of the basement membrane. Anaplasia is characterised by several morphological changes indicative of aggressive behaviour in cancer cells:   Pleomorphism: Variability in cell size and shape. (Option A)   Atypical, bizarre mitotic figures: Abnormal forms of cell division indicative of rapid proliferation.   Abnormal nuclear morphology: Nuclei are disproportionately large, irregularly shaped, and have coarsely clumped chromatin.   Increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio: Often approaching or exceeding 1:1 instead of the normal range of 1:4 to 1:6. (Option C)   Loss of polarity: Disorganized growth pattern and loss of normal cell orientation. (Option B )   Anaplasia is the hallmark of malignancy. questions.question: Which of the following characteristics distinguishes hemangiomas from other benign tumors?

options.B: Presence of extracellular matrix (ECM) deposited by stromal cells

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Unencapsulated Explanation: A hemangioma is a benign vascular tumour caused by an abnormal overgrowth of blood vessels that is distinguished from other benign tumours by:   Lack of well-defined capsule.   Tendency to permeate the site of origin making it difficult for surgical excision. Rapid growth rate (Option A): The rapid growth rate is a feature of malignant tumors, not benign tumors which grow slowly and localized to the site of origin. Presence of extracellular matrix (ECM) deposited by stromal cells (Option B): Benign tumours usually has a capsule, which consists of an extracellular matrix (ECM) deposited by stromal cells such as fibroblasts. Since hemangioma is unencapsulated, it is not associated with the deposition of extracellular matrix by stromal cells. Easily resected by excision (Option C): Encapsulation makes benign tumours easily resectable but since hemangiomas are unencapsulated ,they permeate site of origin making it difficult to resect.

questions.question: Which of the following types of cancer is least likely to exhibit distant metastasis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Basal cell carcinoma Explanation:   Among malignant tumours, tumours such as gliomas and basal cell carcinomas of the skin (Option C), invade early but exhibit a low propensity for metastasis, emphasizing the divergence between invasiveness and metastatic potential. Renal cell carcinoma (Option A) Renal cell carcinoma often metastasises, frequently spreading to the lungs, bones, and other organs. questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Hepatocellular carcinoma Explanation:   Hepatocellular carcinoma typically exhibits metastasis by hematogenous spread rather than direct seeding of body cavities. questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the Sentinel lymph node?

options.A: The first lymph node to receive metastasis from a secondary tumour.
options.B: Also helpful in identifying metastasis in Melanoma.
options.D: The presence of cancer cells indicates a good prognosis

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Also helpful in identifying metastasis in Melanoma. Explanation: The Sentinel lymph node, the first lymph node to receive metastatic cells from a primary tumour, not a secondary tumour (Option A).   The sentinel lymph node is identified and removed using specialized techniques during surgery, such as lymphatic mapping and sentinel lymph node biopsy.   Sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly performed in various cancers, including breast cancer and melanoma, to determine the extent of disease spread.   This procedure aids in the staging of the carcinoma for planning treatment.   The presence of cancer cells in a lymph node indicates a more advanced stage of cancer and is generally associated with a poorer prognosis (Option D).   ‘Skip metastasis’ is a pattern of cancer spread where tumour cells bypass the sentinel lymph node and directly metastasize to more distant lymph nodes or other organs (Option C).

questions.question: A 60-year-old man who has worked in the zinc mines presents to his urologist with urinary symptoms, including increased frequency, hesitancy, and nocturia. During a digital rectal examination, he is found to have an enlarged prostate with a palpable nodule. Which environmental exposure is most likely associated with his prostate cancer risk?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Cadmium Explanation: Occupational exposure to cadmium, commonly found in industries such as zinc mining, smelting of zinc ores, and battery manufacturing, has been associated with an increased risk of prostate cancer. The body accumulates cadmium through inhalation of dust and fumes containing cadmium particles. Zinc (Option A) Zinc is an essential trace element important for prostate health, excessive zinc exposure does not have a direct association with prostate cancer. Benzopyrene (Option B): Benzopyrene, a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) present in tobacco smoke and combustion products, is associated with increased risks of lung cancer, bladder cancer, skin cancer, and other malignancies. Arsenic (Option C): Prolonged exposure to arsenic can occur through contaminated water, soil, and food, commonly by the use of arsenic-based pesticides and herbicides. It is associated with an increased risk of developing skin, lung, bladder, and liver cancers.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with vinyl chloride exposure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Hepatic angiosarcoma Explanation: Hepatic angiosarcoma is a high-grade vascular malignancy and is the most common sarcoma arising in the liver, especially in those with significant exposure to Vinyl chloride. It is more common in men and occurs in the elderly. Some other risk factors include arsenic, anabolic steroids, radiation, and thorium dioxide (Thorotrast). Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option A) Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary liver cancer and is typically associated with cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis B or C infections due to HBV or HCV, alcohol abuse, or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and not associated with exposure to vinyl chloride. Cholangiocarcinoma (Option C) Cholangiocarcinoma (carcinoma of the biliary duct in the liver) includes conditions that lead to chronic inflammation of the bile ducts, such as Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), liver fluke infections such as Clonorchis and Opisthorcis, or certain jbiliary tract disorders. It is not associated with vinyl chloride exposure . Focal nodular hyperplasia (Option D) Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is the second most common benign liver lesion after hepatic hemangioma. It consists of hyperplastic hepatocytes surrounding a central scar, which can result from altered blood flow. FNH is more prevalent in women and is associated with hormonal imbalances but not with vinyl chloride exposure.

questions.question: A 16-year-old girl presents with a clear-cell vaginal tumour. Upon further inquiry, it was revealed that her mother has a history of taking medication during pregnancy to prevent premature labour. Which medication is most likely associated with the development of this tumour in the daughter?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) DES (Diethylstilbestrol) Explanation: In the given scenario, the clear cell vaginal tumour in the daughter is most likely linked to DES (Diethylstilbestrol). DES, a synthetic estrogen previously administered to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and pregnancy complications, has been associated with a significantly increased risk of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the cervix or vagina in daughters exposed to it in utero. Thalidomide (Option B): Thalidomide, once used to treat morning sickness in pregnant women, caused severe birth defects like limb deformities (phocomelia), blindness, deafness, heart issues, and brain damage in their babies. It is a teratogen, not a carcinogen. Tamoxifen (Option C): Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator used in the treatment of ER-positive breast cancer. While it is associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer in women who take it for breast cancer treatment, it's not linked to clear cell vaginal tumours in their daughters. Medroxyprogesterone acetate (Option D): It is a synthetic progestin commonly used in hormonal therapies and contraceptives. Long-term use or high doses of MPA, particularly in combination with estrogen, may increase the risk of breast cancer. However, maternal use of it is not typically associated with vaginal tumours in daughters.

questions.question: Which of the following radiations is the most common cause of skin cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) UV-B radiation Explanation:   UV-B radiation is the major cause of sunburn and skin cancer. These medium wavelengths (280-320 nm) primarily affect the outer layers of the skin and are highly mutagenic.   It is responsible for inducing the formation of pyrimidine dimers within DNA, leading to mutations that can result in various types of skin cancer, including squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, and melanoma.   Fair-skinned individuals are at higher risk. UV-A radiation (Option A): UV-A rays are longer wavelengths (320-400 nm) and penetrate deeper into the skin. They primarily cause skin ageing. UV-A radiation, particularly in combination with UV-B, can increase the risk of skin cancer. UV-C radiation (Option C) These shorter wavelengths (200-280 nm) are extremely potent in terms of DNA damage, but they are largely filtered out by the Earth's ozone layer and do not reach the surface in significant amounts. UV-D radiation (Option D): The UV spectrum typically consists of UV-A, UV-B, and UV-C and no UV-D radiation.

questions.question: A 55-year-old female radiology technician with 25 years of occupational exposure to diagnostic X-rays and fluoroscopy presents with a three-month history of increasing fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and frequent infections. Which cancer type is most likely associated with her occupational history?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Acute Myeloid Leukemia Explanation: Due to prolonged exposure to ionising radiation the patient is at an increased risk of developing Acute Myeloid Leukemia (M/C cancer in individuals with exposure to ionising radiation).   Ionising radiation, which includes electromagnetic (x-rays, γ rays) and particulate (α particles, β particles, protons, neutrons) radiations, is carcinogenic.   It can cause cancer by directly damaging cellular DNA, leading to mutations that disrupt normal gene function and structure.   Leukaemia often has a relatively short latent period, typically around 7 years or less after exposure to certain factors like radiation or chemicals. Solid tumours like breast, colon, thyroid, and lung cancers generally have longer latent periods compared to leukaemia. Pancreatic cancer (Option B):   Risk of Pancreatic cancer is more associated with cigarette smoking, heavy alcohol drinking, obesity, and diet (high intake of saturated fat and/or meat, particularly smoked or processed meats). Medullary thyroid cancer (Option C):   Medullary thyroid cancer is primarily associated with genetic factors, specifically mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, rather than radiation exposure.   However, the risk of Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid and Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid have a high association with radiation exposure. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (Option D): Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is the only leukaemia not associated with radiation exposure.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents for a routine gynaecological examination. Her Pap smear and biopsy reveals abnormal cells suggestive of cervical dysplasia. Further, HPV testing indicates the presence of specific HPV types associated with cervical cancer. Which HPV types are most commonly linked to an increased risk of cervical cancer in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) High-risk 16, 18 Explanation: The abnormal cells in the pap smear and biopsy are known as Koilocytes characterised by a raisinoid nucleus and a perinuclear halo, which indicates HPV infection.   High-risk HPV types like HPV 16 and HPV 18 are strongly linked to a higher risk of cervical cancer, including high-grade cervical dysplasia and invasive cancer.   Low-risk HPV types such as HPV 6 and HPV 11 are often associated with genital warts such as condyloma acuminatum and low-grade changes in cervical cells (Option A).   16- Most common   18- Most specific   Integration of viral DNA within the E1/E2 open reading frame disrupts the E2 viral repressor gene, leading to increased expression of the HPV E6 and E7 oncogenes. Integration of high-risk HPV DNA is a critical step in the oncogenic process, distinguishing it from low-risk HPV infections.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with regular menstrual cycles undergoes routine Pap smear screening, which reveals a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) of the cervix. Further testing confirms infection with high-risk HPV type 16. Which of the following mechanisms regarding the oncogenic activity of E6 and E7 of HPV is correct?

options.A: E6 protein inhibits the degradation of p53.
options.B: E6 stimulates the expression of TERT.
options.D: E7 can inactivate cyclins A and E

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) E6 stimulates the expression of TERT. Explanation: E6 and E7 proteins from high-risk HPV types exhibit increased affinity for key cellular regulatory proteins (e.g., p53, RB) compared to low-risk HPV types. This enhanced affinity allows high-risk HPV-infected cells to evade tumour suppressor mechanisms, dysregulate cell cycle control, and promote oncogenic transformation. Oncogenic Activities of E6 Protein Oncogenic Activities of E7 Protein Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 → Impairs cell growth and apoptosis regulation (Option A). Stimulates expression of TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) → Facilitates cellular immortalisation by maintaining telomere length.Disrupts interaction between RB protein and E2F transcription factors Inactivates CDK inhibitors (e.g., p21 and p27) (Option C). Activates cyclins A and E (Option D) All these mechanisms enhance cell cycle progression and cellular proliferation in HPV infections.

questions.question: A 10-year-old girl presents with rapidly growing jaw swelling and pain. Further examination reveals bilateral enlargement of the mandible and maxilla. Biopsy suggests the presence of a starry-sky appearance as shown in the image. Which of the following infectious agents is most commonly associated with the pathogenesis of this malignancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) EBV Explanation:   The ‘starry sky pattern’ of histopathology represents scattered macrophages with phagocytosed cell debris among proliferating lymphoma cells is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma. Burkitt Lymphoma:   Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma.   It is most commonly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, which is endemic in central Africa and New Guinea, where it is the most common childhood tumour.   EBV, a DNA oncogenic virus, infects epithelial cells of the oropharynx and B-cells via the CD21 molecule on their surface. Its LMP-1 (latent membrane protein-1) gene activates NF- κβ and JAK/STAT pathways, promoting B-cell survival and proliferation, increasing the risk of B-cell lymphoma.   Another EBV gene, EBNA-2, transactivates host genes like cyclin D and src family genes.   EBV's genome contains viral IL-10, suppressing T-cell activation by macrophages and monocytes, crucial for EBV-induced B-cell transformation.   EBV acts as a polyclonal B-cell mitogen, leading to t(8;14) translocation and Burkitt’s lymphoma.   EBV-related cancers include: Hodgkin’s lymphoma (predominantly mixed cellularity type) Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) Post-transplant lymphoma Burkitt’s lymphoma Nasopharyngeal carcinoma Gastric carcinoma Leiomyosarcoma   Hodgkin’s lymphoma (predominantly mixed cellularity type)   Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL)   Post-transplant lymphoma   Burkitt’s lymphoma   Nasopharyngeal carcinoma   Gastric carcinoma   Leiomyosarcoma   Hodgkin’s lymphoma (predominantly mixed cellularity type)   Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL)   Post-transplant lymphoma   Burkitt’s lymphoma   Nasopharyngeal carcinoma   Gastric carcinoma   Leiomyosarcoma HTLV-1 ( Human T-Cell Leukemia Virus Type 1 ) (Option B)   HTLV-1, a human retrovirus, causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL)   HTLV-1 contains genes such as tax and HBZ, potentially contributing to cancer   HTLV-1 may also cause Tropical spastic paraparesis, a demyelinating disorder.   Atypical lymphocytes with clover leaf nuclei are seen in peripheral blood smear. HHV-8 (Human Herpes virus) (Option C):   HHV-8, also known as Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV), is closely associated with Kaposi sarcoma, primarily in immunocompromised individuals.   In AIDS-related Kaposi sarcoma, HHV-8 pathogenesis is exacerbated by HIV, facilitating its dissemination and increasing the risk of tumours.   HHV-8 is also linked to primary effusion lymphoma and multicentric Castleman disease (Both are B-cell disorders). Aspergillus flavus (Option D):   Aspergillus flavus is a fungus known to produce aflatoxins, which are carcinogenic compounds associated with hepatocellular carcinoma.   Aflatoxin B1, produced by Aspergillus moulds on stored grains and nuts, causes a specific mutation (G:C →T: A transversion) at codon 249 in P53, leading to hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Gastric lymphomas associated with H. pylori infection are primarily of B-cell origin. Explanation:   H. pylori, the first bacterium classified as a carcinogen, is associated with gastric adenocarcinomas and lymphomas, including MALT lymphomas of B-cell origin.   Gastric adenocarcinomas arise due to increased epithelial cell proliferation in chronic inflammation caused by H. pylori infection.   Pathogenicity genes like CagA (cytotoxin-associated A) trigger uncontrolled growth factor pathways. (Option B)   H. pylori produces a bacterial toxin VacA, inducing apoptosis in gastric epithelial cells and influencing cancer development. (Option C)   Chronic H. pylori infection leads to polyclonal B-cell proliferation triggered by H. pylori-reactive T cells, which contribute to the development of MALT lymphomas.   Antibiotic therapy can eradicate H. pylori and "cure" MALT lymphomas by removing the antigenic stimulus for T cells . But, MALT lymphomas associated with t(11;18) translocation are resistant to anti-H.Pylori therapy. (Option D)

questions.question: Which of the following is used in immunohistochemical (IHC) staining as a chromogen to diagnose tumours of unknown origin?
questions.solution: Correct answer: 1) Diaminobenzidine Explanation: 3,3′ Diaminobenzidine(DAB) is a chromogen used in histochemical and IHC staining. It is oxidised and converted to an insoluble polymer, precipitating as a dark brown pigment, which allows visualisation of the target molecule. Congo red can stain amyloid fibres in red and orange. It can identify cardiac fibrosis, pulmonary fibrosis, and chronic kidney disease (Option 3). Mucicarmine stains mucin, a secretion produced in epithelial and connective tissue and capsule of Cryptococcus (Option 4).

questions.question: What needle size is typically employed for Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) procedures?
questions.solution: Correct answer: 3 ) 25-gauge needle Explanation: The appropriate needle size commonly used for FNAC procedures is the 25-27-gauge needle. This ensures effective sample retrieval while minimising patient discomfort and mitigating tissue trauma. FNAC:   FNAC is a minimally invasive technique for procuring cells from suspicious lesions or masses for cytological examination. It utilises a slender needle gauge to extract cells from the target site.   In the FNAC procedure, the lesion of interest is first identified via imaging modalities such as ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI. A needle is then inserted into the lesion, and gentle suction is applied to draw cells into a syringe.   Multiple passes may be made to ensure a sufficient sample volume. The material is either smeared onto glass slides or preserved in a fixative solution for subsequent cytological analysis.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male was diagnosed with a lung malignancy two months ago. He now came with complaints of malaise, abdominal pain, bone pain, lethargy, and confusion. The intern suspects a condition related to lung cancer and decides to send a blood test. Which of the following would be the appropriate test?
questions.solution: Correct answer: 3) Parathyroid hormone-related protein Explanation: The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of paraneoplastic syndrome of hypercalcemia associated with lung cancer. The appropriate test to diagnose this is parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHRP). Paraneoplastic syndrome: The paraneoplastic syndrome refers to signs and symptoms that cannot be explained by the tumour's anatomic distribution or hormones indigenous to the tumour tissue.   These occur in about 10% of patients with cancer   It may be the earliest manifestation of an occult neoplasm.   It may mimic metastatic disease and confound treatment. PTHRP leads to hypercalcemia, which can present as   Nausea, vomiting,   Abdominal pain( groans) ,   Bone pain( bones) ,   Renal stones( stones) ,   Fatigue malaise (moans) ,   Polyuria, polydipsia,   Constipation( thrones) ,   Lethargy, confusion, depression,   Memory loss ( psychic overtones ). PTHRP is also associated with Erythropoietin levels can be checked in polycythemia, which associated with renal carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioma, and hepatocellular carcinoma ( Option 1). Adrenocorticotrophic hormone(ACTH) levels can be checked in Cushing’s syndrome which is associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung, pancreatic carcinoma, and neural tumours ( Option 2). Antidiuretic hormone levels can be checked in Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion(SIADH) which is associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung and intracranial neoplasms ( Option 4).

questions.question: A 9-year-old child presents with multiple freckle-like dark spots on sun-exposed areas such as the face and arms. The child complains of discomfort and pain upon exposure to sunlight, and there is evidence of sunburn even after brief periods outdoors. Upon further questioning, they reveal a family history of skin cancer in relatives who also experienced similar skin issues from a young age. What is the most likely diagnosis and the genetic defect in this condition?
questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: 3) Xeroderma pigmentosum, nucleotide excision repair EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum, caused due to defective DNA nucleotide excision repair (Option 1). Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP):   It is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by sun sensitivity, with approximately 50% of patients having acute burning on minimal sun exposure.   UV radiation causes the cross-linking of pyrimidine residues , preventing normal DNA replication. Nucleotide excision repair (NER) prevents this DNA damage.   Inherited loss-of-function mutations in any of these genes give rise to xeroderma pigmentosum.   The onset of freckling (lentigines) on sun-exposed skin before age two years in most patients.   At an early age, there is a significantly increased risk of sunlight-induced cutaneous neoplasms (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma) . Cockyane syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterised by a defect in nucleotide excision repair . But unlike XP, there is no increased incidence of neoplasia ( Option 2). Bloom syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss-of-function mutations in a helicase required for homologous recombination repair (Option 4).

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true regarding Lynch syndrome?

options.A: It is autosomal recessive in inheritance.
options.B: It is also known as hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.
options.C: It is caused by mutations in genes involved in nonhomologous end-joining repair.
options.D: Amsterdam II criteria are used for diagnosis.

questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: D) Amsterdam II criteria are used for diagnosis. EXPLANATION: Amsterdam II criteria are used for the diagnosis of Lynch syndrome (Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer). (Option B)   Three or more relatives with Lynch syndrome-associated cancers (colorectal, endometrial, ovarian, stomach, small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis cancer).   At least one affected relative is a first-degree relative of the others.   Two successive generations are affected.   One or more relatives are diagnosed with Lynch syndrome-associated cancer before age 50.   FAP excluded. Lynch syndrome (Hereditary polyposis non-colorectal cancer):   It is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with carcinomas that arise predominantly in the cecum and proximal colon. (Option A)   Individuals with HNPCC syndrome inherit one abnormal copy of a mismatch repair gene. (Option C)   Trouble arises when cells acquire somatic loss of- function mutations, presumably at random, in their single normal alleles.   Germline loss-of-function mutations in at least four different genes can produce HNPCC syndrome.   The most commonly affected genes are MSH2 and MLH1 , each accounting for approximately 30% of HNPCC syndrome.   Microsatellite instability is also observed in about 15% of sporadic colon cancers and less frequently in many other cancer types.   In sporadic cancers, defects in mismatch repair usually stem from epigenetic silencing of the MLH1 gene rather than somatic mutations. Lynch syndrome is the only autosomal dominant defective DNA repair disease (all other defective DNA repair diseases are autosomal recessive in inheritance).

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the Warburg effect?

options.A: Cancer cells primarily rely on oxidative phosphorylation for ATP production.
options.B: It involves a shift from glycolysis to oxidative phosphorylation in cancer cells.
options.C: Cancer cells exhibit increased glucose uptake and preferentially metabolise glucose via
options.D: It is characterised by decreased glucose uptake and utilisation by cancer cells.

questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: C) Cancer cells exhibit increased glucose uptake and preferentially metabolise glucose via glycolysis, even in the presence of oxygen. EXPLANATION: A unique metabolic characteristic seen in cancer cells is the Warburg effect. Warburg effect:   Even in the presence of ample oxygen, cancer cells demonstrate a distinctive form of cellular metabolism characterised by high glucose uptake levels and increased glucose conversion to lactose (fermentation) via glycolysis (Option D)   Otto Warburg was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1931 for this theory.   Even though ATP production is low with lactate formation compared to mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation, it provides metabolic intermediates needed for synthesising cellular components.   Warburg effect is the basis of positive emission tomography (PET). Patients are injected with 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) , a non-metabolizable glucose derivative preferentially taken up into tumour cells (due to glucose hunger), which can be detected by PET scan. It involves a shift from glycolysis to oxidative phosphorylation in cancer cells (Option B), which is incorrect because the Warburg effect involves the opposite: a shift toward glycolysis. It is characterized by decreased glucose uptake and utilization by cancer cells (Option D) is inaccurate, as cancer cells actually increase glucose uptake and metabolism via glycolysis.

questions.question: Which of the following mechanisms is not employed by tumour cells to evade the host immune system?

options.A: Selective outgrowth of the antigen-negative variants
options.D: Enhanced antigen presentation to promote T cell activation

questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: D) Enhanced antigen presentation to promote T cell activation EXPLANATION: Enhanced antigen presentation is not a mechanism tumour cells employ to evade the host immune system.   Antigen presentation is a crucial step in activating T cells and initiating an immune response against tumour cells.   Antigen-presenting cells, such as dendritic cells, present tumor antigens to T cells via major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules, leading to T cell activation and anti-tumour immune responses.   While tumour cells may downregulate or alter the expression of MHC molecules to evade immune recognition, enhancing antigen presentation to promote T-cell activation is not a typical strategy employed by tumour cells for immune evasion. Mechanisms by which tumour cells evade the host immune system:   Selective outgrowth of the antigen-negative variants (Option A).   Reduced expression of MHC molecules (Option B).   Secretion of immunosuppressive factors (Option C).   Engagement of pathways that inhibit T-cell activation. Immune checkpoint inhibitors have been developed that inhibit CTLA-4, PD-1, and PD-L1. questions.question: Which of the following features does not distinguish between necrosis and apoptosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Association with underlying pathology :   Underlying pathological condition is not an important feature of differentiation between necrosis and apoptosis as necrosis and apoptosis both can be triggered by an underlying disease/ pathological condition. Incorrect Options: Option A - Enzymatic degradation: In necrosis, cellular contents leak out and undergo enzymatic digestion, while in apoptosis, they're enclosed until released as apoptotic bodies, with the membrane intact until engulfed by phagocytic cells. Option C - Lipid change: In apoptosis, inflammation is rare, while in necrosis, it's common due to released cellular contents triggering inflammation. Option D - Intact membrane: In apoptosis, the cell membrane remains intact, whereas in necrosis, it is disrupted.

questions.question: Which of the following shows breast necrosis and calcification?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Comedo subtype of DCIS:   The comedo subtype of DCIS is characterized by high-grade tumor cells with central necrosis.   The necrotic cells often calcify, leading to the presence of calcifications detectable on mammography. Incorrect Options: Option B - Cribriform subtype of DCIS: The cribriform subtype of DCIS features cells that form gland-like structures or "cribriform" patterns within the ducts. Option C - Colloid carcinoma:   Colloid carcinoma is characterized by the production of large amounts of extracellular mucin.   It typically appears as a gelatinous mass. Option D - Lobular carcinoma in situ: Lobular carcinoma in situ involves the proliferation of small, uniform cells that fill the lobules of the breast.

questions.question: p53 regulates which phase of cell cycle?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - G1S:   p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a crucial role in preventing the proliferation of cells with damaged DNA.   It acts as a transcription factor that can induce the expression of genes involved in cell cycle arrest, DNA repair, and apoptosis.   The G1S checkpoint is a critical control point where the cell assesses whether it is ready to enter the S phase.   If DNA damage is detected, p53 can induce the expression of p21, a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor.   p21 binds to and inhibits the activity of the cyclin-CDK complexes, thereby preventing the cell from progressing from G1 to S phase. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Option C - G2M: Although p53 can influence the G2M checkpoint indirectly by allowing repair of DNA before mitosis, its primary role remains at the G1S transition.

questions.solution: Correct Option C - 1, 2 and 3: The tumour markers positive for seminoma are:   LDH   PLAP   CD117   D240   OCT3⁄4   SALL4   NANOG Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Oil Red O stain is used in which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Frozen Section:   Oil Red O stain is commonly used in frozen sections to detect the presence of lipids, particularly neutral lipids such as triglycerides.   Frozen sections are typically used for rapid intraoperative diagnosis or for research purposes.   Oil Red O is a lipophilic dye that selectively stains lipids within cells or tissues.   It binds to the neutral lipid droplets and produces a bright red color when examined under a microscope.   This stain is particularly useful in identifying lipid accumulation in various tissues and organs, including adipose tissue, liver, muscle, and atherosclerotic plaques. Incorrect Options: Option A - Formalin fixation:   Formalin fixation refers to the preservation of tissue samples using formaldehyde solutions.   Formalin fixation leads to the cross-linking of proteins and modification of lipid structures, which may interfere with the staining properties of Oil Red O. Option C - Alcohol fixation:   Alcohol fixation involves the preservation of tissues using alcohol-based solutions, such as ethanol or methanol.   Alcohol fixation can also alter the structure of lipids, affecting the staining properties of Oil Red O. Option D - Gluteraldehyde fixation:   Gluteraldehyde fixation is typically used for electron microscopy studies.   Gluteraldehyde fixation may lead to changes in lipid composition and affect the staining properties of Oil Red O.

questions.question: A 5-year-old child presents with a lesion in the right eye. Histopathology reveals the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Retinoblastoma:   Retinoblastoma is the most common ocular neoplasm in children.   The usual age for clinical presentation in non-familial cases is 1 year, and the usual clinical appearance is leukocoria.   Histopathologically, retinoblastoma is composed of small blue cells intermingled with anastomosing pools of pink necrosis.   More differentiated retinoblastomas often exhibit Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for CML?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - FISH:   Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is the investigation of choice for detecting the Philadelphia chromosome in CML.   FISH involves using fluorescently labeled DNA probes that specifically bind to the chromosomal regions involved in the translocation, allowing for the visualization of the abnormal chromosome 22 with the BCR-ABL fusion gene. Incorrect Options: Option A - LAP score:   In CML, LAP score is typically low due to decreased activity of leukocyte alkaline phosphatase.   While the LAP score can provide useful diagnostic information, it is not the primary investigation used to detect the Philadelphia chromosome or confirm the diagnosis of CML. Option C - Karyotyping: While karyotyping can detect chromosomal abnormalities, including the Philadelphia chromosome in CML, it is not as sensitive as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) for detecting specific translocations like t(9;22)(q34;q11). Option D - Reciprocal translocation: This option names the translocation that is involved in the formation of the philadelphia chromosome.

questions.question: A farmer has a lesion on the shoulder. What is the most likely diagnosis as per the histopathological image of the lesion given below?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - SCC: The histopathological image showing keratin pearls on histopathology is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Incorrect Options: Option B - BCC: The histopathological image of basal cell carcinoma shows a skin biopsy with nests of basaloid cells with peripheral palisading and a characteristic stromal retraction artifact. Option C - Molluscum contagiosum: The histopathological image of Molluscum contagiosum shows a classical cup shape, and these cups are filled with pink-coloured bodies called HP (Henderson Patterson) bodies. Option D - Verrucous carcinoma:   Verrucous carcinoma is a subtype of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).   It typically occurs in areas of the body that are exposed to chronic irritation, such as the oral cavity, genitals, and feet.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a small round blue cell tumor?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Hemangioblastoma:   Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.   It is a rare, benign tumor that arises from the blood vessels in the central nervous system.   Histologically, it is characterized by abundant blood vessels and stromal cells.   It is commonly associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease, an inherited condition that predisposes individuals to the development of various tumors. Incorrect Options: Option B - Ewing's sarcoma:   Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant tumor that predominantly affects children and young adults.   It is characterized by small round blue cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.   It commonly arises in the bones, but it can also occur in soft tissues.   Ewing's sarcoma often presents with localized pain and swelling and can metastasize to other sites. Option C - Retinoblastoma:   Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor that develops in the retina of the eye.   It primarily affects children and can occur unilaterally or bilaterally.   Retinoblastoma is characterized by small round blue cells and can cause leukocoria and visual disturbances.   It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene. Option D - Neuroblastoma:   Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumor that arises from primitive nerve cells, typically in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic nervous system.   It is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children.   Neuroblastoma is composed of small round blue cells and can present with various signs and symptoms, including abdominal mass, bone pain, and neurologic changes.

questions.question: A 3-year-old boy was brought by his parents with concerns about being increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On examination, there is leukocoria with an absence of the red reflex in the left eye. As further workup reveals a tumor, the eye is enucleated, and the microscopic appearance is as shown in the image. Molecular analysis of the tumor indicates a loss of cell cycle control in the tumor cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Retinoblastoma:   Retinoblastoma is the most common ocular neoplasm in children.   The usual age for clinical presentation in non-familial cases is 1 year, and the usual clinical appearance is leukocoria.   Histopathologically, retinoblastoma is composed of small blue cells intermingled with anastomosing pools of pink necrosis.   More differentiated retinoblastomas often exhibit Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Incorrect Options: Option A - Wilms tumor:   Wilms tumor is a pediatric renal tumor. Option C - Ependymoma:   Ependymoma arises in the fourth ventricle and spinal cord.   Patients often present with symptoms of hydrocephalus, including nausea, vomiting, and headaches. questions.question: How would you distinguish between a thymoma and ALL when presented with a mediastinal mass?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Cytokeratin:   Cytokeratins are intermediate filaments found in epithelial cells.   Thymomas are tumors of thymic epithelial cells and express cytokeratin markers.   ALL is a lymphoid malignancy and does not express cytokeratins. Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.question: NARP syndrome belongs to:
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Mitochondrial function disorder:   NARP syndrome is caused by mutations in the mitochondrial DNA, specifically in the ATPase 6 gene.   Mitochondrial function disorders involve defects in the mitochondria, which are responsible for producing energy in the form of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: The mutations / changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except:
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Enhancer deletion:   Enhancer deletion is not a mechanism that directly converts a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.   Enhancers are regulatory DNA sequences that enhance the transcription of genes.   While enhancer mutations can contribute to gene dysregulation, they do not directly convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene. Incorrect Options: Option A - Promoter insertion:   Promoter insertion is a genetic alteration that can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.   When a promoter sequence is inserted near a proto-oncogene, it can lead to increased and unregulated expression of the gene, promoting cell growth and division. Option C - Gene amplification:   Gene amplification refers to an increase in the number of copies of a specific gene.   If a proto-oncogene undergoes amplification, it results in an increased dosage of the gene product, leading to abnormal cell proliferation and potentially converting it to an oncogene. Option D - Point mutation:   Point mutations, which are single nucleotide changes in the DNA sequence, can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.   Point mutations can result in altered protein function, increased protein stability, or constitutive activation of signalling pathways, promoting uncontrolled cell growth and division.

questions.question: Why do neoplastic cells utilise Warburg metabolism?

options.A: It decreases glucose utilisation by neoplastic cells
options.B: It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication
options.C: It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production
options.D: In prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer immortal

questions.solution: Correct Option B - It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication:   Neoplastic cells utilise a metabolic pathway known as the Warburg effect, which involves the conversion of glucose to lactate even in the presence of sufficient oxygen, resulting in lower ATP production than in normal cells.   This phenomenon is also known as aerobic glycolysis.   Neoplastic cells use this pathway as it generates metabolic intermediates such as pyruvate and lactate, which are required for the biosynthesis of nucleotides, amino acids, and lipids, which are essential for cell growth and division. Incorrect Options: Option A - It decreases glucose utilisation by neoplastic cells:   Warburg metabolism increases glucose utilisation by neoplastic cells. Option C - It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production:   Warburg metabolism produces less ATP than oxidative phosphorylation. Option D - In prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer immortal:   Warburg metabolism is not the direct cause of preventing apoptosis.   While altered metabolism in cancer cells can contribute to their survival and resistance to apoptosis, there are other factors involved in these processes, including genetic mutations, dysregulation of signalling pathways, and interactions with the tumor microenvironment.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about anaplasia?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Loss of differentiation:   Anaplasia refers to the loss of differentiation of cells.   It is a characteristic feature of malignant tumors and is associated with the loss of normal tissue organization and cellular features.   Anaplastic cells often exhibit pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and increased mitotic activity. Incorrect Options: Option A - Loss of cohesion between cells: Loss of cohesion between cells is a characteristic feature of malignancy. Option C - Change of epithelium type: Metaplasia refers to the reversible change of one mature cell type to another mature cell type in response to certain stimuli or chronic irritation. Option D - Benign and fully reversible: Anaplasia is typically seen in malignant tumors and is not fully reversible.

questions.question: Which of the following proto-oncogenes is not implicated in carcinoma of the thyroid??
questions.solution: Correct Option D - p53:   p53 is not implicated in carcinoma of the thyroid. Incorrect Options: Option A - RAS: Mutations in the RAS proto-oncogene, particularly the HRAS and KRAS isoforms, are found in thyroid cancer. Option B - RET: Mutations in RET are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) syndromes, which include medullary thyroid carcinoma. Option C - BRAF: Mutations in the BRAF proto-oncogene, particularly the V600E mutation, are found in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.question: Which of the following does not fall under the provisional entity in the WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumours?

options.A: Natural Killer cell lymphoblastic leukemia / lymphoma
options.C: Acute myeloid leukemia with RUNX1 mutation

questions.solution: Correct Option D - Splenic B-cell lymphoma / leukemia:   In the WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumors, provisional entity refers to a category that includes certain rare or less well-characterized entities where further research and clinical experience are needed to determine their precise classification and clinical significance.   This is not included as a provisional entity. It has its own classification within the WHO classification of lymphoid neoplasms. Incorrect Options:   Option A, B, and C are included as a provisional entity in the WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumors.

questions.question: Which of the following components is typically not included in immunohistochemistry for acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Cytokeratin:   Cytokeratins are a group of proteins that are primarily found in epithelial cells, which line the surfaces and cavities of the body.   They are not specific markers for lymphoid cells and are not typically used in the diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Incorrect Options: Option A - TdT:   Tdt is an enzyme that is typically present in the early stages of lymphoid cell development.   It is not found in mature lymphocytes but is expressed in lymphoblasts, which are the immature precursor cells in ALL.   Tdt is commonly used as a marker to identify and confirm the presence of lymphoblasts in ALL.   Tdt-positive staining indicates the presence of immature lymphoid cells, which is a characteristic feature of ALL. Option B - CD1a:   CD1a is a cell surface marker that is predominantly expressed on Langerhans cells, which are specialized immune cells found in the skin and mucosal tissues.   In the context of immunohistochemistry for ALL, CD1a is used to differentiate T-cell ALL (which is CD1a-positive) from B-cell ALL (which is CD1a-negative). Option C - CD3:   CD3 is a complex of proteins that is present on the surface of mature T lymphocytes.   In the context of immunohistochemistry for ALL, CD3 is used to detect T-cell ALL, as the malignant cells in this subtype express CD3 on their surface.   CD3-positive staining helps confirm the T-cell lineage of the leukemia cells.

questions.question: Anaplasia refers to:

options.B: Variation in cell size and shape
options.C: Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.solution: Correct Option A - Lack of differentiation:   Anaplasia is characterized by the loss of normal cellular differentiation, i.e., the tumor cells do not resemble the parent tissue cells they originated from. Incorrect Options: Option B - Variation in cell size and shape: Pleomorphism refers to the presence of cells with different sizes and shapes within a tumor. Option C - Replacement of one type of cell by another: Metaplasia refers to the reversible change of one mature cell type to another mature cell type in response to certain stimuli or chronic irritation. Option D - Disordered arrangement of tumor cells: The disordered arrangement of tumor cells is known as architectural disorder or loss of normal tissue architecture, which is often observed in malignant tumors.

questions.question: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the immortality of cancer cells?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Telomerase:   Telomerase is an enzyme that is responsible for maintaining the length of telomeres, which are protective structures at the ends of chromosomes.   Telomeres shorten with each cell division, and their shortening is associated with cellular aging and eventual cell death.   However, telomerase can extend the length of telomeres, allowing cells to divide indefinitely.   In cancer cells, telomerase is often overexpressed, leading to continuous cell division and immortality. Incorrect Options: Option B - Topoisomerase:   Topoisomerases are responsible for manipulating the structure of DNA by inducing and resolving DNA strand breaks. Option C - Helicase:   Helicases unwind the DNA double helix, allowing other enzymes to access and replicate the DNA. Option D - RNA polymerase:   RNA polymerase is an enzyme responsible for synthesizing RNA from a DNA template during transcription.   It is essential for gene expression and protein synthesis.   While dysregulation of RNA polymerase activity can occur in cancer, it is not directly associated with the immortality of cancer cells.

questions.question: The human papillomavirus inactivates the Rb gene by which of the following proteins?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - E7:   The human papillomavirus (HPV) inactivates the retinoblastoma (RB) gene primarily through the action of the E7 protein.   The E7 protein of high-risk HPV types, such as HPV-16 and HPV-18, is crucial in promoting cell cycle progression and inhibiting cell cycle checkpoints.   E7 interacts with the p105Rb (retinoblastoma protein), encoded by the Rb gene, leading to its inactivation.   By binding to p105RB, E7 disrupts the normal interaction between p105RB and E2F, a transcription factor involved in cell cycle control.   This disruption results in the release of E2F, allowing it to activate genes required for cell cycle progression, including genes involved in DNA replication.   Consequently, the cell cycle becomes dysregulated, and uncontrolled cell proliferation can occur, a hallmark of HPV-associated cancers. Incorrect Options: Option A - E6: The E6 protein of HPV primarily targets and degrades the tumor suppressor protein p53, rather than inactivating the RB gene. Option C - L1: The L1 protein is the major capsid protein of HPV and plays a role in the virus particle assembly. Option D - L2: The L2 protein is a capsid protein of HPV, which assists in entering the viral DNA into the host cell during infection.

questions.question: A boy presents with a fever, night sweats, and neck swelling. The biopsy of the swelling showed a starry sky appearance. What is the most likely genetic abnormality seen in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - MYC:   The presence of a starry sky appearance on biopsy suggests Burkitt lymphoma.   The starry sky appearance in the biopsy is due to the presence of macrophages that have engulfed apoptotic tumor cells, creating a pattern reminiscent of stars in the night sky.   Burkitt lymphoma is characterized by the translocation of the MYC gene.   The MYC gene is located on chromosome 8 and encodes a transcription factor involved in the regulation of cell growth and proliferation.   In Burkitt lymphoma, there is a characteristic translocation involving the MYC gene, most commonly the t(8;14)(q24;q32) translocation.   This translocation juxtaposes the MYC gene with the enhancer region of the immunoglobulin heavy chain gene (IgH), resulting in dysregulated MYC expression.   The dysregulated MYC expression leads to uncontrolled cell growth and division, contributing to the development of Burkitt lymphoma. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: A 7-year-old child presents with fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain. An X-ray of the skull shows multiple lytic lesions. A skin biopsy shows prominent nuclear grooves with eosinophils, as shown in the image below. Immunohistochemistry for S100 and CD1a is also shown in the images below. What would be the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Langerhans cell histiocytosis:   The clinical presentation of fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain in a 7-year-old child with multiple lytic lesions on X-ray and skin biopsy showing prominent nuclear grooves and eosinophils and immunohistochemistry for S100 and CD1a suggests Langerhans cell histiocytosis.   Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare disorder characterized by the accumulation and proliferation of Langerhans cells, a type of dendritic cell.   The disease can affect any age group but is most commonly seen in children between the ages of 1 and 15 years.   The most common sites of involvement are bone, skin, lymph nodes, and lungs. Incorrect Options: Option A - Rosai-Dorfman disease:   Rosai-Dorfman disease is a rare disorder characterized by the overproduction of non-Langerhans histiocytes.   The disease most commonly affects lymph nodes.   The clinical presentation of Rosai-Dorfman disease includes painless lymphadenopathy, fever, and night sweats. Option B - Kimura disease:   Kimura disease is a rare inflammatory disorder that affects the lymph nodes and soft tissues of the head and neck.   The disease is most commonly seen in young Asian males.   The clinical presentation of Kimura disease includes painless swelling of the lymph nodes and soft tissues, along with elevated levels of eosinophils in the blood. Option D - Juvenile xanthogranuloma:   Juvenile xanthogranuloma is a rare disorder characterized by the overproduction of histiocytes.   The disease most commonly affects children under the age of 5.   The clinical presentation of juvenile xanthogranuloma includes firm, dome-shaped papules or nodules on the skin.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of innate immunity?

options.B: Made of epithelial barriers, phagocytes, innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) and NK cells
options.D: Has a lag phase between exposure and response

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Has a lag phase between exposure and response. Explanation: The lag phase between exposure and response is not a feature of innate immunity as it acts rapidly against pathogens.   The lag phase is a feature of adaptive immunity. It specifically targets the pathogen causing infection, so it first needs to recognize the pathogen. This means that it’s slower to respond than the innate immune system, but it’s more accurate when it does respond.   Because of immunological memory, the next time it faces the same pathogen, there is a quick and robust response.   Innate immunity is the body's first line of defense against pathogens, present since birth. It responds similarly to all germs and foreign substances, hence the term non-specific immune system. questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes. He is diagnosed with a viral infection. Which of the following cells is most likely involved in the early defense against the offending agent in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) NK cells Explanation: In this scenario, the patient has a viral infection, and the body's initial defense mechanism against the virus is Natural Killer (NK) cells. Natural Killer cell (NK) :   Produced by a large granular lymphocyte.   Constitutes 5 to 10% of circulating blood lymphocytes.   Function: It can be part of both innate and adaptive immunity. Innate immunity: Directly kill the virus-infected cells or tumour cells. Adaptive immunity: Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity.   It can be part of both innate and adaptive immunity.   Innate immunity:   Directly kill the virus-infected cells or tumour cells.   Adaptive immunity:   Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity.   Popular markers for NK cells: CD 16 and CD 56.   CD 56: The role is still not fully understood.   CD 16: Detect and bind to Fc fragment of IgG on target cells and kill the cell by perforins and by releasing toxins and granzymes.   Nk cells have 2 different kinds of receptors. Activating receptors: NKG2D. Inhibitory receptors: CD94, CD 96 (these prevent self-cells from being attacked by NK cells).   Activating receptors: NKG2D.   Inhibitory receptors: CD94, CD 96 (these prevent self-cells from being attacked by NK cells). T cells ( Option B) are important in the adaptive immune response against viruses, they are not typically involved in the body's immediate defense mechanism during the early stages of infection. Macrophages and Histiocytes (Option C & D) are part of the innate immune system and play a role in the immune response to viral infections. However, NK cells are more directly involved in the early defence against viruses due to their ability to recognize and kill virus-infected cells without prior sensitization.

questions.question: A 20-year-old medical student went for a screening health test and was injected with PPD intradermally. Identify the immune cell in the skin that picks up the PPD to present it to T cells.
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Langerhans cells Explanation: The given clinical scenario describes the Mantoux test. Langerhans cells are specialized dendritic cells found in the skin and mucosa. They are responsible for antigen presentation in the immune system. They are part of the body's first line of defense and belong to the innate immune system. Dendritic cells(DC) are the most potent antigen-presenting cells(APC) for initiating T-cell responses against protein antigens. Type s of APC sDescription Profe ssion al AP CsThese are further divided into Dendritic cells B cells Macrophages These dendritic cells are present in two regions Skin: They are called as Langerhans cells Lymph node: Follicular dendritic cells (reservoirs for HIV) (Langhans cells are not antigen-presenting cells, these are the giant cells generally found in TB). Non- profe ssion al AP CsIt includes Thymic epithelial cells Endothelial cells Fibroblasts Dendritic cell properties:   They have many cytoplasmic processes resembling dendrites and receptors that sense microbes and cell damage that stimulate the secretion of cytokines. This has a critical role in inflammation and antiviral defense.   They express receptors for capturing antigens, including TLRs and lectins.   They are located under the epithelia and interstitia of all tissues, which are common sites for capturing antigens.   They have a higher concentration of MHCs and are present in greater numbers in the epidermis than other APCs. Immature DCs within the epidermis are called Langerhans cells. Langhans cells/Langhans giant cells (Option A) are multinucleated giant cells found in granulomas. They consist of huge cytoplasm and multiple nuclei that are derived from the fusion of multiple activated macrophages. Follicular dendritic cells (Option B) are specialized cells found in lymphoid follicles within lymph nodes and the spleen. They play a crucial role in presenting antigens to B cells and are involved in the formation and maintenance of the germinal center reaction. NK cells (Option D) are not APCs. They destroy abnormal cells, such as virus-infected or malignant cells.

questions.question: An 8-year-old child is brought with complaints of fever and burning micturition. She was diagnosed to have UTI with toxin-producing strains of E.coli. Where are blood-borne antigens trapped in the immune response to these toxins?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Spleen Explanation: In the immune response to toxin-producing strains of E. coli causing UTI, blood-borne antigens are primarily trapped and processed in the spleen.   The spleen is an important secondary lymphoid organ where circulating antigens, including those derived from bacteria and their toxins, are captured by specialized cells such as macrophages.   These antigens are then presented to immune cells, initiating an immune response to neutralize the toxins and clear the infection.   The spleen is part of the secondary lymphoid organs, including lymph nodes and mucosal/cutaneous lymphoid tissues.   They are a part of adaptive immunity.   In contrast, primary lymphoid organs like the thymus and bone marrow are involved in the development and maturation of immune cells (T and B lymphocytes). questions.question: A patient presented with a fever and loose stool for one week. He was diagnosed with typhoid infection. Which of the following MHC class is responsible for antigen presentation in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Class II Explanation: In a patient with typhoid infection (caused by Salmonella typhi), antigen presentation primarily involves MHC class II molecules, which present antigens derived from extracellular pathogens to activate an immune response. Class I MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens derived from intracellular pathogens, such as viruses and some bacteria. Class II MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens derived from extracellular pathogens, such as Salmonella typhi, the bacterium responsible for typhoid fever. Class III MHC class III molecules are not involved in antigen presentation. They encode components of the complement system and other immune-related molecules. Non-MHC-dependent antigen presentationWhile non-MHC-dependent antigen presentation can occur through mechanisms like CD1 molecules presenting lipid antigens.   Class II MHC molecules are expressed on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs), such as dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells.   These cells process exogenous antigens derived from extracellular microbes and proteins after internalization into endosomes or lysosomes.   The internalized proteins are broken down into peptides and associated with class II MHC in the vesicles and transported to the cell surface as stable peptide-MHC complexes.   The class II-peptide complex is recognized by CD4+/helper T cells. Class II MHC molecules present antigens derived from extracellular pathogens to CD4+ helper T cells, initiating an immune response.

questions.question: Which component functions as the antigen binding site in MHC complexes 1 and 2, respectively?

options.A: MHC 1 - beta microglobulin; MCH 2 - alpha 3 domain
options.B: MHC 1 - alpha 1 and 2; MHC 2 - alpha 1 and beta 1
options.C: MHC 1 - alpha 1 and beta 1; MHC 2 - alpha 1 and 2
options.D: MHC 1 - invariant chain; MHC 2 - beta microglobulin

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) MHC 1 - alpha 1 and 2; MHC 2 - alpha 1 and beta 1 Explanation: In MHC class I molecules, the alpha 1 and beta 1 domains together form the antigen-binding site, which binds to peptides derived from intracellular proteins.   MHC-1 molecules are expressed on all nucleated cells, antigen-presenting cells, and platelets   Mature RBCs that lack a nucleus don't express MHC-1   They are heterodimers with a polymorphic α or heavy chain linked non-covalently to a smaller β2-microglobulin.   The antigen is bound within a groove between the α1 and α2 domains of the alpha chain.   This, along with the β2-microglobulin, forms a stable complex to be displayed on the cell surface. In MHC class II molecules, similar to MHC class I, the antigen-binding site is also formed by the alpha 1 and beta 1 domains, binding peptides derived from extracellular proteins presented by antigen-presenting cells.   They consist of 2 alpha and 2 beta chains of equal length.   The invariant chain is a protein structure associated with MHC-2. It is associated with MHC-2 within endosomes to prevent the binding of endogenous antigens. The invariant chain is later broken down, while MHC-2 is moved to the cell surface.

questions.question: A newborn delivered by a mother who received no prenatal care is being evaluated. On examination, the baby has severe oedema, icterus, and organomegaly and is in respiratory distress. What immunoglobulin class was responsible for this child’s presentation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) IgG Explanation: The given clinical scenario describes Hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), also known as erythroblastosis fetalis, occurs when there is an incompatibility between the blood types of a mother and her fetus.   This condition is often caused by Rh (Rhesus) blood group incompatibility, where the mother is Rh-negative and the fetus is Rh-positive. During pregnancy, maternal antibodies of the IgG class against the Rh antigen can cross the placenta and attack the fetal red blood cells (RBCs), leading to hemolysis (destruction of RBCs) in the fetus.   This results in various degrees of anaemia and potentially severe complications for the newborn.   This crossing is facilitated by active transplacental transfer mechanisms, primarily mediated by syncytiotrophoblast cells expressing neonatal Fc receptors (FcRn). These receptors interact with the Fc domain of IgG, permitting their transfer.   This phenomenon is also responsible for newborns' passive immunity, with IgG being the most abundant antibody in their circulation. IgM (Option A) are multinucleated giant cells found in granulomas. They consist of huge cytoplasm and multiple nuclei that are derived from the fusion of multiple activated macrophages. It cannot cross the placenta due to its large size (pentameric structure). IgD and IgE (Option C and D) are also incapable of crossing the placenta.

questions.question: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with swelling in his face and legs, decreased urine output, and dark-colored urine. His parents reported that he had a sore throat about three weeks ago, which resolved without treatment. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is associated with this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Type III hypersensitivity Explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a classic example of a Type III hypersensitivity reaction . PSGN is an immune complex-mediated disease caused by the deposition of circulating immune complexes (composed of streptococcal antigens and antibodies) in the kidney glomeruli, leading to inflammation and damage. Examples of type III hypersensitivity: (mnemonic- SHARP)   Serum sickness, Schick test, SLE (Hematological lesion)   Henoch Schonlein purpura   Arthus reaction   Reactive arthritis   Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN), Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)

questions.question: Which of the following is typically associated with localized immune-complex mediated hypersensitivity?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Arthus reaction Explanation: The presentation from the given clinical scenario suggests localized immune-complex mediated hypersensitivity or Type III hypersensitivity reaction.   The “Arthus reaction” is localized tissue necrosis caused by acute immune complex vasculitis, often occurring in the skin.   It occurs when pre-existing antibodies (IgG) interact with antigens locally injected into the skin or other tissues, leading to complement activation, inflammation, and tissue damage.   This reaction is typically seen in response to repeated exposure to certain antigens (e.g., vaccines) and results in a localised inflammatory response such as localised swelling, redness, pain, and tissue destruction. Systemic type III hypersensitivity Localised type III hypersensitivity Involves the widespread formation of immune complexes in circulation and can deposit in various tissues and organs throughout the body, including the kidneys (leading to glomerulonephritis), joints, skin, blood vessels, and other sites. (e.g., in chronic infections or autoimmune diseases).Immune complexes are deposited at specific sites of antigen exposure, such as the skin (as in the Arthus reaction) or joint spaces, leading to local inflammation (localized swelling, redness, pain) and tissue damage.
