questions.question: Which of the following mechanisms is not involved in the development of emphysema?

options.A: Toxic injury and inflammation leading to variable degrees of parenchymal destruction.
options.B: Protease-antiprotease imbalance with a relative deficiency of protective antiproteases.
options.C: The presence of T and B cells in affected parts of the lung indicates a robust adaptive
options.D: Oxidative stress induced by substances in tobacco smoke, alveolar damage, and

questions.solution: Correct answer: C) The presence of T and B cells in affected parts of the lung indicates a robust adaptive immune response. Explanation:   Chronic inflammation in emphysema does lead to the accumulation of T and B cells in affected parts of the lung, but the role of adaptive immunity is currently uncertain.   Therefore, it's not considered a defining feature of the disease. Pathophysiology of emphysema:   Inhaled cigarette smoke and other noxious particles cause damage to respiratory epithelium and inflammation, resulting in parenchymal destruction, which is a hallmark of emphysema.   In patients with emphysema, there is often a relative deficiency of protective antiproteases, which allows proteases released from inflammatory cells and epithelial cells to break down connective tissue components, contributing to tissue destruction.   Substances in tobacco smoke, alveolar damage, and inflammatory cells all produce oxidants, which contribute to tissue damage, endothelial dysfunction, and inflammation, further exacerbating the pathology of emphysema.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man has been a heavy smoker for the past 40 years and presents with complaints of progressive shortness of breath, especially with exertion, and a chronic cough with occasional scanty sputum production. Physical examination reveals a barrel-shaped chest, decreased breathing sounds, and a prolonged expiratory phase. Based on the clinical presentation and history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct answer: B) Emphysema Explanation:   The patient's history of heavy smoking, chronic cough with occasional scanty sputum production, progressive shortness of breath, especially with exertion and physical examination showing barrel-shaped chest, decreased breath sounds, and a prolonged expiratory phase is highly suggestive of COPD with emphysema.   Clinically significant emphysema is largely confined to smokers and patients with α 1-antitrypsin deficiency. Clinical features:   The classical presentation of emphysema involves a barrel-shaped chest and dyspnea, with obviously prolonged expiration, sitting forward in a hunched-over position, and breathing through pursed lips.   Cough is often slight, overdistention of the lungs is severe, diffusion capacity is low, and blood gas values are relatively normal at rest.   Weight loss is common and can be so severe as to suggest an occult cancer. Chronic bronchitis (Option A) presents insidiously with slowly increasing dyspnea on exertion and chronic cough with sputum production, slight at first but increasing over time.   The most important diagnostic test is spirometry, which typically shows an FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7.   The main clinically distinguishing factor between emphysema and chronic bronchitis is that chronic bronchitis is characterized by a persistent, mucus-producing cough. In contrast, the primary symptom of emphysema is shortness of breath. Bronchitis Emphysema Age (years) 40–45 50–75 Dyspnea Mild; late Severe; early Cough Early; copious sputum Late; scanty sputum Infections Common Occasional Respiratory insufficiency Early, periodic End-stage, unremitting Cor pulmonale Common Uncommon, end-stage Airway resistance Increased Normal or slightly increased Elastic recoil Normal Low Chest radiograph Prominent vessels; large heart size Hyperinflation; normal heart size Appearance Blue bloater Pink puffer Pulmonary fibrosis (Option C) is characterized by progressive scarring of the lungs, leading to decreased lung compliance and restrictive lung disease.   The chest X-ray findings of hyperinflated, hyperlucent lungs are not consistent with pulmonary fibrosis. Asthma (Option D) is characterized by reversible airflow obstruction, wheezing, and chest tightness, but the patient's history of heavy smoking and clinical presentation is not typical of asthma.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient presents with a history of chronic cough, increased sputum production, and shortness of breath. He reports that these symptoms have been present for several years and have gradually worsened over time. The patient is a lifelong smoker, having smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 20 years. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct answer: C) Chronic bronchitis Explanation:   The patient's symptoms of chronic cough, increased sputum production, and shortness of breath, combined with his history of long-term smoking, are highly suggestive of chronic bronchitis.   Chronic bronchitis is a type of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) characterized by persistent cough and mucus production.   The critical diagnostic criteria for chronic bronchitis are cough and sputum production for at least 3 months per year for two consecutive years without any other identifiable cause.   This distinguishes chronic bronchitis from acute bronchitis, which is a temporary condition.   Cause of chronic bronchitis: Smoking Air pollution Occupational exposures (dust, chemicals, fumes) Recurrent respiratory infections Indoor biomass fuel exposure Chronic exposure to environmental irritants   Smoking   Air pollution   Occupational exposures (dust, chemicals, fumes)   Recurrent respiratory infections   Indoor biomass fuel exposure   Chronic exposure to environmental irritants   Smoking   Air pollution   Occupational exposures (dust, chemicals, fumes)   Recurrent respiratory infections   Indoor biomass fuel exposure   Chronic exposure to environmental irritants Pathogenesis:   Longstanding bronchitis commonly leads to pulmonary hypertension, cor pulmonale, and death due to heart failure.   Treatment options include smoking cessation, oxygen therapy, long-acting bronchodilators with inhaled corticosteroids, antibiotics, and physical therapy. Emphysema (Option A):   Characterized by the destruction of the alveoli in the lungs, leading to airflow obstruction.   While emphysema can co-occur with chronic bronchitis, the patient's primary symptoms of chronic cough and increased sputum production indicate more chronic bronchitis. Asthma (Option B):   Characterized by intermittent symptoms that worsen with triggers rather than the persistent, progressive symptoms described in the case. Lung cancer (Option D):   Lung cancer can also present with cough and shortness of breath, but the gradual, chronic nature of the patient's symptoms makes lung cancer a less likely diagnosis compared to chronic bronchitis.

questions.question: Which of the following is not true regarding chronic bronchitis?

options.B: The most common cause is smoking
options.C: The most common cause of exacerbation is Haemophilus influenzae.
options.D: Recurrent, episodic attacks of wheezing, prolonged expiration, dyspnea (shortness of

questions.solution: Correct answer: D) Recurrent, episodic attacks of wheezing, prolonged expiration, dyspnea (shortness of breath), and chest tightness. Explanation:   Recurrent, episodic attacks of wheezing, prolonged expiration, dyspnea (shortness of breath), and chest tightness are seen in asthma.   Chronic bronchitis is defined clinically as persistent cough with sputum production for at least 3 months in at least 2 consecutive years in the absence of any other identifiable cause.   Reid's Index: RI = Thickness of submucosal gland layer / overall thickness of the wall   The Reid index (normally 0.4) is increased in chronic bronchitis (>0.4), usually in proportion to the severity and duration of the disease. Histopathology:   Chronic inflammation of the airways (predominantly lymphocytes and macrophages).   Thickening of the bronchiolar wall due to smooth muscle hypertrophy.   Deposition of extracellular matrix in the muscle layer.   Peribronchial fibrosis.   Goblet cell hyperplasia.   Enlargement of the mucus-secreting glands of the trachea and bronchi.   The most striking change is an increase in the size of the mucous glands. This increase can be assessed by the Reid index.   This increase can be assessed by the Reid index.   The primary or initiating factor in the genesis of chronic bronchitis is exposure to noxious or irritating inhaled substances such as tobacco smoke (90% of those affected are smokers, making it the commonest cause) and dust from grain, cotton, and silica. (Option B)   The most common cause of exacerbation in COPD is Haemophilus influenzae and the second most common cause is Moraxella. (Option C)   This increase can be assessed by the Reid index.

questions.question: A 32-year-old female presents with recurrent episodes of wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. On further testing, a diagnosis of asthma was made. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiological changes seen in this patient's condition?

options.C: Increase in airway inflammation and remodeling

questions.solution: Correct answer: C) Increase in airway inflammation and remodelling Explanation:   The clinical presentation of recurrent wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath suggests airway inflammation and remodelling, which are characteristic of asthma.   These changes contribute to airway hyperresponsiveness and the symptoms experienced by the patient. Pathophysiology of Asthma:   Atopic asthma, the most common form of the disease, is caused by a Th2-mediated IgE response to environmental allergens in genetically predisposed individuals. (Type 1 hypersensitivity)   Airway inflammation is central to the disease pathophysiology and causes airway dysfunction partly through the release of potent inflammatory mediators and partly through the remodelling of the airway wall.   As the disease becomes more severe, there is increased local secretion of growth factors, which induce mucous gland enlargement, smooth muscle proliferation, angiogenesis, and fibrosis. Several factors released from eosinophils (e.g., major basic protein, eosinophil cationic protein) also cause damage to the epithelium.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male has a history of recurrent wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. His sputum microscopy, shown in the image below, reveals the following finding. Which best describes this finding?

options.A: Extrusion of mucus plugs from the subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles.
options.B: Ciliated columnar cells sloughed from the bronchial mucosa.

questions.solution: Correct answer: D) They are composed of Galectin 10. Explanation:   The clinical presentation points towards a diagnosis of bronchial asthma, with sputum culture showing Charcot-Leyden crystals Charcot-Leyden crystals:   They are microscopic, needle-shaped crystals that are often found in the sputum of asthma patients, particularly during exacerbations.   They are primarily composed of galectin-10 (derived from the eosinophils) also known as Charcot-Leyden crystal protein (CLC).   Strong inducers of inflammation and mucus production.   Extrusion of mucus plugs from the subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles describes the Curschmann spirals. They are a characteristic finding in asthma. (Option A)   Ciliated columnar cells sloughed from the bronchial mucosa describe the Creola bodies seen in bronchial asthma. (Option B)   Polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within the bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and alveoli describe Masson bodies, which are seen in cryptogenic organising pneumonia. (Option C)

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. Upon further investigation, it is found that the patient has a family history of allergies and asthma. Which genetic factor is most likely co-related to the severity of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct answer: D) YKL40 gene mutation Explanation:   The YKL40 (a chitinase-like glycoprotein) gene mutation has been found to be correlated with the severity of asthma.   YKL40 levels are associated with inflammation and tissue remodelling in the airways, contributing to the progression and severity of asthma symptoms. Genetic Factors in Asthma:   A susceptibility locus for asthma located on chromosome 5q, near the gene cluster, encoding the cytokines IL-3, IL-4, IL-5, IL-9, and IL-13 and the IL-4 receptor. Polymorphisms in the IL13 gene have the strongest and most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease. questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of chronic cough with production of purulent sputum, intermittent hemoptysis, and recurrent respiratory infections over the past several years. He reports a history of childhood respiratory infections and no significant past medical history. Physical examination reveals coarse crackles and rhonchi on auscultation of the chest. Chest X-ray shows bilateral bronchial wall thickening and tram-line shadows. Which of the following is unlikely to be a cause for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct answer: B) Bronchial Asthma Explanation:   The clinical findings along with radiographic findings are suggestive of bronchiectasis and bronchial asthma is not a cause.   Bronchiectasis is the permanent dilation of the bronchi and bronchioles. Aetiology of Bronchiectasis: Congenital or hereditary conditions Cystic fibrosis Primary ciliary dyskinesia Kartagener syndrome Severe necrotising pneumonia Caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi This may be a single severe episode or recurrent infection Bronchial obstruction Tumor Foreign body Idiopathic (50% of the cases) Dysfunctional host immunity to infectious agents leads to chronic inflammation

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the pathophysiology of Kartagener's syndrome?

options.A: Mutation in the CFTR gene leading to impaired ciliary function.
options.B: Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern affecting the cilia in the respiratory tract.
options.C: The primary defect involves dynein arm proteins, leading to impaired ciliary motility.
options.D: Characterized by an excess of cilia in the respiratory epithelium.

questions.solution: Correct answer: C) The primary defect involves dynein arm proteins, leading to impaired ciliary motility. Explanation:   Kartagener’s syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that is part of the broader spectrum of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).   The primary defect lies in the dynein arm proteins; there is impaired ciliary motility.   This impairment leads to ineffective clearance of mucus, debris, and pathogens from the respiratory tract, sinuses, and other ciliated surfaces in the body.   Kartagener’s syndrome is characterised by a triad of: Bronchiectasis. Situs inversus Sinusitis.   Bronchiectasis.   Situs inversus   Sinusitis.   Infertility can be seen in males due to sperm dysmotility (Asthenospermia).   Bronchiectasis.   Situs inversus   Sinusitis. Mutation in the CFTR gene leading to impaired ciliary motility (Option A):   Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder caused by CFTR gene mutations, leading to thick mucus buildup in the lungs and digestive system. Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern affecting the cilia in the respiratory tract (Option B):   Kartagener's syndrome follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, not autosomal dominant.   Additionally, it affects the structure and function of cilia throughout the body, not just in the respiratory tract. Characterized by an excess of cilia in the respiratory epithelium (Option D):   Kartagener's syndrome is characterized by defects in ciliary structure and function, leading to impaired ciliary motility rather than an excess of cilia.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a chronic cough productive of copious sputum. He reports frequent respiratory infections over the past several years. Physical examination reveals digital clubbing and coarse crackles on auscultation. An HRCT is done and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct answer: D) Bronchiectasis Explanation: The clinical presentation of a male with chronic cough, copious sputum, past history of frequent respiratory infections, clubbing, coarse crackles on auscultation, and HRCT showing thickened and dilated bronchi (tram-track appearance) is suggestive of bronchiectasis.   Bronchiectasis is characterised by the irreversible dilation and distortion of bronchi, typically due to chronic inflammation and recurrent infections. The image below shows bronchiectasis with markedly dilated bronchi in the upper and lower lobes. Tuberculosis (Option A):   HRCT shows cavitary lesions, tree-in-bud nodules, or consolidations, not the bronchial dilation seen in bronchiectasis. Asthma (Option B):   HRCT is usually normal or may show bronchial wall thickening but not bronchial dilation. COPD (Option C):   HRCT shows emphysematous changes (air trapping, bullae) and airway narrowing but lacks the tram-track or signet ring appearance seen in bronchiectasis.

questions.question: A 52-year-old male, non-smoker, presents with progressive shortness of breath, persistent dry cough, and chest pain. A CT scan reveals a peripheral mass in the lower lobe of left lung, and a biopsy of the nodule demonstrates a glandular pattern with mucinous differentiation, as shown in the image below. Which of the following markers is least likely to be positive in this patient's lung lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Chromogranin Explanation: Markers that are generally expressed in lung adenocarcinomas:   TTF-1 (Option A)   MUC1 (Option B)   Napsin A (Option C) Chromogranin is a protein found in the secretory vesicles of neuroendocrine cells and is most commonly used as a marker for neuroendocrine tumours such as small-cell lung cancer.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an IHC marker for small-cell lung carcinoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Napsin A Explanation: NAPSIN A, MUC 1, and TTF 1 are the IHC (immunohistochemistry) markers for adenocarcinoma of the lung. IHC markers for small cell lung carcinoma are:   Synaptophysin   Chromogranin (Option B)   Bombesin   NSE (Neuron-Specific Enolase) (Option C)   CD56 (Option D)   CD57

questions.question: A 56-year-old male presents with persistent shoulder pain radiating to the ulnar aspect of the forearm and progressive weakness in his right hand. Examination reveals muscle wasting in the right hand. Imaging of the chest shows a mass at the apex of the right lung involving nearby neurovascular structures. Which syndrome is most likely associated with this presentation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Horner syndrome Explanation:   The patient's presentation and the presence of a lung apex mass involving nearby neurovascular structures suggests a Pancoast tumour (superior sulcus tumour) located at the apex of the lung, typically involving nearby neurovascular structures.   Compression or invasion of nearby nerves, including the sympathetic chain, can result in Horner syndrome, characterised by a combination of ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face and sometimes enophthalmos (sunken appearance of the eyeball). Superior vena cava syndrome (Option B):   SVC syndrome is characterised by symptoms related to compression or obstruction of the superior vena cava, typically by a tumour in the mediastinum leading to facial swelling, dilated veins, and other signs of venous congestion but not neurological manifestations. Caplan syndrome (Option C):   Caplan syndrome is the combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis (Coal workers' pneumoconiosis) with characteristic pulmonary nodules.   It is not associated with any neurological symptoms. Carcinoid syndrome (Option D):   Carcinoid syndrome is associated with symptoms such as flushing, diarrhoea, and wheezing due to the release of vasoactive substances from carcinoid tumours, and it has no association with neurological manifestations.

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman has an incidental finding of a lung mass on imaging. CT scan reveals a well-circumscribed lesion with calcifications. Biopsy revealed spindle and epithelioid cells with an eosinophilic cytoplasm, perivascular growth, and positive HMB-45 staining. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Sugar tumour (PEComa) Explanation:   The clinical scenario of a well-circumscribed lung mass with calcifications and histological features of spindle and epithelioid cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, perivascular growth pattern, and positivity for HMB-45 immunostaining is highly suggestive of a sugar tumour.   It is also known as a perivascular epithelioid cell tumour (PEComa). PEComa   It is a rare mesenchymal tumour.   It can lead to cystic, emphysema-like dilation of terminal airspaces and obstruction of lymphatic vessels.   Treatment involves surgical resection, and mTOR inhibitors are considered for un-resectable or metastatic cases. Pulmonary hamartomas (Option A):   Pulmonary hamartomas are benign lung tumours of mesenchymal and epithelial components like cartilage, fat, and fibrous tissue.   They are often discovered incidentally on imaging scans as small, well-defined, rounded opacities (coin lesions).   Microscopically, they show nodules of connective tissue with epithelial clefts, often containing cartilage and lined by ciliated or non-ciliated epithelium. Solitary fibrous tumour (Option C):   Solitary fibrous tumours are rare mesenchymal tumours of the lung and are well-circumscribed masses composed of spindle and epithelioid cells.   They typically stain positive for CD34 and STAT6, with a favourable prognosis after surgical resection. Carcinoid tumor (Option D):   Carcinoid tumours are neuroendocrine tumours typically manifest as polypoid masses in the bronchi.   Their histopathological features include the nesting of cells with uniform round nuclei, moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, and chromatin's characteristic 'salt and pepper' appearance within the nuclei.   These tumours stain positive for neuroendocrine markers like Synaptophysin and Chromogranin.

questions.question: A 45-year-old nonsmoking woman presents with a persistent cough and hemoptysis. Imaging reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right lung. Biopsy shows cells with neuroendocrine features, including round to oval nuclei, stippled chromatin, and abundant granular cytoplasm arranged in nests and trabeculae. Which cell type is most likely involved in the origin of this patient's lung tumour?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Kulchitsky cells Explanation:   The clinical scenario, along with biopsy features, suggest a Carcinoid tumour, a neuroendocrine tumour arising from Kulchitsky cells (Neuroendocrine cells) within the bronchial epithelium.   These cells produce and secrete bioactive substances such as serotonin (5-HT) and other peptides that can influence smooth muscle contraction, immune responses, and other physiological processes. Type II pneumocytes (Option A):   Type II pneumocytes are surfactant-producing cells in the alveoli and are associated with adenocarcinoma rather than carcinoid tumours. Clara cells (Option B):   Clara cells are non-ciliated cells found in the bronchioles and are not involved in the origin of bronchial carcinoid tumours.   These cells secrete proteins and lipids that maintain and protect the airway epithelium. Alveolar macrophages (Option D):   Alveolar macrophages are immune cells responsible for phagocytosis within the alveoli and are not related to the development of carcinoid tumours.

questions.question: A 50-year-old female presents with a chronic cough and recurrent episodes of wheezing. Bronchoscopy reveals a "coat button lesion" within the bronchus, as shown in the image. Biopsy of the lesion shows nesting of cells with uniform round nuclei and moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the described features?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Bronchial carcinoid tumor Explanation:   The features described in the scenario suggest bronchial carcinoid tumour, a neuroendocrine tumour of bronchial epithelium characterised by nesting of cells with uniform round nuclei, moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, and the characteristic "salt and pepper" appearance of chromatin within the nuclei.   Typical carcinoids exhibit <2 mitoses per 10 high-power fields and lack necrosis.   Atypical carcinoids may show 2-10 mitoses per 10 high-power fields and/or foci of necrosis. questions.question: A 50-year-old heavy smoker presents with a persistent cough and unintentional weight loss. Imaging shows a right lung mass with mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Biopsy reveals small, round cells with scant cytoplasm and nuclei exhibiting a salt-and-pepper chromatin pattern. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is positive for neuroendocrine markers. Which of the following features is incorrectly associated with this clinical condition?

options.A: Both glandular and squamous differentiation are seen
options.B: Encrustation of tumour cells along the blood vessels with DNA material
options.C: Presence of dense neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Both glandular and squamous differentiation are seen Explanation:   The clinical presentation and histological features described suggest small-cell lung carcinoma, a highly malignant neuroendocrine tumour with a strong relationship to cigarette smoking.   Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) primarily exhibits neuroendocrine characteristics without the glandular histological features seen in adenocarcinoma or the squamous differentiation seen in squamous cell carcinoma. Encrustation of tumour cells along the blood vessels with DNA material(Option B)   The encrustation of necrotic tumour cells along the blood vessels with DNA material causes basophilic staining of vascular walls.   It is known as the ‘Azzopardi effect’, a characteristic feature often observed in Small-cell lung carcinoma. Presence of dense neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy (Option C):   Small-cell lung carcinoma shows neuroendocrine differentiation and dense neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy. High proliferative index (Option D):   Small-cell lung carcinoma is known for its aggressive behaviour and rapid growth, both clinically and histologically.   This is reflected in a high proliferative index, with many cells in active cell cycle phases.

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents progressive shortness of breath, especially on exertion, fatigue, and ankle swelling. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure. Echocardiography shows right ventricular hypertrophy and elevated pulmonary artery pressure. Which of the following conditions can predispose her to this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) All the above Explanation:   The patient's clinical presentation with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, signs of right heart failure (elevated jugular venous pressure, right ventricular hypertrophy), and echocardiographic evidence of elevated pulmonary artery pressure suggest the presence of pulmonary hypertension.   Pulmonary hypertension results from vascular remodelling and vasoconstriction in the pulmonary arterioles, leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and elevated pulmonary arterial pressure.   Manifestations include exertional dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain, syncope, right heart failure with jugular venous distension, and peripheral oedema. Causes of Pulmonary hypertension   High altitude (Chronic hypoxia) (Option A)   Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)   Interstitial lung disease (e.g., Pulmonary fibrosis)   Left Heart Failure (e.g. Mitral stenosis, Systolic dysfunction)   Recurrent thromboembolism events (Pulmonary embolism) (Option B)   Autoimmune diseases (e.g. Systemic sclerosis) (Option C)   Congenital Heart Disease (e.g. Atrial Septal Defect; Eisenmenger Syndrome)   Obstructive Sleep apnea High altitude (Option A):   Living at high altitudes with reduced oxygen can lead to pulmonary hypertension as: Recurrent thromboembolic events (Option B):   Repeated pulmonary embolisms can obstruct blood vessels in the lungs, increasing pulmonary vascular resistance and causing pulmonary hypertension. Scleroderma (Option C):   Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis can lead to lung vessel fibrosis and narrowing, raising pulmonary vascular resistance and contributing to pulmonary hypertension.

questions.question: A 59-year-old heavy smoker presents with loss of appetite and a persistent cough for the past few months. Imaging reveals a central lung mass involving the right bronchus and mediastinal lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical staining of a lung mass biopsy is positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin. Which set of genes is most likely involved in the underlying pathology of this patient's condition? P53 RB L-myc
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) 1,2,3 Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation and positive staining for neuroendocrine markers such as Chromogranin and synaptophysin are highly suggestive of Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) originating from neuroendocrine cells.   It is a highly malignant form of lung cancer associated with smoking and is known for its aggressive behaviour and early metastasis.   The genetic landscape of SCLC typically involves the inactivation of TP53 and RB genes.   L-MYC amplification is a common feature in some SCLC cases, contributing to the tumour's rapid growth and aggressive nature.

questions.question: A 57-year-old male smoker with a persistent cough and weight loss is found to have a lung mass on imaging. The biopsy showed keratin pearls and intercellular bridges. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is highly associated with this diagnosis?

options.B: Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Hypercalcemia Explanation:   The given clinical presentation and histological findings point towards the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma, one of the major subtypes of non-small cell lung cancer,   which typically arises from the central bronchi and can cause symptoms like coughing, chest pain, and hemoptysis.   Hypercalcemia is the most common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.   SCC of the lung can produce parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP), leading to elevated calcium levels in the blood.   This condition is characterised by symptoms such as fatigue, confusion, excessive thirst and urination, and nausea. Type of Lung Carcinoma Paraneoplastic Syndrome Squamous cell carcinoma Hypercalcemia Adenocarcinoma Migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) Small cell or oat cell Carcinoma SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone secretion) Cushing's syndrome Lambert eaton syndrome Large cell carcinoma Gynaecomastia Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) (Option B):   It is more commonly associated with small cell lung cancer rather than SCC.   SIADH leads to excessive release of antidiuretic hormone, causing water retention and dilutional hyponatremia, which can result in symptoms like muscle cramps, nausea, headaches, and disorientation. Migratory thrombophlebitis (also known as Trousseau’s syndrome) (Option C):   While this can be seen in many types of cancers, it is typically more associated with adenocarcinoma rather than with SCC.   This syndrome involves the formation of blood clots that migrate within the venous system. Cushing's syndrome (Option D):   It is characterised by the ectopic production of ACTH, most frequently associated with small cell lung cancer, not SCC.   Patients may experience symptoms such as weight gain, muscle weakness, and a rounded face (moon face).

questions.question: A 67-year-old male smoker presents with a persistent cough and weight loss. Imaging reveals a lung mass in the upper lobe of the right lung. The biopsy reveals typical features, including keratin pearls, intercellular bridges, and nests of malignant squamous cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Based on this scenario, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.A: Keratin pearls are not seen in poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.
options.B: p40 is the best marker for squamous cell carcinoma.
options.C: Squamous dysplasia is a precursor lesion of squamous cell carcinoma
options.D: The squamous cell carcinoma described is likely a peripheral lung lesion.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) The squamous cell carcinoma described is likely a peripheral lung lesion. Explanation:   Squamous Cell Carcinoma is typically found in the central regions of the lungs (Not peripheral), often originating in the major bronchi near the hilum.   It can cause symptoms by obstructing airways.   Histopathologically, it is characterised by keratin pearls, intercellular bridges, and nests of malignant squamous cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Location of lung carcinomas:   Central: Squamous cell carcinoma, Small cell carcinoma and Bronchial carcinoids.   Peripheral: Adenocarcinoma and Large-cell carcinoma. Keratin pearls are not seen in poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (Option A):   Keratin pearls are a characteristic feature of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma p40 is the best marker for squamous cell carcinoma (Option B):   p40 is the most specific and best marker for squamous cell carcinoma Squamous dysplasia is a recognised precursor lesion for squamous cell carcinoma (Option C):   Squamous cell carcinomas often arise from pre-existing bronchial epithelial conditions such as squamous metaplasia or dysplasia.

questions.question: A 58-year-old male smoker presents with a persistent cough and mild shortness of breath. Chest imaging reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule. A biopsy is performed, and a histopathological examination of the lung tissue is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.D: Diffuse idiopathic pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Adenocarcinoma in situ Explanation:   The histopathological image shows a localised proliferation of dysplastic cells along pre-existing alveolar septa, indicative of adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) or bronchioloalveolar carcinoma which is a precancerous lesion of adenocarcinoma of the lung with severe cytologic atypia.   AIS is an early stage of lung cancer where abnormal glandular cells are confined to the airway lining without invasion and exhibit a “lepidic growth pattern” (or butterfly on fence pattern), spreading along intact alveolar structures without invasion.   Lesions are usually small, measuring ≤ 3 cm. Carcinoma in situ (Option A):   Carcinoma in situ involves abnormal squamous cells confined to the epithelium without invading the surrounding structures. Adenomatous hyperplasia (Option B):   Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia (AAH) is a precursor lesion of lung adenocarcinoma with mild cytologic atypia, characterised by dysplastic pneumocytes lining alveolar walls.   These lesions are typically small, ≤5 mm, and can be single or multiple.   AAH may be adjacent to invasive tumours or independently within the lung tissue and signifies an initial stage in adenocarcinoma development. Diffuse idiopathic pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia (Option D):   DIPNECH (Diffuse idiopathic pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia) is a preneoplastic condition characterised by the abnormal proliferation of neuroendocrine cells in the lungs, which can progress to develop into neuroendocrine tumours over time like small cell carcinoma and carcinoid tumours.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male smoker presents to the clinic with chronic cough and hemoptysis. He has been smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. Upon further evaluation, a biopsy reveals lung carcinoma. Which of the following statements regarding risk factors for lung carcinoma is false?

options.A: Smoking is a major risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.
options.B: Smoking has no association with adenocarcinoma of the lung.
options.C: Smoking is a significant risk factor for small-cell lung carcinoma.
options.D: Asbestosis exposure, along with smoking, multiplies the risk of lung cancer.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Smoking has no association with adenocarcinoma of the lung. Explanation:   Smoking significantly increases the risk of adenocarcinoma of the lung, although to a lesser extent than other types.   Adenocarcinoma, commonly found in non-smokers, can still occur due to tobacco smoking.   It often involves mutations in growth factor receptor pathways and is the most prevalent subtype in non-smokers. Smoking is a major risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung (Option A):   Smoking significantly increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung as it has a strong association, resulting in chromosomal deletions involving tumour suppressor loci involving 3p,9p and 17p. Smoking is a significant risk factor for small-cell lung carcinoma (Option C):   Small-cell carcinoma is almost always linked to smoking, exhibiting the highest mutation rate among lung cancers.   SCLC is almost exclusively caused by smoking and usually involves the inactivation of both TP53 and RB genes. Asbestosis exposure, along with smoking, multiplies the risk of lung cancer (Option D):   Asbestos exposure, especially when combined with smoking, significantly raises the risk of lung cancer.   Non-smokers exposed to asbestos have a five-fold higher risk, while smokers have a 55-fold increased risk compared to non-smokers.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath, cough, and fever after recent bacterial pneumonia. Physical examination shows tachypnea, hypoxia, and diffuse crackles on chest auscultation. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral opacities suggestive of pulmonary oedema. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows congested, edematous lungs with inflammation. Which histopathological finding is characteristic of the acute exudative stage in this patient's lung injury?

options.B: Formation of fibrotic thickening in the alveolar septa
options.C: Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls
options.D: Resolution of granulation tissue in the alveolar spaces

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls Explanation:   In the acute exudative stage of lung injury, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) triggered by bacterial pneumonia, lungs exhibit characteristic waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls.   These membranes comprise fibrin-rich oedema fluid mixed with remnants of necrotic epithelial cells, representing a hallmark feature of acute lung injury and ARDS. Pathological changes seen in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) Stage Features 1. Acute Exudative Stage Lungs appear heavy, firm, red, and boggy. Manifestations include congestion, interstitial and intra-alveolar oedema, inflammation, fibrin deposition, and diffuse alveolar damage. Alveolar walls are lined with “waxy hyaline membranes” composed of fibrin-rich oedema fluid mixed with remnants of necrotic epithelial cells. 2. Proliferative or Organizing StageProliferation of Type II pneumocytes. Granulation tissue forms in the alveolar walls and spaces. 3. Late Fibrotic Stage Fibrotic thickening of alveolar septa indicates persistent fibrosis and scarring that may develop in some cases of lung injury.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the pathogenesis sequence of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (NCPE) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is incorrect? Endothelial activation is the hallmark of pathogenesis. Release of cytokines by alveolar epithelial cells Macrophage activation resulting in the release of IL-8 and TNF Recruitment of lymphocytes by IL-8
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) 2 and 4 Explanation:   In ARDS, cytokines are released by endothelial cells, not alveolar epithelial cells, and IL-8 causes the recruitment of neutrophils, not lymphocytes. Pathogenesis of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (NCPE) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS):   The hallmark of pathogenesis is ‘endothelial activation’ by bacteria leads to cytokine release, promoting neutrophil adhesion to blood vessels and subsequent endothelial damage.   This process results in blood/plasma leakage into the interstitial space and alveoli, causing non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (NCPE).   Activated macrophages release IL-8 and TNF, recruiting more neutrophils into the alveoli.   They also release proteases and free radicals, which damage type 1 and type 2 pneumocytes.   This impairs gas exchange and surfactant production, contributing to lung dysfunction.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath and fatigue. On examination, she has elevated jugular venous pressure and a loud pulmonary component of the second heart sound. Echocardiography reveals right ventricular hypertrophy and dilation. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the vascular changes of this condition?

options.A: BMPR2 mutations result in endothelial and vascular smooth muscle cell apoptosis.
options.B: Classic atherosclerotic changes are commonly observed in pulmonary arteries.
options.C: Plexiform lesions are early changes of pulmonary hypertension.
options.D: Pulmonary arterioles show medial hypertrophy and intimal fibrosis, narrowing the

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Pulmonary arterioles show medial hypertrophy and intimal fibrosis, narrowing the lumens. Explanation:   The patient's clinical presentation with symptoms of right heart failure, elevated jugular venous pressure, and findings of right ventricular hypertrophy and dilation on echocardiography suggest pulmonary hypertension.   Histopathologically, pulmonary hypertension is characterised by the remodelling of pulmonary arterioles, which typically exhibit medial hypertrophy (thickening of the smooth muscle layer) and intimal fibrosis.   These changes lead to the narrowing of the vessel lumens, increased pulmonary vascular resistance, and subsequent right heart strain. BMPR2 mutations result in endothelial and vascular smooth muscle cell apoptosis. (Option A):   BMPR2 mutations are associated with familial pulmonary arterial hypertension, commonly associated with dysregulation of endothelial and vascular cellular processes involved in vascular homeostasis, including aberrant proliferation and resistance to apoptosis. Classic atherosclerotic changes are commonly observed in pulmonary arteries. (Option B):   Classic atherosclerotic changes, such as plaque formation and lipid deposition, are not typical findings in pulmonary arteries affected by pulmonary hypertension. Plexiform lesions are early changes of pulmonary hypertension. (Option C):   Plexiform lesions are characterised by tufts of capillary formations that are more specific to certain types of pulmonary hypertension, particularly in idiopathic and familial cases.   Plexiform lesions of small arteries are characteristic of advanced pulmonary hypertension rather than early changes.

options.A: It is external to the lung.

questions.question: A 29-year-old previously healthy male presents with a one-week history of progressively worsening dry cough, fever, and shortness of breath. He denies any recent travel but mentions attending a crowded social gathering a week ago. He is febrile, tachypneic, and has crackles on auscultation. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis with lymphopenia. A chest X-ray demonstrates patchy infiltrates in the lower lobes bilaterally. Which of the following features is not associated with this condition?

options.A: Inflammatory changes are confined to the pulmonary interstitium.

options.C: It is associated with malnutrition and alcoholism.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male with a long-standing history of chronic alcohol abuse presents with a one-week history of high-grade fever, productive cough with rust-coloured sputum, and right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He reports frequent binge drinking episodes and denies any recent travel or sick contacts. On examination, he appears ill, with a temperature of 39.5°C, tachypnea, and decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung fields. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis with neutrophilia and elevated inflammatory markers. What is the most likely organism implicated in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Klebsiella pneumoniae Explanation: The clinical presentation of a patient who is a known alcoholic, presenting with high-grade fever, productive cough, rust-coloured (red currant jelly) sputum, right-sided pleuritic chest pain, decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung fields, and neutrophilia is suggestive of pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae. Klebsiella pneumoniae:   It is the most common cause of gram-negative bacterial pneumonia.   It causes typical pneumonia with neutrophil-rich exudate that fills the bronchi, bronchioles, and adjacent alveolar spaces.   It commonly afflicts debilitated and malnourished people, particularly chronic alcoholics.   Thick, mucoid (often blood-tinged) sputum is characteristic because the organism produces an abundant viscid capsular polysaccharide, which the patient may have difficulty expectorating. Mycoplasma Pneumonia (Option A)   Mycoplasma pneumonia causes atypical pneumonia with dry cough, fever, and fatigue.   It often presents with mild symptoms but can lead to complications.   It presents with a persistent dry cough, low-grade fever, sore throat, headache, and fatigue.   Chest X-ray findings may appear worse than clinical symptoms.   It spreads via respiratory droplets and is common in young adults and crowded settings. Treatment includes macrolides or tetracyclines. Legionella pneumophila (Option B):   Legionella pneumophila is the agent of legionnaires’ disease and Pontiac fever, a self-limited upper respiratory tract infection.   It flourishes in artificial aquatic environments, such as water-cooling towers and the tubing systems of domestic (potable) water supplies.   It is common in individuals with predisposing conditions such as cardiac, renal, immunologic, or hematologic disease and organ transplant recipients. Moraxella catarrhalis (Option C):   Moraxella catarrhalis is recognised as a cause of bacterial pneumonia, especially in the elderly.   It is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD.   Along with S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae, M. catarrhalis is one of the three most common causes of otitis media in children.

Pulmonary aspergillosis is the most common form.   KOH (10%) mount or histopathological staining of specimens reveals characteristic narrow septate hyaline hyphae with acute angle branching. Measles:   The measles virus is a single-stranded RNA virus of the Paramyxoviridae family.   It causes measles, an acute, highly contagious childhood disease characterised by fever and respiratory symptoms followed by a typical maculopapular rash. questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not associated with aspiration?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Nelson syndrome Explanation: Nelson syndrome is not associated with aspiration. It is a rare disorder that occurs in some individuals who have undergone surgical removal of both adrenal glands to treat Cushing's disease. It is characterised by the growth of a pituitary tumour, often resulting in elevated levels of ACTH and increased skin pigmentation. Aspiration pneumonia:   It occurs in markedly debilitated patients or those who aspirate gastric contents either while unconscious (e.g., after a stroke) or during repeated vomiting.   Predisposing factors: Abnormal gag and swallowing reflexes.   The resultant pneumonia is partly chemical due to the irritating effects of gastric acid and partly bacterial (from the oral flora).   More than one organism is recovered in culture (aerobes > anaerobes).   It is often necrotising with a fulminant clinical course, and a frequent cause of death. questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with a persistent cough, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals an infiltrate in the upper lobe of the right lung. Which of the following pathological processes is not seen in this condition?

options.A: Th2-mediated macrophage activation and killing of bacteria.
options.B: The bacterium blocks phagolysosome formation by recruiting a host protein called
options.C: M. tuberculosis is recognised by innate immunity receptors.
options.D: It causes granulomatous inflammation and damage.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Th2-mediated macrophage activation and killing of bacteria. Explanation: The clinical presentation of a 45-year-old male with a persistent cough, night sweats, unintentional weight loss, and chest X-ray showing an infiltrate in the upper lobe of the right lung is suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis. Th2-mediated macrophage activation and bacteria killing is not seen in tuberculosis. Rather, a Th-1-mediated response is seen. Pathogenesis of tuberculosis:   Infection by M. tuberculosis proceeds in steps, from initial infection of macrophages to a subsequent Th1 response that both contains the bacteria and causes tissue damage.   Early in infection, M. tuberculosis replicates essentially unchecked within macrophages, and later in infection, the cell response stimulates macrophages to contain the proliferation of the bacteria.   The steps for infection are as follows: Entry into macrophag esM. tuberculosis enters macrophages by phagocytosis. Replication in macrophagesM. tuberculosis inhibits the maturation of the phagosome. It blocks the formation of the phagolysosome (Option B), allowing the bacterium to replicate unchecked within the vesicle. Thus, during the earliest stage of primary tuberculosis (<3 weeks) in the nonsensitized individual, bacteria proliferate in the pulmonary alveolar macrophages and air spaces, resulting in bacteremia and seeding of multiple sites. Despite the bacteremia, most people at this stage are asymptomatic or have a mild flu-like illness. Innate immunity (Option C)Mycobacterial lipoarabinomannan binds TLR2, and unmethylated CpG nucleotides bind TLR9. These interactions initiate and enhance the innate and adaptive immune responses to M. tuberculosis, as described below. Th1 response, Th1 mediated macrophage activation, and killing of the bacteria (mediated by IFN- γ). Granulomatous inflammation and damage (mediated by Th1 response) (Option D). Caseous necrosis and giant cell formation (epithelioid histiocytes-giant cells, mediated by IFN- γ).

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with fever, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, erythema nodosum, and acute polyarthritis affecting ankles and knees. He has a history of recurrent uveitis. Laboratory tests show elevated serum angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels and hypercalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Lofgren's syndrome Explanation :   This patient's clinical presentation and lab findings are suggestive of Lofgren’s syndrome which is associated with sarcoidosis.   A history of uveitis, elevated levels of serum angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), which is a marker of granulomatous activity, and hypercalcemia (increased activation of vitamin D by macrophages within granulomas) all point to systemic involvement and suggest sarcoidosis. Lofgren syndrome triad: Lupus pernio (Option A):   Cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis characterised by violaceous or erythematous indurated plaques distributed on the central face, particularly the nose and cheeks. Mikulicz syndrome (Option C):   Defined as diffuse and bilateral enlargement of the salivary and lacrimal glands.   It can occur as an isolated phenomenon or as a part of systemic diseases like sarcoidosis, Sjögren syndrome, etc. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (Option D):   Autoimmune disease affecting multiple organs, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and heart.   Common symptoms of SLE include joint pain, skin rash (such as the classic butterfly rash), fatigue, and organ involvement.

questions.question: In a histopathological examination of a lung biopsy from a patient with suspected sarcoidosis, which of the following microscopic features would be most characteristic and supportive of the diagnosis?

options.A: Macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment
options.B: Non-necrotizing granulomas with asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Non-necrotizing granulomas with asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies Explanation:   Sarcoidosis is characterised by non-necrotizing granulomas containing asteroid bodies (stellate-shaped structures) and Schaumann bodies (calcium and protein inclusions). Asteroid Bodies:   Asteroid bodies are stellate or star-shaped structures seen within the cytoplasm of giant cells.   They are composed of aggregated proteinaceous material consisting primarily of fibrin.   The image below shows asteroid bodies. Schaumann Bodies:   They are concentrically laminated, basophilic structures found within the cytoplasm of giant cells.   They comprise calcium and proteinaceous material, such as mucopolysaccharides and immunoglobulins.   Macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment (smokers’ macrophages) (Option A) are seen in desquamative interstitial pneumonia and respiratory bronchiolitis–associated interstitial lung disease.   Coalescent tubercles with central caseation (Option C) are seen in active lesions of secondary tuberculosis.   Curschmann spirals (extrusion of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous glands) and Charcot-Leyden crystals (composed of the eosinophil-derived protein) (Option D) are characteristic findings in sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage specimens of patients with atopic asthma.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with a chronic cough, dyspnea, and chest tightness. On examination, fine crackles are heard bilaterally. A lung biopsy reveals collections of carbon-laden macrophages within the respiratory bronchioles and alveolar ducts, along with focal fibrosis and occasional small granulomas. Which of the following is not a condition associated with this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Psittacosis Explanation:   As the histopathology shows carbon-laden macrophages, it is not associated with Psittacosis which is a zoonotic bacterial infection caused by Chlamydia psittaci, contracted from exposure to infected birds, such as parrots.   Carbon deposits are dark black and are readily visible grossly and microscopically.   Inhaled carbon pigment is engulfed by alveolar or interstitial macrophages, accumulating in the connective tissue adjacent to the lymphatics and organised lymphoid tissue adjacent to the bronchi or lung hilum. Anthracosis (Option A) is the deposition of carbon particles in the lungs due to chronic inhalation of smoke, soot, or pollution.   It is commonly seen in urban dwellers, smokers, and coal workers. HPE shows carbon-laden macrophages. Coal Worker’s Pneumoconiosis (CWP) Simple CWP (Option B)Complicated CWP (Option C) It is characterised by coal macules (1 to 2 mm in diameter) and larger coal nodules containing carbon-laden macrophages and a delicate network of collagen fibres. Although these lesions are scattered throughout the lung, the upper lobes and upper zones of the lower lobes are more heavily involved. Dilatation of alveoli adjacent to bronchioles gives rise to centrilobular emphysema.It leads to progressive massive fibrosis and large, dark scars measuring 1 to 10 cm in diameter, often appearing in multiple areas. Microscopically, these lesions contain dense collagen and pigment deposition. Lung function is compromised

questions.question: Which of the following forms of asbestos is more toxic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Amphibole Explanation:   Amphibole (crocidolite, amosite) is the most toxic form of asbestos.   Asbestos is a family of crystalline hydrated silicates associated with pulmonary fibrosis and various forms of cancer.   It occurs in two distinct geometric forms: serpentine and amphibole.   Amphiboles are straight and stiffly aligned with the airstream and can be delivered deeper into the lungs. They can penetrate epithelial cells and reach the interstitium.   Chrysolites, with their more flexible, curled structure, are likely to become impacted in the upper respiratory passages and removed by the mucociliary elevator. Even if they get trapped in the lungs, they are easily removed as they are more soluble.   Both amphiboles and serpentines are fibrogenic and are associated with a higher incidence of asbestos-related diseases. Serpentine/ Chrysolite Amphibole/ Crocidolite/ Amosite Wavy Rigid More common (90% of the asbestos) More pathogenic (amphiboles particularly associated with mesothelioma) Mnemonic: I am crying (Chrysotile) After looking at a snake (Serpentine) Snake is wavy Snakes can be seen more commonly (more common)Mnemonic: I am on a site (Amosite) Saw a Crocodile (Crocidolite) Which is an Amphibian Crocodile is straight (rigid) Erionite is a naturally occurring fibrous mineral with properties similar to asbestos. Exposure to it is associated with increased risks of lung cancer and mesothelioma.

questions.question: A patient has been experiencing dyspnea for the past few weeks. A biopsy of his lungs has revealed the finding given below. What is the characteristic finding shown below in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Ferruginous body The histopathological slide shows golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods with a translucent core containing asbestos fibres coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material suggestive of asbestos (ferruginous) bodies. They arise when macrophages phagocytose asbestos fibres; the iron is presumably derived from phagocyte ferritin. Laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins are known as Schaumann bodies (Option B) and stellate inclusions are known as asteroid bodies (Option D). Both are found within giant cells in patients with sarcoidosis. Creola bodies (Option A) are ciliated columnar cells shed from the bronchial mucosa of patients with asthma.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent chest pain, shortness of breath, and unexplained weight loss. He was chronically exposed to minerals when he worked as a shipbuilder. Imaging studies revealed a growth that was subjected to needle biopsy. What is the most common lung malignancy associated with his occupational exposure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Adenocarcinoma Explanation:   The patient's occupational history where he worked as a Shipbuilder suggests that he was chronically exposed to Asbestos and the most common lung malignancy seen with occupational asbestos exposure is adenocarcinoma.   Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung and pleural cancers.   Asbestos-related lung carcinoma is markedly magnified by smoking.   Thus, asbestos workers (particularly those who smoke) are at much higher risk of dying of lung carcinoma than mesothelioma.   Compared to other occupational lung diseases which affect the upper lobes of the lungs, it commonly affects the lower lobes.   Adenocarcinoma (primary bronchogenic carcinoma) is the most common type of cancer that accounts for about 45%, followed by squamous cell carcinoma. (Option A)   Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure. It is common but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma. (Option C)   In contrast to bronchogenic carcinoma, the risk of mesothelioma does not increase with smoking in patients with asbestos.

It occurs in those working with bagasse, such as those in wallboard or paper manufacturing, but is not seen in sugar industry workers.   Siderosis is due to exposure to iron oxide in welders.   Berylliosis is caused by beryllium exposure. It leads to non-caseating granulomas, as in sarcoidosis and can be differentiated based on industry exposure.   Stannosis- Tin/ Lead exposure.   Baritosis- Barium exposure.

questions.question: A patient presents with respiratory distress and is diagnosed with pan-acinar emphysema. Which deficiency is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:   Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency leads to pan-acinar emphysema and liver cirrhosis. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D do not cause pan-acinar emphysema.

questions.question: A male patient is diagnosed with ARDS and is not responding to oxygen therapy. What is the role of IL-8 in ARDS?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Neutrophil recruitment:   Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a potent chemokine that plays a significant role in the inflammatory response in Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). Its primary function is to recruit neutrophils to the site of inflammation in the lungs. Once recruited, neutrophils release enzymes and reactive oxygen species that contribute to lung tissue damage, a hallmark of ARDS. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are not influenced by IL-8.

questions.question: TTF-1 immunohistochemical marker is associated with which of the following cancers?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Lung adenocarcinoma:   TTF-1 is an immunohistochemical marker for lung adenocarcinoma. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D: TTF-1 is not an immunohistochemical marker for these tumors.

questions.question: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the provided histopathology of the enlarged cervical lymph node?
questions.solution: Correct Option B – Tuberculosis:   The given histopathological image shows signs of chronic granulomatous inflammation, along with areas of caseous necrosis (seen as pink-colored areas) and Langerhans giant cells. All these findings are suggestive of Tuberculosis. Incorrect Options: Option A: Sarcoidosis- Sarcoidosis typically presents with non-caseating granuloma or naked granuloma (lymphocytic collar absent). Option C: Histoplasmosis- Histoplasmosis shows the presence of small Histoplasma capsulatum yeasts. Option D: Brucellosis- Brucellosis does not show caseous necrosis and Langerhans giant cells.

questions.question: Based on the biopsy image given below, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A – Adenocarcinoma:   The presence of glands in the given histopatholgy image indicates adenocarcinoma of the lung. In adenocarcinoma of the lung, neoplastic epithelial cells proliferate in a glandular pattern, forming well-differentiated tumors characterized by distinct glandular structures. Incorrect Options: Option B - Squamous cell carcinoma: The absence of keratin pearls and desmosomes in the image indicates that it does not correspond to squamous cell carcinoma. Option C - Small cell carcinoma: The image does not exhibit the salt and pepper appearance of chromatin or the Azzopardi Effect, features of small cell carcinoma. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of granulomas without central necrosis. What is the most likely histological finding in this scenario?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Non-caseating granuloma:. questions.question: What is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Mycoplasma pneumoniae:   Mycoplasma pneumoniae is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia.   It is a small bacterium that lacks a cell wall and is typically associated with mild respiratory symptoms such as cough, sore throat, and low-grade fever.   Atypical pneumonia refers to a milder form of pneumonia that often presents with non-specific symptoms. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are not the most common cause of atypical pneumonia.

questions.question: The most common lung finding in a COVID-19 infection is:
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Diffuse alveolar damage:   The most common lung finding in a COVID-19 infection is diffuse alveolar damage (DAD).   COVID-19 is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which primarily affects the respiratory system.   When the virus enters the lungs, it can cause inflammation and damage to the alveoli, which are the tiny air sacs responsible for gas exchange.   Diffuse alveolar damage is a histopathological pattern observed in the lungs of patients with severe respiratory diseases, including COVID-19.   It is characterized by injury to the alveolar epithelium, inflammation, and the accumulation of fluid, protein, and inflammatory cells within the alveolar spaces.   This leads to impaired oxygenation and respiratory distress. Incorrect Options: Option A - Pulmonary infarction:   Pulmonary infarction refers to the obstruction of the blood supply to a portion of the lung, resulting in tissue death.   While COVID-19 can cause vascular complications and blood clotting disorders, pulmonary infarction is not the most common lung finding associated with COVID-19. Option C - Endothelial injury:   COVID-19 can cause endothelial dysfunction and injury, leading to vascular complications and the formation of blood clots.   However, endothelial injury is not the most common lung finding specifically associated with COVID-19. Option D - Fibrin clots:   COVID-19 can lead to a hypercoagulable state and an increased risk of blood clot formation.   While fibrin clots can be observed in the lungs of COVID-19 patients, they are not the most common lung finding associated with the infection.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with a chronic cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain. He has a history of working in construction for several decades, where he was exposed to asbestos. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds over the lower lung fields. A chest X-ray shows bilateral, diffuse interstitial opacities. Pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest demonstrates "honeycombing" in the lung parenchyma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Asbestosis:   Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers.   It presents with symptoms like a chronic cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain.   Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial opacities, and HRCT may show " honeycombing" due to fibrosis.   The restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests is a characteristic finding in asbestosis. Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.question: Ciliocytophthoria is most commonly seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Acute respiratory infection:   Ciliocytophthoria refers to the presence of ciliated respiratory epithelial cells with cytoplasmic vacuoles containing inhaled particles, such as bacteria, viruses, or debris.   It is commonly observed in respiratory infections, particularly those affecting the lower respiratory tract. Incorrect Options:   Ciliocytophthoria can be seen in options B, C, and D but is not specific to these conditions.

questions.question: A 47-year-old male active smoker with a known case of bronchial asthma now presents with difficulty breathing, with the breath sounds being audible externally. Which of the following is not a feature you will expect to find in this patient?

options.B: Increase in number of airway goblet cells

questions.solution: Correct Option C - Fibroblastic foci:   Fibroblastic foci are not a characteristic feature of bronchial asthma.   Fibroblastic foci are commonly seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), a distinct disease characterized by progressive lung scarring and fibrosis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Thickening of bronchial wall:   In bronchial asthma, chronic inflammation of the airways leads to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of smooth muscle cells, along with edema and infiltration of inflammatory cells.   This contributes to the thickening of the bronchial wall. Option B - Increase in the number of airway goblet cells:   Goblet cells produce and secrete mucus in the respiratory tract.   In asthma, there is an increase in goblet cell hyperplasia, leading to excessive mucus production and airway obstruction. Option D - Sub-basement membrane fibrosis:   Chronic inflammation in asthma can lead to remodelling of the airway wall, including thickening of the sub-basement membrane due to the deposition of collagen and other extracellular matrix components.   This contributes to airway narrowing.

questions.question: Which of the following is a post-mortem finding seen in the lung after the death of a patient from COVID-19 after a week?

options.D: Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.solution: Correct Option B - Thick layer of fibrin:   In severe COVID-19 cases, fibrin and inflammatory cells accumulate in the alveoli, leading to diffuse alveolar damage.   Fibrin deposits and hyaline membranes can form within the alveoli, impairing gas exchange. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are not a post-mortem finding seen in the lung after the death of a patient from COVID-19.

questions.question: A 25-year-old farmer was admitted with an acute onset of fever, cough, and dyspnea. A chest radiograph showed findings of pneumonia, for which he was treated with antibiotics and showed a good response. After 1 month, he again presented in a hypoxemic state with progressive dyspnea. The CT chest showed diffuse ground glass changes. Transbronchial biopsies showed numerous small granulomas and marked lymphocytosis. Which of the following is a causative agent for a given disease?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Thermoactinomyces sacchari:   The patient's presentation with sudden fever, cough, and difficulty breathing and then improving and again deteriorating with diffuse ground glass changes on CT and multiple small granulomas on transbronchial biopsies suggests hypersensitivity pneumonitis.   The most likely causative agent for the disease in this case is Thermoactinomyces sacchari.   Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP), classified as an interstitial lung disease, is characterized by a complex immunological reaction of the lung parenchyma in response to repetitive inhalation of a sensitized allergen. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D do not cause hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient who has been working in a factory for the past 20 years presents with breathlessness. HRCT of the of the chest shows pleural thickening and fibrosis. What is the person suffering from?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Asbestosis:   The patient's history of working in a factory for a prolonged period, along with the HRCT chest findings of pleural thickening and fibrosis, points towards the diagnosis of asbestosis.   Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers, commonly encountered in occupational settings.   Prolonged exposure to asbestos can lead to the deposition of fibers in the lungs, triggering an inflammatory response that results in fibrosis and scarring of lung tissue, including the pleura. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D do not cause pleural thickening and fibrosis. Option B - Coal worker pneumoconiosis:   Coal worker pneumoconiosis, also known as black lung disease, is caused by the inhalation of coal dust.   It typically presents with coal macules and nodules in the lungs. Option C - Silicosis:   Silicosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica dust.   It results in the formation of fibrotic nodules in the lungs. Option D - Berylliosis:   Berylliosis is a lung disease caused by exposure to beryllium.   It primarily affects the lung parenchyma.

questions.question: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imaging shows dense infiltration in the lower lobe, and the lung biopsy showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - CMV pneumonia:   The patient's presentation with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks and history of HIV with owl eye appearance in the image is suggestive of CMV pneumonia. Incorrect Options:   Options A, C, and D do not have an owl eye appearance.

questions.question: Identify the condition represented in the image below:
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Miliary tuberculosis:   The image showing a lung specimen represents miliary tuberculosis.   Miliary tuberculosis is a form of tuberculosis characterized by the widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis throughout the body.   In this condition, the bacteria spread through the bloodstream and affect multiple organs, including the lungs.   The term "miliary" refers to the appearance of small millet seed-like lesions, which can be seen on imaging or in pathological specimens, giving the characteristic appearance seen in the image. Incorrect Options:   Options A, C, and D do not present with the widespread millet seed-like lesions seen in the image.

questions.question: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of:
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Measles:   The presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies is suggestive of measles infection.   The Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are multinucleated cells that contain viral inclusion bodies and are commonly seen in measles infections. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are not associated with the presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.

questions.question: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was the person most likely working in?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Asbestos:   Based on the histopathological image provided, the most likely industry the person was working in is asbestos.   Asbestos exposure is associated with the development of a specific lung disease known as asbestosis.   Asbestosis is a chronic lung condition caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers over a prolonged period of time.   These fibers accumulate in the lung tissue, leading to inflammation, fibrosis, and scarring.   The histopathological features seen in asbestosis include: Interstitial fibrosis: Asbestos fibers cause injury to the lung parenchyma, resulting in the deposition of collagen and fibrous tissue in the interstitium. This fibrosis leads to thickening of the alveolar walls and restrictive lung function. Ferruginous bodies: Asbestos fibers can be recognized in the lung tissue as long, golden-brown, rod-shaped structures called ferruginous bodies. These bodies are composed of an asbestos fiber coated with iron and protein. Their presence is highly suggestive of asbestos exposure. Histopathological features of silicosis include the presence of nodular lesions composed of silica particles, collagenous fibrosis, and characteristic concentric layers known as silicotic nodules. Option C - Coal dust:   Coal dust exposure is associated with a lung disease known as coal worker's pneumoconiosis (CWP).   Histopathological features of CWP include the presence of coal macules (collections of carbon-laden macrophages) and coal nodules (fibrotic lesions with central cores of coal dust).
