questions.question: Whipple's disease is caused by:
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Bacteria:   Whipple's disease is a rare systemic infectious disease caused by a bacterium called Tropheryma whipplei.   It primarily affects the small intestine but can also involve various other organs, such as the joints, heart, brain, and eyes.   The bacterium infects the lining of the small intestine, leading to malabsorption of nutrients and subsequent systemic symptoms. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sensitive and specific marker of intestinal inflammation?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Fecal lactoferrin:   Lactoferrin is an enzyme that is synthesized from neutrophil granulocytes and epithelial cells.   Fecal lactoferrin and fecal calprotectin are raised in active intestinal diseases like ulcerative colitis.   Fecal lactoferrin is a marker of IBD and is used to rule out irritable bowel syndrome.   Fecal lactoferrin also helps in monitoring the response to treatment. Incorrect Options: Option A - Procalcitonin:   Procalcitonin is synthesized by C cells of the thyroid gland.   It increases in response to severe sepsis or any bacterial infection. Option C - Tissue transglutaminase IgA:   Tissue transglutaminase IgA helps in the diagnosis of celiac disease. Option D - High-sensitivity C-reactive protein:   High-sensitivity CRP helps in assessing the risk of coronary artery disease and is more sensitive than the normal C-reactive protein.

questions.question: Which one of the subsequent options pertains to a stomach tumor present with acanthosis nigricans?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Gastric adenocarcinoma:   Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor that presents with acanthosis nigricans. Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and C do not present with acanthosis nigricans.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Barrett's esophagus?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Intestinal metaplasia:   Barrett's esophagus is characterized by the presence of intestinal metaplasia.   Intestinal metaplasia is the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus with a columnar epithelium similar to that found in the intestine.   This change is considered a precursor to the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about celiac disease?

options.A: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries
options.C: Improves with food rich in carbohydrates

questions.solution: Correct Option D - Increased risk of GI lymphoma:   Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by a hypersensitivity reaction to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.   It primarily affects the small intestine and leads to chronic inflammation and damage to the intestinal lining.   This chronic inflammation and damage increase the risk of developing gastrointestinal (GI) lymphoma, which is a type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system in the GI tract. Incorrect Options: Option A - Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries:   Celiac disease is more commonly seen in developed countries, particularly in populations of European descent. Option B - Can be diagnosed with CECT:   CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is not a diagnostic test for celiac disease.   The diagnosis of celiac disease is typically made through a combination of clinical evaluation, serologic testing (e.g., anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies), and confirmation by small bowel biopsy. Option C - Improves with food rich in carbohydrates:   Celiac disease is not improved by consuming a diet rich in carbohydrates.   In fact, the primary treatment for celiac disease is a strict gluten-free diet, which involves avoiding foods that contain gluten.

questions.question: All is true about the Barrett oesophagus, except?

options.B: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
options.C: Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.solution: Correct Option C - Increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma:   Barrett esophagus increases the risk of developing adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. Incorrect Options: Option A - Complication of chronic GERD:   Barrett esophagus is considered a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).   Prolonged exposure to stomach acid can cause changes in the lining of the esophagus, leading to the development of Barrett's esophagus. Option B - Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD:   Barrett esophagus is estimated to occur in about 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Option D - Intestinal metaplasia:   Barrett esophagus is characterized by the presence of intestinal metaplasia, where the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium resembling the lining of the intestine.

questions.question: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Herpes simplex virus:   Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus can be caused by a herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.   HSV esophagitis typically presents with shallow, well-demarcated ulcers with a punched-out appearance.   The infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS or undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Incorrect Options: Option B - Cytomegalovirus: CMV esophagitis typically presents with linear or linearly arranged shallow ulcers in the esophagus. Option C - Candida: Candida esophagitis can cause raised, white plaques or pseudomembranes in the esophagus. Option D - Gastric acid: Acid reflux or gastroesophageal reflux disease can cause esophagitis, but it typically results in erosions or linear ulcers.

questions.question: A 17-year-old boy presented with intussusception and was taken up for surgery. He was found to have multiple polyps. The resected section was sent for histopathology, and the whole mount image of the specimen is given below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Hamartomatous Polyp:   In the given histopathological image, the identified lesion is a hamartomatous polyp, as it shows an arborizing pattern of connective tissue, smooth muscle, glands, and lamina propria.   Hamartomatous polyps are non-neoplastic growths that result from the disorganised overgrowth of normal tissues in an organ.   Hamartomatous polyps are commonly associated with genetic syndromes such as Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) and juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS). Incorrect Options: Option A - Tubulovillous adenoma:   A tubulovillous adenoma is a premalignant lesion characterized by the presence of both tubular and villous components.   It has the potential to progress to adenocarcinoma.   However, the given image does not show the characteristic features of a tubulovillous adenoma, such as dysplasia or the presence of dysplastic cells within the epithelial lining. Option C - Adenocarcinoma:   Adenocarcinoma is a malignant tumor that arises from the glandular cells of an organ.   It is characterized by invasive growth and the presence of dysplastic cells.   The given image does not show features consistent with adenocarcinoma, such as infiltration into the surrounding tissue or cytological atypia. Option D - Hyperplastic polyp:   Hyperplastic polyps are non-neoplastic growths characterized by an increase in the number of cells in the epithelial layer of the organ.   They are typically small, sessile, and have a smooth surface.   The given image does not match the typical appearance of hyperplastic polyps, which are usually smaller and more uniform in size.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease?

options.A: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.solution: Correct Option A - Failure of migration of neural crest cells:   Hirschsprung disease, also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon, is a developmental disorder of the gastrointestinal tract characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric and submucosal plexuses of the distal bowel, leading to functional obstruction.   Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of the migration of neural crest cells, which are responsible for the development of the enteric nervous system.   In normal development, neural crest cells migrate along the gastrointestinal tract and populate the entire length, including the distal bowel.   In Hirschsprung disease, there is a segment of the bowel where the ganglion cells fail to migrate, resulting in an aganglionic segment leading to functional obstruction and impaired motility. Incorrect Options: Option B - Increase ganglion cells:   Hirschsprung disease is characterized by a lack of ganglion cells. Option C - Visceral myopathy:   Visceral myopathy refers to a group of disorders characterized by abnormal smooth muscle function in the gastrointestinal tract.   While Hirschsprung disease involves abnormalities in the enteric nervous system, it does not involve primary defects in the smooth muscle layer. Option D - Obstruction by inflammatory strictures:   Inflammatory strictures are not associated with the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease.

questions.question: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. A duodenal biopsy showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in the lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Celiac disease:   Celiac disease, also known as gluten-sensitive enteropathy, is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing grains, such as wheat, barley, and rye, in genetically predisposed individuals.   It is characterized by an immune-mediated response to gluten, leading to damage in the small intestine.   The duodenal biopsy findings of crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and the presence of CD8+ cells in the lamina propria are characteristic features of celiac disease. Incorrect Options: Option A - Environmental enteropathy: Environmental enteropathy is a condition characterized by chronic intestinal inflammation and structural changes in the small intestine, typically seen in individuals from developing countries with poor sanitation and hygiene. Option C - Whipple's disease: Whipple's disease is a rare bacterial infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei and primarily affects the small intestine but can involve other organs. Option D - Chronic pancreatitis: Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the pancreas, leading to impaired pancreatic function.

questions.question: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Juvenile polyp:   Juvenile polyps are benign growths that commonly occur in children, typically under the age of 5.   They are characterized by a prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding.   The given histopathological image shows juvenile polyps showing dilated crypts and dilated glands filled with mucin. Incorrect Options: Option A - Peutz-Jeghers syndrome:   Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by the presence of hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract.   While it can manifest with rectal polyps, the histopathological image is more characteristic of juvenile polyps. Option B - Villous adenoma:   Villous adenoma is a type of adenomatous polyp that is more commonly seen in adults.   It is characterized by finger-like projections with abundant mucin production.   The histopathological image is more characteristic of juvenile polyps. Option D - Tubular adenoma:   Tubular adenoma is a common type of adenomatous polyp that typically occurs in adults.   It is characterized by glandular structures composed of tubular architecture.   The histopathological image is more characteristic of juvenile polyps.

questions.question: Which of the following can be given to a celiac disease patient?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Quinoa:   Quinoa is a gluten-free grain and can be safely consumed by individuals with celiac disease.   Quinoa does not contain gluten and is considered a suitable alternative for people following a gluten-free diet. questions.question: Which of the following statements are true about familial adenomatous polyposis? It is autosomal recessive. If not treated, 100% of the cases progress to adenocarcinoma colon. Polyps do not arise after puberty. It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.
questions.solution: Correct Option A - 2 and 4: 2. If not treated, 100% of the cases progress to adenocarcinoma colon:   FAP is characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon.   If left untreated, these polyps have a high likelihood of progressing to colon cancer (adenocarcinoma).   Therefore, it is crucial to detect and manage FAP early to prevent the development of cancer. 4. questions.question: Which of the following is the manifestation of increased estrogen levels in Cirrhosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Palmar erythema Explanation: Increased estrogen levels in chronic liver failure lead to vascular changes, resulting in palmar erythema and spider angiomas. This condition can also cause hypogonadism and gynecomastia in males. Increased PT and aPTT (Option A) are primarily due to impaired synthesis of clotting factors by the damaged liver rather than the effects of hyperestrogenemia. Flapping tremors (aka asterixis) (Option B) are commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy in cirrhosis, primarily due to elevated ammonia levels rather than estrogen. Jaundice (Option D) seen in cirrhosis is a result of impaired bilirubin metabolism due to liver dysfunction rather than being directly influenced by estrogen levels.

questions.question: Which of the following is not typically associated with developing fatty liver disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Hepatitis B Explanation:   Hepatitis B primarily affects the liver by causing inflammation and can lead to chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, and liver cancer, but it does not directly cause fatty liver disease.   Fatty liver disease is often associated with several factors, such as alcoholism (Option D), obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and type 2 diabetes (Option C).   Chronic Hepatitis C (Option B) can cause liver inflammation and damage, potentially resulting in fat accumulation in the liver cells and leading to fatty liver disease.

questions.question: Which of the following is typically observed in liver biopsy findings of acute hepatitis A infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Councilman bodies Explanation: Councilman bodies, also known as acidophilic or apoptotic bodies, are eosinophilic structures representing apoptotic hepatocytes. These are characteristic findings of acute viral hepatitis. questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Mallory-Denk bodies Explanation: The histopathological feature characteristic of the condition depicted in the biopsy image is Mallory-Denk bodies, a hallmark of both alcohol-induced and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. questions.question: Which cells are primarily involved in the fibrosis in liver cirrhosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Stellate cells Explanation:   Hepatic stellate cells (or Ito cells) are pericytes located in the space of Disse, between hepatocytes and sinusoidal endothelial cells in the liver.   In the healthy liver, these cells store vitamin A in lipid droplets and regulate sinusoidal blood flow.   Upon liver injury, they activate and transform into myofibroblast-like cells, release TGFβ, and lead to fibrosis by producing excessive extracellular matrix, such as collagen. Kupffer cells (Option A) are macrophages found in sinusoids of the liver, involved in phagocytosis. Pit cells (Option B) are liver-associated lymphocytes, primarily NK (Natural Killer) cells. They contribute to liver immune surveillance but are not directly implicated in liver fibrosis. Hepatocytes (Option D) are vital liver cells.

questions.question: A 38-year-old female presents with fatigue, joint pain, and bronze skin pigmentation. Labs show a heterozygous mutation in the HFE gene. The histopathology image is shown below. Which of the following is the best screening test for this condition?

options.D: Genetic testing for the HFE gene

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Transferrin saturation Explanation:   The diagnosis in this case is hemochromatosis.   Transferrin saturation (TSAT) is the best screening test for hereditary hemochromatosis.   TSAT measures the amount of iron bound to transferrin, reflecting the body's iron status.   Elevated TSAT levels (>45-50%) suggest iron overload, which is a characteristic feature of hemochromatosis. Serum ferritin is a protein that stores iron in the body. However, while serum ferritin levels can be a useful indicator, they are not as specific as transferrin saturation (TSAT) for diagnosing hemochromatosis (Option A). In hereditary hemochromatosis, LFTs may show abnormalities in advanced stages of the disease when iron overload has caused liver damage (e.g., elevated alanine transaminase or AST levels). However, LFTs are not specific screening tests for hemochromatosis (Option C). Genetic testing for mutations in the HFE gene is the definitive diagnostic test for hereditary hemochromatosis (Option D).

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient presents with a history of tremors, dysarthria, and personality changes. Serum ceruloplasmin levels were found to be low. Based on the image below, what ocular finding is associated with the underlying condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Kayser-Fleischer rings Explanation: The image shows characteristic Kayser-Fleischer rings, a brownish-green discolouration in the cornea.   These rings are associated with Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder involving copper metabolism.   Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterised by impaired copper metabolism. It leads to copper accumulation primarily in the liver, brain, and other organs.   Molecular genetic testing can identify mutations in the ATP7B gene, which is responsible for Wilson's disease. Clinical Features:   Kayser-Fleischer Rings: These are characteristic brownish-green rings seen in the cornea due to copper deposition and are a hallmark feature of Wilson's disease.   Serum copper is raised, while ceruloplasmin levels (a copper-binding protein) are decreased in Wilson's disease.   Increased urinary copper excretion is a characteristic finding in Wilson's disease. Arcus senilis refers to a white or greyish ring around the cornea that is commonly seen in elderly individuals. It is caused by lipid deposits in the peripheral cornea and is generally considered a normal age-related change. (Option A) Roth spots are retinal haemorrhages with a white or pale centre. Roth spots can be seen in various medical conditions, including bacterial endocarditis, leukemia, and diabetic retinopathy (Option C) Horner's syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterised by a triad of eye and face symptoms. It includes ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constriction of the pupil), and anhidrosis (decreased sweating) on the affected side of the face (Option D)

Brain Imaging: MRI to assess neurological involvement.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with a history of chronic alcohol abuse and complains of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Laboratory investigations show elevated liver enzymes. Gross feature of the liver has a characteristic mottled appearance. Based on these findings and the image below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Nutmeg Liver Explanation: The patient's history of chronic alcohol abuse and the characteristic mottled appearance of the liver on imaging studies point towards Nutmeg Liver as the most likely diagnosis. Nutmeg liver, also known as congestive hepatopathy or passive hepatic congestion, is a condition characterized by a mottled appearance of the liver on imaging studies, resembling the cross-section of a nutmeg seed. This appearance is due to centrilobular congestion and haemorrhage caused by chronic passive congestion of the liver, often secondary to right-sided heart failure, chronic venous congestion, or conditions leading to hepatic venous outflow obstruction. Acute passive congestion (“nutmeg liver”). (A) The cut surface of the liver has a variegated mottled red appearance, representing congestion and haemorrhage in the centrilobular regions of the parenchyma. (B) On microscopic examination, the centrilobular region is suffused with red blood cells, and atrophied hepatocytes are not easily seen. Portal tracts and the periportal parenchyma are intact.

questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal pain. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Hepatocytes show globular inclusions which are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive. Her sibling died of the same liver condition a few years back. What is the primary function of the enzyme implicated in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Inhibits neutrophil elastase Explanation: Alpha-1 antitrypsin (α1AT) is a serine protease inhibitor that plays a crucial role in inhibiting proteases, particularly neutrophil elastase.   Alpha-1 Antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency is an autosomal recessive (AR) disorder with defective gene in Chromosome 14 - SERPINA1 gene   In Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency (AATD), there is a deficiency or dysfunction of α1AT, leading to decreased inhibition of neutrophil elastase.   This results in uncontrolled protease activity, particularly neutrophil elastase, which can cause tissue damage, especially in the lungs and liver leading to pan-acinar emphysema and liver cirrhosis respectively Histopathology: The deficiency is characterised by the presence of round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes, which are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) 1,2 and 3 Explanation : The following markers will be elevated in case of hepatocellular carcinoma :   HepPar-1 (Statement 1)   Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (Statement 2)   Glypican-3 (GPC3) (Statement 3)   Neurotensin   Arginase-1   CA-19-9 Chronic liver disease with cirrhosis is the major cause of transformation into hepatocellular carcinoma, and some of the common causes are listed below :   Alcohol (as given in the above scenario)   Chronic hepatitis B & C   Metabolic diseases   Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis   Aflatoxins from Aspergillus

questions.question: A 2-year-old child presented with progressive jaundice for the past 2 months. Initial investigations were done, and subsequent histopathological examination of liver biopsy showed changes consistent with hepatoblastoma. Which of the following additional biomarkers will be elevated in this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) AFP (alpha-fetoprotein) Explanation :   Alpha-fetoprotein will be elevated in a patient with hepatoblastoma.   Hepatoblastoma is the most common liver tumour of childhood. Activation of the Wnt signalling pathway is characteristic of hepatoblastoma, leading to nuclear β-catenin and increased expression of Wnt target genes such as glutamine synthetase in nearly all cases.   It is important to note that elevated AFP is not pathognomonic to hepatocellular carcinoma. Conditions where AFP is raised are listed below : Malignancy Non-malignant conditions Hepatocellular carcinoma Hepatoblastoma Secondary liver metastasis Nonseminomatous germ cell tumours Yolk sac tumourNeural tube defects Ataxia telangiectasia CA 19-9 and Neurotensin markers are elevated in Heptatocellular carcinoma. questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) BRCA1 Explanation : BRCA 1 mutation is most commonly associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer in women, whereas PRSS1, SPINK1, and CFTR are linked to hereditary pancreatitis. questions.question: A female patient presents with progressive jaundice and weight loss for the past six months. She also complains of low grade upper abdominal pain. Lab investigation revealed a random blood sugar of 320mg/dL and a raised serum Ig-G4 levels and a USG scan showed a mass like lesion over the head of pancreas. Based on these findings which of the following is the most likely finding in the histopathological examination ?

options.A: Pleomorphic cuboidal to columnar epithelial cells
options.B: Necrotic changes in the acini and ducts
options.D: Swirling fibrosis with inflammation of veins

questions.solution: Correct Answer : D)Swirling fibrosis with inflammation of veins Explanation: Based on the clinical presentation, history, raised blood glucose and serum Ig-G4, along with a mass-like lesion in the pancreas points towards Autoimmune pancreatitis and histopathological examination of the pancreatic specimen will show characteristic swirling/storiform fibrosis with inflammation of veins Autoimmune pancreati tis Types Type 1 - IgG4 associated - common in adults Type 2 - Non-IgG4 associated - common in younger age groups Clinical features Low grade Abdominal pain Jaundice Weight loss Lab findings Elevated IgG4 (except in type 2) Elevated liver enzymes Elevated pancreatic enzymes Elevated blood sugar USG Diffuse enlargement of pancreas Focal enlargement can be present mimicking a malignancy Narrowing of pancreatic ducts Histology Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate predominantly made up of IgG4-positive plasma cells (except in type 2) Swirling fibrosis (storiform fibrosis) and Obliterative phlebitis (inflammation of veins) Treatment Excellent response to steroids Azathioprine for relapsing disease Raised Ig-G4 and the characteristic histological appearance help differentiate autoimmune pancreatitis from carcinoma pancreas since they both present with almost similar clinical features, and a mass-like lesion can be seen while imaging both. Pleomorphic cuboidal to columnar epithelial cells (Option A) are seen in carcinoma pancreas Necrotic changes in the acini and ducts (Option B) are seen in acute necrotising pancreatitis Honeycombing appearance with cuboidal epithelium (Option C) is seen in serous cystadenoma of the pancreas.

questions.question: A patient was evaluated for hepatic cirrhosis, he was investigated for hepatitis B, following were the findings: HbsAg - not reactive AntiHbs IgM - not reactive Total Anti Hbc - reactive Hbe Ag - not reactive Anti Hbe Ab - not reactive. What is your conclusion?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Remote infection with complete recovery:   The absence of HBsAg and the presence of Total Anti-HBc indicate a resolved hepatitis B infection with successful recovery. The patient has developed antibodies against the core antigen, suggesting a past infection that has been cleared. Incorrect Options: Option A - Acute HBV B window period:   The absence of HBsAg and the presence of Total Anti-HBc suggest a past infection rather than an acute infection in the window period. Option B - Chronic hep B carrier:   This option is unlikely because the patient's HbsAg is non-reactive. Chronic carriers typically have persistent HbsAg positivity. Option C - Post-vaccination status:   This option is not supported by the findings. If the patient had been vaccinated, you would expect to see a reactive anti-Hbs response, which is not the case here.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, edema, and ascites. On examination, his liver function tests are severely deranged. Further investigation reveals a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma. The pathogenesis of this condition is most likely related to:
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Aflatoxin:   Aflatoxin is a potent carcinogenic toxin produced by certain molds, primarily Aspergillus species. It is a well-known risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, particularly in individuals with chronic liver disease. Aflatoxin contamination of food, such as grains, nuts, and legumes, can lead to long-term exposure and increase the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma. Incorrect Options: Option A - Benzol (Benzene): Benzene is a chemical compound found in various industrial processes. Exposure to high levels of benzene is associated with the risk of developing leukemia, particularly acute myeloid leukemia. However, benzene exposure is not a known cause of hepatocellular carcinoma. Option B - Arsenic: Arsenic exposure has been linked to various health issues, including skin lesions, cardiovascular disease, and certain types of cancer (such as skin, lung, and bladder cancer). While arsenic exposure might contribute to liver damage in chronic exposures, it is not a primary cause of hepatocellular carcinoma. Option D - Vinyl Chloride: Vinyl chloride is a chemical used in the production of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) plastic and has been associated with liver damage, including a rare form of angiosarcoma known as hepatic angiosarcoma. However, this type of cancer is relatively rare, andhepatocellular carcinoma is not directly linked to vinyl chloride exposure

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 25-year-old male who presented with fever and has the following viral marker results: HBsAg: Positive and IgM anti-HBc antibody: Positive
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Acute hepatitis:   HBsAg is the surface antigen of the Hepatitis B virus and indicates current infection.   IgM anti-HBc antibodies are specific to acute infection and indicate recent exposure to the virus. Incorrect Options: Option B - Chronic hepatitis: Chronic hepatitis B is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg for more than six months. The presence of IgM anti-HBc antibody indicates an acute or recent infection, making chronic hepatitis less likely. Option C - Window period: The window period refers to the time between infection and the appearance of detectable markers. In this context, the presence of both HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc antibody suggests an active infection rather than a window period. Option D - Persistent infection: Persistent infection could be considered for cases with prolonged presence of HBsAg, but the presence of IgM anti-HBc antibody indicates an ongoing immune response, which is more consistent with acute infection.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of having dark tan skin despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. What is this patient most likely suffering from?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Hemochromatosis:   The patient's presentation with dark tan skin and histopathological findings showing iron deposition in liver cells is suggestive of hemochromatosis.   Hemochromatosis is a hereditary disorder characterized by the accumulation of iron in the body, which can lead to damage to various organs, including the liver, heart, and pancreas. Incorrect Options: Option A - Wilson's disease:   Wilson's disease is an inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in various organs, including the liver, brain, and eyes.   The symptoms of Wilson's disease usually begin in childhood or early adulthood and can include neurological symptoms such as tremors, dystonia, and difficulty with coordination.   The liver damage associated with Wilson's disease can lead to hepatomegaly, as well as signs of liver disease such as jaundice, ascites, and elevated liver enzymes. Option B - Autoimmune hepatitis:   Autoimmune hepatitis is a chronic autoimmune disorder that causes inflammation and damage to the liver.   The symptoms of autoimmune hepatitis can include fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and abdominal pain.   Liver damage can lead to hepatomegaly, as well as signs of liver disease such as jaundice, ascites, and elevated liver enzymes. Option C - α-1 antitrypsin deficiency:   α-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that affects the production of a protein called α -1 antitrypsin, which plays a role in protecting the lungs and liver from damage.   The symptoms of α-1 antitrypsin deficiency can include respiratory symptoms such as shortness of breath and coughing, as well as liver diseases such as hepatomegaly and elevated liver enzymes.

questions.question: A health care worker has been found to be seropositive for HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgM, indicating an acute HBV infection with high infectivity. A liver biopsy in such cases is likely to show all the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Ground glass hepatocytes:   Ground glass hepatocytes are hepatocytes with a granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm. This appearance is due to the accumulation of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) within the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes.   This feature is more characteristic of chronic HBV infection rather than acute infection. It reflects ongoing viral replication and chronicity. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D   A. Ballooning change of hepatocytes: Common in acute hepatitis.   C. Focal or spotty necrosis: Common in acute hepatitis.   D. Confluent necrosis of hepatocytes: Seen in severe acute hepatitis.

questions.question: Which marker is specific for alcohol disease?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - GGT:   Elevated levels of GGT in the blood are often associated with liver dysfunction and can be indicative of alcohol-related liver disease.   Alcohol consumption increases the production and release of GGT from liver cells into the bloodstream.   Elevated GGT levels can be used as a specific marker for alcohol abuse or alcohol-related liver damage. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.   SGPT, also known as ALT, and SGOT, also known as AST, are liver enzymes that can be elevated in various liver diseases, including alcohol-related liver damage.   They are not specific to alcohol-related disease.

questions.question: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present, and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Intermediate filaments:   Chronic alcoholism can lead to various liver complications, including alcoholic liver disease.   One of the histopathological features seen in alcoholic liver disease is the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes, known as Mallory-Denk bodies or Mallory bodies.   Mallory bodies are composed of abnormal aggregates of intermediate filaments within hepatocytes. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presented to you. The gross appearance of his liver is shown below. Which of the following is true about it?

options.A: Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver
options.B: Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis

questions.solution: Correct Option A - Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver:   Cirrhosis is a chronic liver disease characterized by fibrosis and nodular regeneration of the liver parenchyma.   It results from various causes, such as chronic alcohol abuse, viral hepatitis, or metabolic disorders.   In cirrhosis, the liver undergoes extensive remodeling, leading to the destruction of normal liver architecture and the formation of fibrous bands.   The dark areas in the liver represent areas of necrosis.   Necrosis refers to the death of liver cells due to insufficient blood supply or impaired liver function.   These areas may appear darker due to the loss of cellular integrity and blood congestion.   The white areas in the liver represent viable liver tissue.   These areas contain functional hepatocytes that are responsible for normal liver functions such as detoxification, metabolism, and the synthesis of proteins.   The presence of viable liver tissue is essential for overall liver function, despite the structural abnormalities caused by cirrhosis. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from which condition?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Hemochromatosis:   Hemochromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by excessive iron absorption and accumulation in various organs, including the liver.   Hepatomegaly is a common finding in hemochromatosis due to iron deposition in hepatocytes.   The liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron staining supports the diagnosis of hemochromatosis in this patient.   Darkening of the skin, known as bronze diabetes or dark tan, is another characteristic feature of hemochromatosis resulting from iron deposition in the skin. Incorrect Options: Option A - Wilson's disease:   Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by impaired copper transport, leading to copper accumulation in various organs, including the liver and brain.   It typically presents with hepatic and neurological symptoms, such as hepatomegaly, jaundice, and neurologic manifestations. Option B - Autoimmune hepatitis:   Autoimmune hepatitis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by immune-mediated inflammation of the liver.   It can present with hepatomegaly, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes. Option C - Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:   Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to liver and lung diseases.   Liver involvement in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency typically presents as neonatal cholestasis or later-onset liver disease.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female presenting with an unsteady gait, forgetfulness, labile moods, and Kayser-Fleischer rings was diagnosed with Wilson’s disease. Which of the following options correctly indicates the gene mutated in this condition and its location?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - ATP7B gene on chromosome 13:   Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder and is the result of pathogenic variants in ATP7B, a gene encoding a copper transport protein, ATP7B, on chromosome 13.   Wilson's disease, or hepatolenticular degeneration, results in an excess copper buildup in the body.   It primarily affects the liver and basal ganglia of the brain.   Liver-related symptoms include vomiting, weakness, ascites, swelling of the legs, yellowish skin, and itchiness.   Neurological symptoms include tremors, muscle stiffness, trouble speaking, personality changes, anxiety, and auditory or visual hallucinations. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.question: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma, except:

options.A: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
options.B: Carcinoma of body pancreas often present with jaundice

questions.solution: Correct Option B - Carcinoma of body pancreas often present with jaundice:   Carcinomas of the body and tail of the pancreas often do not present with jaundice because they are not located near the common bile duct.   Jaundice is more commonly associated with tumors located in the head of the pancreas, where they can obstruct the common bile duct and lead to the accumulation of bilirubin in the bloodstream.   In contrast, tumors in the body of the pancreas may cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, weight loss, and digestive issues but are less likely to cause jaundice. Incorrect Options: Option A - Cigarette smoking is a risk factor:   Cigarette smoking is a well-established risk factor for pancreatic carcinoma.   It is one of the most significant environmental risk factors for developing pancreatic cancer, increasing the likelihood of developing the disease. Option C - They elicit intense desmoplastic response:   Pancreatic carcinoma is known for its intense desmoplastic response.   The tumor microenvironment in pancreatic cancer is characterized by the proliferation of fibrous connective tissue, which creates a dense stromal reaction around the tumor cells.   This desmoplastic response contributes to the poor prognosis and therapeutic challenges associated with pancreatic carcinoma. Option D - Perineural invasion is common:   Perineural invasion is a common feature of pancreatic carcinoma.   The tumor cells have a propensity to invade and infiltrate along the nerves in the vicinity of the pancreas, which can contribute to the spread and metastasis of the disease.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is true?

questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: B) The GBM is a selective barrier between the glomerular capillaries and Bowman's capsule. questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of severe lower abdominal pain, dysuria, and hematuria. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Urinalysis reveals a high pH of 8.5 and the presence of white blood cells. Microscopic examination of the urine sediment shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's current presentation?
questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: C)Infection with urease-producing bacteria EXPLANATION:   Triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones, are composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate.   They typically form in alkaline urine due to urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria.   These bacteria hydrolyse urea into ammonia, increasing urine pH and facilitating stone formation.   Struvite stones are characterised by their "coffin lid" appearance under a microscope.   They can grow rapidly and fill the renal pelvis, leading to complications like infection and obstruction.

Muddy brown casts will be seen in this condition. Muddy brown casts:   They are often seen in patients with ethylene glycol poisoning, leading to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). questions.question: All of the following are true about medullary sponge kidney except:

options.A: It is more common in adults.

options.C: It often presents with recurrent urinary tract infections.
options.D: Cysts are lined by cuboidal epithelium.

questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: C)It often presents with recurrent urinary tract infections. EXPLANATION: Medullary Sponge Kidney (MSK) often presents with recurrent urinary tract infections is incorrect because recurrent UTIs are not a defining feature of the condition. While patients with MSK may experience urinary tract infections, it is not a characteristic or common presentation of the disease. Medullary Sponge Kidney:   The term medullary sponge kidney is restricted to multiple cystic dilations of the collecting ducts in the medulla.   The condition occurs in adults and is usually discovered radiographically. (Option A).   Renal function is usually normal.   On gross inspection, the papillary ducts in the medulla are dilated (Option B) and small cysts may be present.   The cysts are lined by cuboidal epithelium or occasionally by transitional epithelium. questions.question: A 12-year-old male child presents to the clinic with a history of progressive hearing loss, blurred vision, and recurrent episodes of hematuria over the past few months.Electron microscopy reveals the ‘basketweave’ appearance of GBM. Which of the following morphological findings is responsible for this appearance?

options.B: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with subepithelial electron-dense
options.C: Irregular thickening, thinning, and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane
options.D: Mesangial expansion with GBM thickening and eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Irregular thickening, thinning, and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane Explanation: The clinical presentation and EM findings of the characteristic basket-weave appearance of GBM suggest Alport syndrome arises due to mutations affecting type IV collagen, resulting in hematuria progressing to chronic renal insufficiency.   It presents alongside sensorineural hearing impairment and various ocular manifestations, including lens subluxation, posterior subcapsular cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.   Histologically, Alport syndrome shows distinct electron microscopic features: GBM exhibits irregular areas of thickening interspersed with thinning. Splitting and layering of the lamina densa (basket-weave appearance of GBM)   GBM exhibits irregular areas of thickening interspersed with thinning.   Splitting and layering of the lamina densa (basket-weave appearance of GBM)   GBM exhibits irregular areas of thickening interspersed with thinning.   Splitting and layering of the lamina densa (basket-weave appearance of GBM) Effacement of podocyte foot processes (Option A) Effacement of podocytes is characteristically seen in Minimal change disease, not the Alport syndrome. Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with subepithelial electron-dense deposits (Option B) Membranous nephropathy shows the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane without hypercellularity on light microscopy, while electron microscopy shows the ‘spike and dome’ appearance of subepithelial deposits. Mesangial expansion with GBM thickening and eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis (Option D) Diabetic glomerulonephropathy shows mesangial expansion with GBM thickening and eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions)

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with worsening kidney function. Upon examination, renal biopsy reveals glomerular changes consistent with diabetic nephropathy. Which histological findings would be least likely to be observed in the glomeruli of this patient's kidney biopsy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Armani-Ebstein lesion Explanation: In uncontrolled diabetes, glucosuria causes glycogen accumulation in the proximal tubular cells (not in the glomerulus), known as Armanni-Ebstein cells. This pathological finding is more commonly associated with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) than with diabetic nephropathy. Incorrect options explanation Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodule (Option A) Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules (aka Nodular glomerulosclerosis) are a hallmark of diabetic nephropathy. They are ovoid or spherical, PAS-positive nodules found in the mesangial core of glomeruli. They are often accompanied by mesangiolysis and sometimes surrounded by dilated capillary loops. Diffuse glomerulosclerosis (Option B) Diffuse glomerulosclerosis refers to a diffuse increase in the mesangial matrix and thickening of GBM. It correlates with deteriorating renal function and increasing proteinuria.   This is the most common histopathological finding of diabetic nephropathy. Arteriolar hyalinosis (Option C)   Arteriolar hyalinosis involves the accumulation of hyaline material in the walls of both afferent and efferent arterioles, contributing to ischemia and kidney damage in diabetes.   Hyaline material accumulated in capillary loops is known as “fibrin caps” in Bowman’s capsule, it is called “capsular drops.”

questions.question: A 32-year-old female presents with a history of joint pain, skin rash, and recent onset of shortness of breath. Lab investigations reveal elevated anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies and low complement levels. A kidney biopsy shows >50% involvement of glomeruli with wire loop lesions on light microscopy. Which type of lupus nephritis is most likely observed in the biopsy findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Class IV Explanation: Based on the clinical scenario and lab results, the patient likely has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with renal involvement. The kidney biopsy revealing >50% glomerular involvement with wire loop lesions indicates class IV lupus nephritis, the most common and severe form. Classification of Lupus Nephritis (LN): Class I Minimal Mesangial LN Class II Mesangial proliferative LN Class III (Option A) Focal LN (<50% glomeruli) Class IV Diffuse LN (>50% glomeruli) Class V (Option C) Membranous LN Class VI (Option D) Advanced Sclerosing LN Light microscopy: Subendothelial immune complex deposits can result in the circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, leading to the formation of "wire loop" structures, which are observed in Class III, IV (maximum) and V. Electron microscopy: Thumbprint/ fingerprint sign (alternating areas of electron-dense deposits and lucent regions in GBM, indicating immune complex deposition) Immunofluorescence: Full House Effect (IgG, IgA, IgM, C1, C3 get deposited in the kidney)

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with generalised oedema and frothy urine. Laboratory investigations reveal significant proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. A kidney biopsy reveals diffuse thickening of GBM, a spike and dome pattern on the silver stain and subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Mutation in PLA2R Explanation: The clinical presentation, along with the histological findings of diffuse thickening of GBM, a spike and dome pattern on the silver stain, and subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy, suggest Membranous nephropathy, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in elderly patients.   In primary membranous nephropathy, antibodies primarily target the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) located on the basal surface of podocytes. This triggers complement activation and subepithelial immune complex deposition, resembling Heymann nephritis lesions.   Other less common target antigens include THSD7A and neutral endopeptidase (CD10).   The presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies is crucial for diagnosing the disease.

questions.question: Which genetic mutation is responsible for a syndrome of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome of childhood onset?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) NPHS2 Explanation: The above clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, which is defined as the absence of remission despite 4 weeks of therapy with daily prednisone at a dose of 2 mg/kg/d.   Mutations in the NPHS2 gene lead to this syndrome, typically manifesting in childhood.   The NPHS2 gene is located on chromosome 1q25–q31.   The NPHS2 gene encodes the protein product known as podocin which is localised to the slit diaphragm within the kidney.   Patients typically present from birth to 6 years of age have a steroid-resistant course and reach End-stage Renal Disease (ESRD) before the end of their first decade. NPHS1 (Option A) NPHS1 mutations are associated with congenital nephrotic syndrome of the Finnish type. α-actinin 4 (Option C) Mutations in the gene encoding the podocyte actin-binding protein α-actinin 4 (ACTN4) underlie some cases of autosomal dominant focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which tends to have a high rate of progression to renal insufficiency. TRPC6 (Option D) Mutations in the TRPC6 gene, which encodes a calcium-permeable ion channel in podocytes, have been identified in some cases of familial FSGS. However, TRPC6 mutations are not typically linked to childhood-onset steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with swelling around his eyes, ankles, and abdomen, along with frothy urine. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, elevated serum creatinine, and BUN levels. Image of renal biopsy is given below. Which of the following is not an established cause of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Diabetes mellitus Explanation: Based on the given clinical scenario and HPE image (segmental sclerosis, glomerular hyalinosis, and tubular atrophy, with negative immunofluorescence), the most likely diagnosis is Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Diabetes mellitus primarily causes diabetic nephropathy, characterised by diffuse glomerulosclerosis rather than the focal and segmental pattern seen in FSGS. Causes of FSGS: 1. Primary (Idiopathic) FSGS. 2. Secondary FSGS: Mnemonic- H3R3S1   Hypertension (Option C)   HIV associated nephropathy (Option B)   Heroine drug abuse   Reflux nephropathy   Renal tissue loss   Sickle cell anaemia (Option D) 3. Inherited forms:   Genetic mutations affecting slit diaphragm proteins like nephrin, podocin, α-actinin 4, and TRPC6.

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy presents with sudden generalised oedema and frothy urine. Urinalysis reveals heavy proteinuria without hematuria. Renal biopsy widespread effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

options.A: Lipid deposition within glomerular capillaries (tubular cells)
options.B: Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular deposition of IgG and C3 in the

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Good response to corticosteroid therapy Explanation:   The clinical and electron microscope findings suggest the diagnosis as Minimal Change Disease (MCD), characterised by diffuse effacement of foot processes of podocytes in glomeruli. It primarily affects children aged 2-6 years.   MCD typically responds rapidly to corticosteroid therapy, especially in children (>90%), leading to complete remission of proteinuria and resolution of symptoms. Lipid deposition within glomerular capillaries (Option A) Lipid deposition within glomerular capillaries is not observed in MCD. Instead, protein and lipid deposition may occur in the proximal tubules due to tubular reabsorption of lipoproteins passing through diseased glomeruli, leading to the historical term "lipoid nephrosis" for this disease. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular deposition of IgG and C3 in the glomeruli (Option B)   Immunofluorescence studies in MCD typically show no significant immune complex deposition or granular staining patterns.   This distinguishes MCD from immune complex-mediated glomerular diseases like IgA nephropathy or lupus nephritis, where IgG and C3 deposits are commonly observed. Non-selective proteinuria (Option D) Minimal Change Disease (MCD) typically presents with highly selective proteinuria, mostly albumin. Renal function remains good despite massive proteinuria, with no hypertension or hematuria commonly.

questions.question: A 7-year-old girl with a recent upper respiratory tract infection presents with generalised swelling and reduced urine output. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria without blood cells or casts. Electron microscopy findings show flattening, retraction, and swelling of podocytes. Which light microscopy findings is characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Normal glomeruli Explanation: The above clinical presentation and EM finding of podocyte effacement is characteristic of Minimal change disease.   It is marked by the widespread flattening of podocytes, seen only on electron microscopy, while light microscopy shows normal glomeruli with lipids in proximal tubules.   This alteration in podocyte structure leads to increased permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier, resulting in the loss of large amounts of protein in the urine. Glomerulosclerosis (Option A)   Observed in diabetic nephropathy.   Diffuse glomerulosclerosis Diffuse glomerulosclerosis Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis Fibrinoid necrosis in the glomeruli (Option C) Vasculitis or immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis. Wire looping of capillaries (Option D)   Wire looping of capillaries is seen in diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, often due to SLE (lupus nephritis).

questions.question: A 36-year-old woman presents with intermittent flank pain and occasional gross hematuria. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests show normal renal function. A renal biopsy of a mass lesion reveals a mixture of mature adipose tissue, thick-walled blood vessels, and bundles of smooth muscle cells. All are true regarding this condition except?

options.A: It is commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis.
options.B: It is more prevalent in males than females.
options.C: It is mostly a benign tumor.
options.D: It has a high susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage.

questions.solution: CORRECT ANSWER: B)It is more prevalent in males than females. (Option C)   It is most often detected incidentally and has a female preponderance. (Option B)   They are present in 25% to 50% of patients with tuberous sclerosis. (Option A)   It has a high susceptibility for bleeding (can present as loin pain).   Morphology: Histology: Circular blood vessels, muscles, and fat; perivascular epithelioid cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm and mitotic figures.

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of blurred vision, hearing loss, and recurrent episodes of hematuria. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in Type 4 collagen. Which of the following genetic mutations is observed in the patient?
questions.solution: Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: Mutations in COL4A3, COL4A4, COL4A5 genes are seen in Alport syndrome.   Alport syndrome is caused by defective COL4A3, COL4A4, and COL4A5 genes, which lead to impaired production and deposition of the Type 4 collagen α345 chain network in the basement membranes of the glomerulus, cochlea, and eyes.   It is predominantly inherited as an X-linked dominant trait.   It has a triad of symptoms. Blurred vision due to Anterior lenticonus, lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy. Recurrent hematuria can lead to renal failure. Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.   Blurred vision due to Anterior lenticonus, lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.   Recurrent hematuria can lead to renal failure.   Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.   Blurred vision due to Anterior lenticonus, lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.   Recurrent hematuria can lead to renal failure.   Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents with painless hematuria post-upper respiratory infections, normal vital signs, and no oedema. Urinalysis reveals red blood cell casts and further investigation shows elevated serum creatinine and mild proteinuria. Renal biopsy confirms glomerulonephritis. What is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in this case?
questions.solution: Answer: A) IgA nephropathy Explanation: IgA nephropathy, or Berger’s disease, is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in adults and worldwide.   It presents with gross hematuria in adults, usually 2-3 days after an upper respiratory infection.   It can progress to acute renal failure, causing ankle oedema, facial puffiness, and hypertension.   It occurs due to the formation of aberrant IgA molecules that deposit in the mesangial regions. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option B)   It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in children and presents with fever, oliguria, hypertension, periorbital oedema, and hematuria.   It usually occurs 1 to 2 weeks after recovery from an upper respiratory infection, which causes an inflammatory response (type III hypersensitivity reaction). Minimal change disease (Option C)   It is the most common type of nephrotic syndrome in children.   It presents with massive proteinuria(>3.5g/24hrs) due to immunological damage to epithelial cells. Membranous nephropathy (Option D)   It is the most common type of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly.   It is immune complex-mediated and can be caused by malignancy(colon, lung, melanoma), infections(malaria, hepatitis B, C, syphilis, schistosomiasis), drugs(gold, penicillamine), or autoimmune conditions(SLE).

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent hematuria following upper respiratory infections and intermittent proteinuria. Renal biopsy shows mesangial IgA deposits on immunofluorescence and electron-dense deposits in the mesangium on electron microscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Answer: A) Berger’s Disease Explanation: The clinical and histopathological findings suggest the diagnosis of Berger’s disease or IgA nephropathy, characterised by the deposition of IgA antibodies in the mesangial regions of the glomeruli, leading to recurrent episodes of hematuria.   Electron microscopy reveals electron-dense deposits predominantly localised in the mesangium.   The characteristic immunofluorescent picture shows mesangial deposition of IgA, often with C3 and properdin and lesser amounts of IgG or IgM. Alport syndrome (Option B)   It is a genetic disorder characterised by abnormalities in type IV collagen, leading to progressive kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities.   Electron microscopy reveals irregular thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with lamellation and splitting. Membranous nephropathy (Option C) It is caused by the deposition of immune complexes (primarily IgG and C3) on the outer (subepithelial) side of the glomerular basement membrane. Buerger's Disease (Option D)   It is also called Thromboangiitis obliterans, it is a vascular disease causing extremity ischemia and is unrelated to renal involvement or immune deposits in the kidney.   It does not present with hematuria or proteinuria.

questions.solution: Answer: A) >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic. questions.question: A 65-year-old diabetic male presented to the hospital complaining of chronic abdominal discomfort and unexplained weight loss over the past few months. A palpable firm mass was detected on the left upper quadrant upon physical examination. Ultrasound revealed a large mass in the left upper pole of the kidney. Due to suspicion of renal malignancy, the patient underwent a left nephrectomy. Based on the specimen obtained, what is the most likely diagnosis? {{caption_text}}
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Renal oncocytoma Explanation: Renal Oncocytoma:   It is most commonly seen in > 50-year-old adults.   It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts.   Gross appearance:Tan or mahogany brown, with a central scar.   Microscopy: Composed of pink eosinophilic cells with small, round, benign-appearing nuclei.   Electron microscope: Numerous mitochondria (granular appearance) Epithelioid angiomyolipoma (Option B) is a rare variant of angiomyolipoma composed of smooth muscle cells, fat, and blood vessels, and it often occurs in patients with tuberous sclerosis. However, the gross appearance of the specimen, without fat and showing a well-circumscribed mass, is more consistent with renal oncocytoma. Clear cell carcinoma (Option C) would typically present with more aggressive features like hematuria, anemia, and vascular invasion. This patient's presentation along with a well-circumscribed mass is more typical of a benign tumor. Urothelial carcinoma (Option D) is unlikely because the mass is located in the renal parenchyma, and in urothelial carcinoma it is typically found in the renal pelvis or ureter, often with associated hematuria.

questions.question: A middle-aged male patient has proteinuria. Looking at the immunofluorescence image below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Lupus Nephritis:   Lupus nephritis is a kidney inflammation that occurs as a result of SLE.   The immunofluorescence findings in lupus nephritis demonstrate a variety of patterns, including the presence of a "full house" pattern.   This pattern shows granular deposits of IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, and C1q throughout the glomeruli.   The "full house" pattern indicates the deposition of immune complexes containing multiple types of antibodies and complement components. questions.question: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other than nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Fabry’s disease:   Fabry's disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency or dysfunction of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A.   This leads to the accumulation of a lipid called globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) within various cells and tissues, including the kidneys.   One of the characteristic findings in the urinalysis of patients with Fabry's disease is the presence of Maltese cross casts, also known as "corneal-shaped" or "glycolipid" casts.   These casts are formed by the precipitation of Gb3 within the renal tubules. They appear as refractile, yellowish-brown structures with a cross-like pattern when viewed under polarized light. Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and C are not associated with the presence of Maltese cross crystals in the urine.

These are pathognomonic lesions seen in the kidneys of patients with diabetic nephropathy.   They are characterized by the presence of nodular mesangial expansion, thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, and hyaline deposits.   These changes are indicative of advanced diabetic nephropathy and are associated with the development of proteinuria and progressive renal dysfunction. questions.question: What type of urinary casts would you expect in a patient diagnosed with Fabry’s disease?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Maltese Cross Cast:   Fabry's disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency or dysfunction of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A.   This leads to the accumulation of a lipid called globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) within various cells and tissues, including the kidneys.   One of the characteristic findings in the urinalysis of patients with Fabry's disease is the presence of Maltese cross casts, also known as "corneal-shaped" or "glycolipid" casts.   These casts are formed by the precipitation of Gb3 within the renal tubules. They appear as refractile, yellowish-brown structures with a cross-like pattern when viewed under polarized light. Incorrect Options: Option A - Waxy cast:   Waxy casts are broad, homogeneous casts that indicate chronic renal disease.   They are composed of degenerated renal tubular epithelial cells and are often associated with severe proteinuria.   While kidney involvement is a feature of Fabry's disease, the presence of waxy casts is not specific to this condition. Option B - RBC cast:   RBC casts are cylindrical structures formed by the entrapment of red blood cells within the renal tubules.   They are typically seen in glomerulonephritis, vasculitis, or other conditions causing hematuria.   While kidney involvement in Fabry's disease may lead to hematuria, RBC casts are not specific to this condition. Option C - WBC cast:   WBC casts are formed by the entrapment of white blood cells within the renal tubules.   They are usually seen in urinary tract infections or interstitial nephritis.   Although kidney involvement in Fabry's disease may lead to inflammation, the presence of WBC casts is not specific to this condition.

questions.question: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is:
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Painless hematuria:   Painless hematuria is the most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma.   Hematuria refers to the presence of blood in the urine, and when it occurs without pain, it is often associated with bladder carcinoma.   Painless hematuria may occur intermittently or be persistent, and it is an important warning sign that should prompt further evaluation for bladder cancer. questions.question: A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with solid cancer of the bowel. He also experienced massive proteinuria a few months after the initial diagnosis of cancer. What do you think is the likely cause of the development of urinary findings?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Membranous nephropathy:   Membranous nephropathy is a glomerular disease characterized by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane.   It is commonly associated with solid tumors, including cancer of the bowel.   The immune complexes formed in the presence of cancer can deposit in the glomerular basement membrane, leading to proteinuria. Incorrect Options: Option B - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis:   Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by scarring and sclerosis of the glomeruli.   While FSGS can occur in the setting of cancer, it is not commonly associated with solid cancer of the bowel. Option C - Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis:   Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and proliferation of cells within the glomeruli.   MPGN is not associated with solid cancer of the bowel. Option D - Dense deposit disease:   Dense deposit disease, also known as C3 glomerulopathy, is characterized by the abnormal accumulation of complement component C3 within the glomeruli.   Dense deposit disease is not associated with solid cancer of the bowel.

questions.question: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Minimal change disease:   Effacement of podocyte foot processes refers to the flattening or loss of the foot processes of podocytes, which are specialized cells in the glomerulus of the kidney.   This structural alteration is a characteristic finding in minimal change disease, also known as minimal change nephrotic syndrome.   Minimal change disease is a type of nephrotic syndrome characterized by massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and lipiduria.   In minimal change disease, the glomeruli appear normal under light microscopy, and the characteristic findings are only visible under electron microscopy, i.e., effacement of podocyte foot processes. Incorrect Options:   Effacement of podocyte foot processes is not seen in Options A, C, and D.

questions.question: A 51-year-old male patient came with complaints of hematuria to the clinic. On examination, he was normotensive and had pedal edema. questions.solution: Correct Option B - Anti-GBM antibodies:   Crescents on renal biopsy indicate glomerular involvement and suggest the possibility of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).   The most relevant test to perform is the detection of anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies.   Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies are specific markers for Goodpasture syndrome, a rare autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies targeting the glomerular basement membrane and lung alveolar basement membrane. Incorrect Options: Option A - ANA:   Antinuclear antibodies are associated with systemic autoimmune conditions, such as systemic lupus erythematosus.   While SLE can involve the kidneys and cause glomerulonephritis, it is not the most likely cause, and the presence of crescents suggests a more acute and rapidly progressive disease. Option C - HIV RNA:   Human immunodeficiency virus infection can cause renal complications, including HIV-associated nephropathy.   The patient's presentation of hematuria, pedal edema, and the presence of crescents on renal biopsy make Goodpasture syndrome a more likely diagnosis than HIV-associated nephropathy. Option D - Urine immunoelectrophoresis: Urine immunoelectrophoresis is a useful test in evaluating various renal diseases, including the detection of monoclonal immunoglobulins in conditions such as multiple myeloma and amyloidosis.

questions.question: Tamm-Horsfall protein is a major component of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Renal casts:   Tamm-Horsfall protein is synthesized by the ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidney.   It is found in abundance in urine. questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with increased frequency, nocturia, and a weak urine stream. Digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged prostate with a palpable nodule. A prostate biopsy is performed, and histological examination is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct answer: B) Prostate Adenocarcinoma The case scenario describes a 60-year-old male with urinary symptoms and a palpable nodule on digital rectal examination, suggestive of prostate pathology. The histological features as seen include prominent nucleoli, perineural invasion, and an infiltrative growth pattern, which are characteristic of prostate adenocarcinoma. Features of Prostate Cancer:   Prostate cancer cells form irregular glandular structures that may vary in size and shape.   Glands may be crowded and back-to-back, lacking the normal orderly appearance seen in benign glands.   Cells exhibit enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli.   Perineural invasion is a common feature of prostate cancer and may indicate a higher risk of disease progression.   Cancer cells infiltrate the surrounding tissues in an irregular, invasive manner.   Immunohistochemical staining can be used to identify specific markers associated with prostate cancer, such as prostate-specific antigen (PSA), prostate-specific acid phosphatase (PSAP), androgen receptor (AR), and cytokeratins.

Condyloma acuminata are cauliflower-like, dry, and bulky, typically found in the squamous mucosa of the anal canal.   Condyloma lata are smooth, moist, and flat, often located in the genital area, inner thighs, axillae, or oral mucosa.   Unlike condyloma acuminata, condyloma lata may appear ulcerated.   Microscopic examination reveals papillary, exophytic, treelike stromal cores covered by thickened squamous epithelium.   Koilocytes are evident, featuring enlarged nuclei, hyperchromasia, and a perinuclear cytoplasmic halo.   These are not precancerous lesions, and HPV vaccines provide excellent protection. HPV 16 and 18 (Option B): HPV 16 and 18 are high-risk strains responsible for cervical carcinoma, vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) and vulvar carcinoma.

questions.question: A 25-year-old sexually active female presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge and dysuria. Upon examination of the cervix, the following appearance is noted. questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Trichomonas vaginalis Explanation: The clinical presentation, examination, and microscopy findings suggest Trichomonas vaginalis infection, a large, flagellated ovoid protozoan transmitted by sexual contact.   Patients may present with yellow, frothy vaginal discharge, vulvovaginal discomfort, dysuria (painful urination) dyspareunia (painful intercourse).   The vaginal and cervical mucosa has a fiery-red appearance, with dilation of cervical mucosal vessels resulting in a “strawberry cervix.”   Wet mount microscopy of the discharge reveals motile organisms with flagella. Candida (Option B):   Clinical features: Curdy white discharge   Pap smear: shish kebab effect Herpes simplex virus (Option C)   HSV is a sexually transmitted disease characterized by multinucleated squamous cells containing eosinophilic viral inclusions (Cowdry type A inclusions) with a “ground-glass” appearance.   The patient presents with painful purulent vesicles/ulcers, often associated with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and tender inguinal lymph nodes.   Clinical features: Painful vesicles.   Microscopy: squamous cell nuclei exhibit 3Ms : Multinucleation, molding and margination Human Papillomavirus (Option D)   Clinical features: Low risk HPV 6,11 → cause condyloma acuminata.   Microscopy; Koilocytes are seen.   High risk HPV 16, 18 → cause squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.question: A 58-year-old woman complains of persistent itching and redness in her vulvar area. On examination, well-defined, erythematous plaques with an eczematous appearance are noted. A biopsy reveals large cells with pale cytoplasm and positive staining for mucopolysaccharides. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for cytokeratin 7. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Extramammary Paget's disease Explanation:   Biopsy findings commonly reveal large, round cells, known as Paget cells, within the epidermis.   These cells have pale cytoplasm containing mucopolysaccharide that stains with PAS, Alcian blue, or mucicarmine stains.   Immunohistochemistry staining often shows positivity for cytokeratin (CK) 7.   Unlike Paget disease of the nipple (Ductal carcinoma of the breast), vulvar Paget's disease is typically not associated with underlying malignancy and is confined to the vulvar epidermis.

questions.question: Which of the following has a strong association with clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina?

options.A: Male partner who has multiple sexual partners
options.D: Sexual activity at a young age

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) In utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol Explanation:   The clinical presentation and biopsy findings suggest Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina, characterized histologically by cells with clear cytoplasm and hobnail cells and is strongly associated with in-utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES).   Vaginal adenosis (precursor lesion for clear cell adenocarcinoma) refers to the presence of glandular columnar epithelium in the proximal vagina.   Diethylstilbestrol is a synthetic non-steroidal estrogen that was historically widely used to prevent potential miscarriages by stimulating the synthesis of estrogen and progesterone in the placenta (especially from the 1940s to the 1970s).

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of vaginal bleeding and a visible mass protruding from her vagina. options.A: Cells with small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end
options.B: Marked atypia of cells with numerous keratin pearls
options.D: Fibrous stroma covered by mucus-secreting endocervical glands

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Cells with small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end. Explanation: The clinical presentation and IHC findings suggest Sarcoma botryoides, a rare type of Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, characterised by polypoid,rounded, bulky masses that have the appearance and consistency of grapelike clusters, commonly found in infants and children younger than 5 years of age.   Histologically characterised by cells with small and oval nuclei with small protrusions of cytoplasm resembling a tennis racket (Tennis racket cells/ Tadpole cells) and rarely cytosolic striations (indicative of muscle differentiation) can be seen.   The "cambium layer" in sarcoma botryoides refers to a band of undifferentiated or slightly differentiated tumour cells beneath the surface epithelium.   Its presence aids in diagnosing sarcoma botryoides and distinguishing it from other vaginal tumours.   Immunohistochemical staining is positive for Desmin/MyoD1.   It tends to invade locally and cause death by penetration into the peritoneal cavity obstruction of the urinary tract.
