options.D: Patient A: β-thalassemia major, Patient B: α-thalassemia, Patient C: β-thalassemia

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Patient A: β-thalassemia major, Patient B: β-thalassemia minor, Patient C: α -thalassemia Explanation: The peripheral smear findings can help distinguish between different types of thalassemia:   β-thalassemia major (Patient A): This condition is characterized by severe anemia. The peripheral smear typically shows significant abnormalities, including target cells, nucleated red blood cells (NRBCs), microcytosis, hypochromia, and anisopoikilocytosis. These findingsare consistent with the severe hemolytic anemia and ineffective erythropoiesis seen in β-thalassemia major.   β-thalassemia minor (Patient B): This condition usually presents with mild anemia. The peripheral smear shows microcytosis and hypochromia but generally lacks significant numbers of NRBCs.   α-thalassemia (Patient C): This condition can vary in severity. The peripheral smear of a patient with α-thalassemia trait may show mild anemia, microcytosis, and hypochromia. In cases of HbH disease (a form of α-thalassemia), the smear can also show NRBCs and hemoglobin H inclusions (golf ball cells), which are not seen in β-thalassemia minor.

questions.question: The medical team, aware of the prevalence of genetic disorders in the village decides to implement a screening process using NESTROFT for beta thalassemia. They plan to test the result by observing the solution turning clear by checking the visibility of a black line behind the test and control tubes. Which of the following on Nestrof test would be indicative of a positive result?

options.A: Black line visible in both tubes
options.B: Black line visible in only control tubes
options.C: Black line visible in only test tubes
options.D: No black line visible in any of the tubes

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) A black line visible only in the test tube containing blood sample mixed with a 0.36 buffered solution is suggestive of a positive Nestrof test. Explanation: The Nestrof test, also known as the Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test, is a screening test used to identify carriers of beta thalassemia and sickle cell anemia. The test is based on the principle that red blood cells (RBCs) from individuals with beta thalassemia are resistant to hemolysis in hypotonic solutions compared to normal RBCs. Procedure:   Bloood sample is mixed with 0.36% saline solution   After incubation, observe the test tube against a black line.   Look for the presence or absence of a black line behind the tube. Interpretation:   Positive Test: Black line visible in only test tubes A positive NESTROFT indicates that all red cells in the tested sample have not undergone lysis in 0.36% buffered saline. These unlysed red cells result in the hazy appearance of the contents of the tube and render the line on the paper indistinct. Thus a positive NESTROFT indicates decreased red cell osmotic fragility and increased resistance to osmotic lysis.   Black line visible in only test tubes   A positive NESTROFT indicates that all red cells in the tested sample have not undergone lysis in 0.36% buffered saline. These unlysed red cells result in the hazy appearance of the contents of the tube and render the line on the paper indistinct. Thus a positive NESTROFT indicates decreased red cell osmotic fragility and increased resistance to osmotic lysis.   Negative Test (Normal Result): No black line visible in any of the test tubes This indicates that the RBCs have remained intact in control as well as test tube.   No black line visible in any of the test tubes   This indicates that the RBCs have remained intact in control as well as test tube.   Black line visible in only test tubes   A positive NESTROFT indicates that all red cells in the tested sample have not undergone lysis in 0.36% buffered saline. These unlysed red cells result in the hazy appearance of the contents of the tube and render the line on the paper indistinct. Thus a positive NESTROFT indicates decreased red cell osmotic fragility and increased resistance to osmotic lysis.   No black line visible in any of the test tubes   This indicates that the RBCs have remained intact in control as well as test tube.

Heterozygous patients (HbAS) are said to have sickle cell trait where about 40% of the hemoglobin is HbS and the rest is HbA, which interferes with HbS polymerization.   Therefore they have less severe disease than their homozygous counterparts who have more HbS.   HbF inhibits HbS polymerization more effectively than HbA, keeping infants with sickle cell disease asymptomatic until 5-6 months when HbF levels decline.   Metabolically active intracellular parasites consume oxygen and decrease intracellular pH, promoting sickling of HbAS red cells, which are then rapidly cleared by splenic and hepatic phagocytes, reducing parasite loads.   In individuals with coexistent α-thalassemia, reduced Hb synthesis results in milder disease.

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly describes the principle of Prussian blue stain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Ferrocyanide to ferroferric cyanide Explanation:   The Prussian blue stain is a histological stain used primarily to detect ferric iron (Fe³■) in tissues, cells, and blood smears.   It works based on the reaction of potassium ferrocyanide with ferric ions to form an insoluble blue compound called Prussian blue (ferroferric cyanide) which stains blue and is insoluble in water. The reaction can be summarized as follows: Fe3+ + Fe2+ (Ferrocyanide) ➡ Fe3(Fe(CN)6)2   Therefore, when tissues or cells are stained with Prussian blue, ferric iron deposits appear blue under microscopy, aiding in the detection and localization of iron in biological specimens. Note: Lillie’s stain is used for ferrous (Fe2+) detection.

questions.solution: Correct answer: B) Ancylostoma Explanation: The clinical presentation (fatigue, pallor, and pica) and laboratory findings (microcytic anaemia, and low serum ferritin levels) in this patient point towards iron deficiency anaemia. questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) MCH Explanation: The least useful investigation in determining the underlying cause of anemia is MCH (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin).   MCH measures the average amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell.   MCH can be valuable when used together with MCV to refine the classification of anemia but it does not independently yield as much diagnostic information regarding the underlying causes of anemia as other tests MCV (Option A) categorizes anemia by measuring the red blood cell size: microcytic (<80 fL), normocytic (80-100 fL), and macrocytic (>100 fL), aiding in identifying underlying causes such as iron deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency. Peripheral smear (Option C) is used to assess the morphology of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, crucial in identifying abnormalities such as hypochromia, microcytosis, or macrocytosis,. Reticulocyte count (Option D) measures the percentage of reticulocytes in the blood and can indicate the bone marrow's response to anemia. It helps differentiate between causes of anemia related to decreased production or increased destruction or loss of red blood cells.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Increase in serum iron level Explanation: One of the earliest responses to the correction of iron deficiency anemia is increase in serum iron. questions.question: A 28-year-old female presented with easy fatigability and dyspnea on exertion. She was found to have a hemoglobin of 6 g/dL. What will be most likely finding in the peripheral blood smear of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Microcytic and hypochromic red cells Explanation: Microcytosis (smaller than normal red cells) and hypochromia are classic findings in iron deficiency anemia, which is consistent with the patient's symptoms and low hemoglobin. In iron deficiency anemia (IDA), a peripheral blood smear can reveal characteristic changes.   Hypochromic Red Blood Cells: The RBCs appear pale due to decreased hemoglobin content.   Microcytic Red Blood Cells: RBCs are smaller than normal due to decreased hemoglobin synthesis.   Anisocytosis: There is significant variation in the size of RBCs.   Poikilocytosis: RBCs may show abnormal shapes, such as pencil cells, target cells (codocytes), and occasionally, elliptocytes. Macrocytic red cells (Option A): Macrocytosis typically indicates a deficiency in vitamin B12 or folate, not iron. Cabot rings (Option B): Appear as thin, thread-like structures that form a loop or figure-eight shape within RBCs. It is composed of remnants of the nuclear material remnants from erythroblasts or megakaryocytes. Associated with megaloblastic anemia. Hypersegmented neutrophils (Option C): These have more than 5 lobes in their nucleus. This condition is often associated with vitamin B12 deficiency or folate deficiency.

questions.question: A 32-year-old female diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia is prescribed oral iron supplements. Foods containing which of the following can she take to increase iron absorption?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Ascorbate Explanation: Ascorbate (Vitamin C) enhances the absorption of non-heme iron (the type of iron found in plant-based foods and supplements) by reducing ferric iron (Fe³ ■) to the more soluble ferrous form (Fe²■), which is more readily absorbed in the duodenum. questions.question: In a patient diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia, the values of all of the following increase except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Transferrin saturation Explanation: Transferrin saturation decreases in iron deficiency anemia. It is the serum iron to TIBC ratio and reflects the percentage of transferrin saturated with iron. In iron deficiency, less iron is available for binding to transferrin, leading to a decreased saturation. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) (Option A) is increased in iron deficiency anemia. It represents the maximum amount of iron that can be bound to transferrin. RBC protoporphyrin (Option B) is a precursor to heme, and in the absence of sufficient iron, protoporphyrin accumulates. Transferrin receptor (TfR) (Option D) expression on cells increases to enhance cellular uptake of iron when iron stores are low.

questions.question: A 10-year-old girl presented with fatigue and weakness. Her laboratory results show reduced hemoglobin, MCV 75 fl, MCH 22 pg and RDW 28. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Iron deficiency anemia Explanation:   The given clinical presentation and investigation points towards the diagnosis of Iron deficiency anemiaIron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic (low MCV) and hypochromic (low MCH) red blood cells.   The elevated RDW suggests a wide variation in red blood cell sizes, which is characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.   Iron deficiency anemia can result from dietary lack, impaired absorption, increased iron requirement (e.g., during pregnancy), or chronic blood loss (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding).   Clinical features include Koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic glossitis, and esophageal webs, pica and intestinal malabsorption, affecting overall nutritional status Megaloblastic anemia (Option B) usually presents with macrocytic anemia due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. Sideroblastic anemia (Option C) can also present with microcytosis, but it is usually associated with ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow and may show elevated iron indices.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following is true about the intracellular regulation of iron in the above condition? IRP- Iron regulatory protein IRE- Iron response elements

options.A: Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE.
options.B: Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE.
options.C: Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE.
options.D: Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE. Explanation: In iron deficiency anemia, ferritin translation is decreased by binding iron regulatory protein to iron response elements. Iron regulatory mechanism:   IRP: Binds to IREs in specific mRNAs' untranslated regions (UTRs) to control the translation of proteins involved in iron metabolism.   IRE: These are sequences found in the mRNAs of proteins involved in iron metabolism, such as ferritin and transferrin receptor 1   Ferritin: Ferritin stores iron inside cells. When iron levels are low, IRPs bind to IREs in the 5' UTR of ferritin mRNA, preventing its translation to conserve iron.   Transferrin receptor 1 (TfR1): TfR1 imports iron into cells. When iron levels are low, IRPs bind to IREs in the 3' UTR of TfR1 mRNA, stabilizing it and increasing its translation to enhance iron uptake.

questions.question: Which transport molecule facilitates the absorption of Fe2+ into enterocytes in the small intestine?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) DMT-1 Explanation: DMT-1 is a transmembrane protein that facilitates the transport of divalent metal ions, primarily ferrous iron (Fe2+), across the apical membrane of enterocytes in the duodenum.   Heme iron enters the intestinal cells directly through a heme transporter.   Non-heme iron (Fe³■) is first reduced to Fe²■ by duodenal cytochrome B, then Fe²■ enters the cells via the DMT-1 transporter (Option C).   Inside the duodenal cell, Fe²■ can either be stored as mucosal iron or transported into the bloodstream.   Fe²■ exits the cell through ferroportin (Option A).   In the blood, Fe²■ is oxidized to Fe³■ by hephaestin (Option B) and ceruloplasmin.   Fe³■ binds to transferrin for delivery to the bone marrow, where it is stored as ferritin; in cases of hemolysis, ferritin aggregates to form hemosiderin. The liver secretes hepcidin (Option D), a protein that regulates iron absorption. When iron stores are adequate, hepcidin downregulates ferroportin expression, reducing iron absorption.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents with fatigue and pallor. Lab tests show hemoglobin of 9 g/dL and MCV of 68 fL. Peripheral smear reveals microcytic and hypochromic red blood cells. Her symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following statements regarding iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is correct?

options.B: Serum ferritin is the gold standard investigation
options.D: Serum ferritin levels are not affected.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Decreased serum ferritin levels Explanation:   Serum ferritin is a key marker used in diagnosing iron deficiency anemia.   In iron deficiency, ferritin levels are decreased because ferritin stores decrease as iron stores deplete. (Option A and D)   Serum ferritin levels below 30 ng/mL are generally considered indicative of depleted iron stores and are a reliable marker for iron deficiency. Serum ferritin is the gold standard investigation (Option B): While serum ferritin is commonly used as a marker for iron stores, it is not considered the gold standard test for diagnosing iron deficiency. A bone marrow aspirate to directly assess iron stores is the gold standard for diagnosing iron deficiency.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman has been experiencing fatigue, pallor, and shortness of breath for the past six months. Laboratory tests reveal a Hb of 6 gm/dl. Red cell distribution width is increased. Peripheral smear is shown below. Where is the likely site of absorption of the micronutrient deficient in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Duodenum Explanation: The given clinical presentation of low hemoglobin, increased RDW, and microcytic hypochromic red cells on peripheral smear, points towards the diagnosis of Iron deficiency anemia. Iron is primarily absorbed through the duodenal mucosa, making duodenum the most likely site of absorption. Metabolism of iron:   Iron from the diet (heme and non-heme) is converted to ferrous form in the stomach.   Heme iron is primarily found in animal-based foods, while non heme iron is found in plant-based foods and iron-fortified foods.   In the duodenum, ferrous iron is absorbed via DMT1 and transported into enterocytes.   Inside, it binds to ferritin or enters the bloodstream via ferroportin.   Iron binds to transferrin in the blood, facilitating its delivery to tissues for functions like hemoglobin synthesis.   Hepcidin, a peptide hormone produced by the liver, plays a crucial role in regulating iron homeostasis. Jejunum (Option A) absorbs nutrients like amino acids, glucose, fatty acids, and folic acid. Ileum (Option B) completes nutrient absorption, including bile salts, vitamin B12, and remaining nutrients, before the material enters the colon. Colon (Option D) focuses on absorbing water, electrolytes like sodium and chloride, and some vitamins from gut bacteria, such as vitamin K and biotin.

questions.question: Which of the following helps differentiate megaloblastic anaemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency, not folate?

options.B: Neurological symptoms improve after folate administration
options.D: Anaemia doesn’t improve after folate administration

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Raised urinary methylmalonic acid levels Explanation: Plasma and urinary methylmalonic acid levels will be elevated in case of vitamin B12 deficiency but not with folate deficiency. This is because the enzyme methylmalonyl coenzyme A mutase's isomerisation of methylmalonyl coenzyme A to succinyl coenzyme A requires adenosylcobalamin (a form of vitamin B12) as a cofactor. A deficiency of vitamin B12 thus leads to increased plasma and urine levels of methylmalonic acid. Vitamin B12 is key in converting homocysteine to methionine; hence, its deficiency will lead to elevated homocysteine levels (Option A) rather than reduction. Neurological symptoms will remain the same, if not worsen, after folate administration in case of Vitamin B12 deficient megaloblastic anaemia (Option B). Improvement in symptoms and reduction in megaloblastic count occur after folate administration, even if the anaemia is due to Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option D).

questions.question: Which of the following is true when increased urinary formiminoglutamic acid is detected in a patient to whom histidine is given?

options.A: Presence of antibodies against intrinsic factor

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Deficiency of folic acid is present Explanation:   Elevated urinary levels of formiminoglutamic acid (FIGlu) in a patient to whom histidine is given suggests the presence of folic acid deficiency. This is called the FIGlu test.   Folic acid is normally required in its tetrahydrofolate form to regulate DNA synthesis and the production of methionine, glutamate, etc.   Formiminoglutamic acid derived from histidine will be converted to glutamate in the presence of folic acid.   If there is a folic acid deficiency, this conversion will not occur, leading to elevated urinary formiminoglutamic acid. Presence of antibodies against intrinsic factor (Option A): Antibodies to intrinsic factor will be seen in pernicious anaemia in which there will be vitamin B12 deficiency. Neurological symptoms are common (Option C): Neurological symptoms will be seen in Vitamin B12 deficiency, not folate deficiency.

questions.question: A patient presents with inflammation of the mouth and tongue. He is a non-vegetarian. As part of the evaluation, a Schilling test was done and found unremarkable. Which of the following investigations could lead to the aetiology behind this presentation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Serum folate levels Explanation:   It is a scenario of possible megaloblastic anaemia due to folate deficiency. Hence, serum/red cell folate can lead to the aetiology behind this presentation.   Schilling test is done by orally administering the patient with radioactive vitamin B12 and checking its presence in the urine. If present, as with this case, it is understood that there is no problem with the absorption.   In addition to an unremarkable Schilling test, the fact that vitamin B12 deficiency is uncommon among non-vegetarians suggests a diagnosis of folate-deficient megaloblastic anaemia. Anti-IF (intrinsic factor) antibodies (Option C) are found in patients with pernicious anaemia, and since the Schilling test is unremarkable, it can be ruled out.

questions.solution: Correct Option D - High mechanical fragility, Low osmotic fragility: High mechanical fragility:   Sickle cells have increased mechanical fragility, meaning they are more prone to rupture or break under physical stress. The abnormal shape of sickle cells, which is rigid and less deformable than normal red blood cells, contributes to their increased mechanical fragility. Low osmotic fragility :   Sickle cells have decreased osmotic fragility, meaning they are less prone to rupture in a hypotonic (lower concentration of solutes) environment. questions.question: A 25-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and pale skin. On further investigation, her complete blood count reveals a microcytic anemia. What is the likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Iron deficiency anemia:   Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by a deficiency of iron, a key component required for hemoglobin synthesis in red blood cells. Microcytic anemia, where the red blood cells are smaller than normal, is a hallmark of iron deficiency. The patient's symptoms of fatigue, weakness, and pale skin are classic signs of anemia. Iron deficiency can be caused by inadequate dietary intake, chronic blood loss (such as from menstruation or gastrointestinal bleeding), or poor iron absorption.   Based on the patient's presentation of microcytic anemia along with the symptoms of fatigue, weakness, and pale skin, the most likely diagnosis is D. Iron deficiency anemia. Incorrect Options: Option A - Alcoholism: Alcoholism can lead to various health issues, including anemia. However, in this case, the patient's presentation of fatigue, weakness, and pale skin along with microcytic anemia suggests a more specific cause related to iron deficiency. Option B - Chronic Kidney Disease: Chronic kidney disease can cause anemia due to reduced production of erythropoietin (a hormone that stimulates red blood cell production) by the kidneys. However, anemia caused by chronic kidney disease is usually normocytic or normochromic rather than microcytic. Option C - Hemolytic Anemia: Hemolytic anemia results from the destruction of red blood cells at a rate that exceeds their production. It can lead to a variety of symptoms, including fatigue and pale skin. However, microcytic anemia is typically associated with conditions related to impaired hemoglobin synthesis, like iron deficiency anemia, rather than hemolysis

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of chronic inflammatory conditions presents with fatigue, weakness, and pallor. Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic hypochromic anemia. Further evaluation suggests an underlying disorder affecting iron metabolism. Which cytokine is most likely inhibiting the activity of ferroportin in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - IL-6:   IL-6 stands for Interleukin-6, which is a cytokine that plays a crucial role in inflammation and immune responses. In this scenario, the patient presents with microcytic hypochromic anemia, which is often caused by iron deficiency. Ferroportin is a protein that functions as an iron exporter, allowing iron to exit from cells into the bloodstream, where it can be utilized for various physiological processes including red blood cell production. When ferroportin is inhibited, it leads to reduced iron export from cells and contributes to iron retention within the cells.In chronic inflammatory conditions, such as the one mentioned in the question, there is an increased production of IL-6. IL-6 has been shown to stimulate the production of hepcidin, a peptide hormone synthesized in the liver. Hepcidin regulates iron homeostasis by binding to ferroportin and causing its internalization and degradation. This action reduces iron export from cells, leading to decreased iron availability for erythropoiesis (red blood cell production). Consequently, chronic inflammation-induced elevation of IL-6 and subsequent increase in hepcidin levels result in reduced iron absorption and availability for red blood cell formation, leading to microcytic hypochromic anemia. Incorrect Options: Option A - IL-1: Interleukin-1 is also involved in inflammation and immune responses, but it does not have a direct role in inhibiting ferroportin. It can contribute to inflammation-induced systemic responses. Option C - IFN-gamma: Interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) is primarily involved in immune responses and has not been directly implicated in the inhibition of ferroportin. Option D - TNF-Alpha: Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) is another cytokine involved in inflammation. It does contribute to the inflammatory response, but it is not the primary cytokine responsible for inhibiting ferroportin.
