questions.question: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of occasional dizziness and palpitations in crowded spaces. He is an executive who travels frequently and reports high-stress levels at work. Labs: Hb= 14.0 Platelets = 80,000 Leukocytes = 7,200 RBCs= 5 million Peripheral smear shows a reduced platelet count without clumping or malignant cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next test for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) HIV antibody test Explanation: Isolated thrombocytopenia without anemia or leukopenia suggests Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP), diagnosed after excluding other causes. Thrombocytopenia may occur in chronic HIV infection; thus, HIV and hepatitis C testing are essential. ITP is a diagnosis of exclusion, requiring exclusion of other causes of thrombocytopenia. Features Acute ITP Chronic ITP Age Child Adult (<40 yrs) Common in M=F Females Etiology Often follows viral infections Can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to SLE, HIV, CLL Laboratory FindingsIsolated thrombocytopenia (<20,000/ µL), normal PT and aPTT, ↑BTIsolated thrombocytopenia (30,000-80,000/ µL), normal PT and aPTT, ↑BT; Hypercellular marrow with megakaryocytic hyperplasia; Megathrombocytes in peripheral blood Resolution Normal within 6 months > 6 months Treatment Often self-limited Steroids. Splenectomy in refractory cases. EBV virus titers (Option A): EBV virus titers are useful for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis. Patients with infectious mononucleosis usually present with fatigue, sore throat, fever, palatal petechiae, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Labs show lymphocytosis and possible thrombocytopenia. This patient does not have findings of infectious mononucleosis. Rapid plasma reagin test (Option B): It is a non-troponemal antigen test used to screen for syphilis. However, syphilis is not associated with thrombocytopenia. Schilling test (Option C): Schilling test determines if vitamin B12 deficiency is due to pernicious anemia or a malabsorption syndrome. It is not used to diagnose ITP.

questions.question: A 14-year-old adolescent presents with recurrent episodes of unexplained swelling and pain following minor injuries or physical activity. Upon examination, there are signs of localized swelling and tenderness. Lab investigations reveal normal platelet counts and bleeding time, but clotting times are prolonged. Which symptom would strongly suggest a coagulation defect in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Hemarthrosis Explanation: Coagulation factor abnormalities, or defects in secondary hemostasis, may manifest as bleeding into soft tissues like muscles or joints. Hemarthrosis, characterized by bleeding into joints following minor trauma, is a specific feature associated with hemophilia. Clinical manifesta tionPlatelet disorders Coagulation disorders Bleeding siteMucous membranes Muscles and joints Presentati onSuperficial bleeds like Petechia , purpura, mucosal bleeds; multiple sitesDeep tissue bleeds like Hematoma , intracranial bleeds (most dangerous ) , joint bleeds/ hemarthroses (most common); localized Bleeding onsetProlonged bleeding from cuts May be delayed at onset Family historyRare Common Treatment responseImmediately Insidious Petechiae(Option A): Petechiae (minute 1 to 2-mm hemorrhages) arise due to a defect in platelet function. They occur as pinpoint hemorrhages in the dependent areas where the capillary pressure is higher. Purpura (Option B): Purpura are slightly larger than petechiae (>3 mm) and can be palpable. They are often seen in conditions like Henoch-Schonlein purpura. Ecchymoses(Option C): Ecchymoses, or bruises, are 1 to 2-cm hemorrhages. The volume of blood that has been extravasated in purpura and ecchymoses may be sufficient to form a palpable mass of blood called a hematoma.

questions.question: A 22-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of frequent nosebleeds and heavy menstrual periods. She reports prolonged bleeding after minor cuts and has noticed easy bruising. On physical examination, multiple small bruises are on her arms and legs. Which of the following tests is most likely to be abnormal?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Bleeding Time (BT) Explanation:   The symptoms described—frequent nosebleeds, heavy menstrual periods, prolonged bleeding after minor cuts, and easy bruising—are characteristic of a primary hemostasis disorder, which involves platelet function.   The Bleeding Time (BT) test assesses the function of platelets and their ability to form a primary hemostatic plug. Normal BT is 2 to 9 minutes and is prolonged when there is a defect in platelet function. Clotting time (CT) (Option B): The clotting time (CT) reflects the time needed for clot formation rather than platelet function. Normal CT: 8-15 mins. Prothrombin time (PT) (Option C):   Prothrombin time is used to assess both extrinsic and common coagulation pathways.   Deficits or dysfunctions of factors 1, 2, 5, 7, or 10 can cause a prolonged prothrombin time (PT). Normal PT: 11-16 secs.   INR = PT of patient / PT of a normal person. Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) (Option D):   Activated partial prothrombin time is used to study intrinsic and common coagulation processes. Normal aPTT: 25-30 secs.   Deficits or dysfunctions of factors 12, 11, 9, 8, 10, 5, 2, 1 or interfering antiphospholipid antibodies can all prolong the aPTT.

questions.question: A 2-week-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because of prolonged bleeding from the umbilical stump. The parents report that the bleeding started soon after the umbilical cord fell off and has not stopped despite applying pressure. Laboratory tests show normal Prothrombin Time (PT), Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT), and platelet count. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely causing the prolonged bleeding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Factor XIII Explanation:   Factor XIII is crucial for maintaining clot stability and promoting fibrin polymer cross-linking, ensuring effective hemostasis.   Its deficiency can lead to prolonged bleeding from the umbilical stump in neonates, as seen in this case. Other symptoms include severe menstrual bleeding, hemarthrosis, repeated early pregnancy loss, and delayed postoperative bleeding.   Unlike other factors, Factor XIII deficiency does not affect BT, CT, PT, aPTT, or platelet count. Diagnosis is confirmed with a urea clot solubility test, in which the clot dissolves if Factor XIII is deficient. Factor VIII deficiency (Option A):   Hemophilia A, or Factor VIII deficiency is an X-linked disorder, characterized by elevated aPTT and causes deep tissue and joint bleeding.   Von Willebrand factor (vWF) protects Factor VIII from degradation, and its deficiency can lead to reduced Factor VIII levels, resulting in a condition called pseudohemophilia. Factor IV deficiency (Option C): Factor IV (calcium) is essential for the coagulation cascade, activating Factor X in intrinsic and extrinsic pathways. However, calcium deficiency is extremely rare and not associated with umbilical stump bleeding; it typically causes widespread bleeding. Factor IX deficiency (Option D): Factor IX deficiency (Hemophilia B or Christmas disease) is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting the intrinsic pathway, causing elevated aPTT with normal PT. Like Hemophilia A, it primarily leads to deep tissue and joint bleeding.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presents with excessive bleeding following a tooth extraction. She reports a history of recurrent nosebleeds and easy bruising since childhood. Lab tests show prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and normal prothrombin time (PT). Further testing reveals decreased levels of a clotting factor’s activity. Which of the following is not an intrinsic factor?

questions.question: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a history of recurrent episodes of uncontrolled bleeding from minor injuries and easy bruising. Lab investigations reveal prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). Considering a potential vitamin K deficiency, which specific clotting factors should be evaluated to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Stable factor Explanation: In the context of a potential vitamin K deficiency, clotting factors synthesized in the liver and dependent on vitamin K should be evaluated.   Factors II (Prothrombin), VII (Stable factor), IX (Christmas factor), X (Stuart-Prower factor), and Protein C depend on vitamin K for synthesis in the liver.   Vitamin K deficiency leads to reduced carboxylation of glutamate residues on clotting factors impairing blood clotting. Factors III (Tissue thromboplastin), V (Labile factor), and XII (Hageman factor) are not vitamin K-dependent factors (Options A, B, and C)

questions.question: Which of the following is the major source of plasma Von Willebrand factor?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Endothelial Cells:   Endothelial cells, which line the blood vessels, are the primary source of plasma von Willebrand factor.   These cells synthesize and release vWF into the bloodstream.   Von Willebrand factor produced by endothelial cells plays a crucial role in blood clotting and platelet adhesion to damaged blood vessel walls. questions.question: All of the following are crosslinking fixatives, except?
questions.solution: Correct option D: Osmium tetraoxide:   Osmium tetroxide is a strong oxidizing agent and is used primarily as a staining agent in transmission electron microscopy (TEM) for biological specimens.   It is not primarily used as a cross-linking fixative.   Glutaraldehyde, formaldehyde (also known as formalin), and methanol are commonly used crosslinking fixatives in biological and histological sample preparation.   These fixatives help preserve the structure of biological tissues by forming chemical crosslinks between proteins and other macromolecules, preventing degradation, and maintaining the tissue's integrity for further analysis. Incorrect options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.question: What does the following image show?
questions.solution: Correct option B: Emperipolesis:   Emperipolesisis a cellular process in which one cell is engulfed and contained within the cytoplasm of another cell without being degraded.   It is a non-destructive process, unlike phagocytosis or autophagy, where the engulfed material is typically broken down and degraded. Incorrect options: Option A: Autophagy:   Autophagy is a cellular process that involves the degradation and recycling of cellular components.   It is a mechanism by which cells remove damaged organelles, misfolded proteins, and other cytoplasmic constituents.   Autophagy plays a crucial role in maintaining cellular homeostasis and responding to various stress conditions. Option C: Phagocytosis:   Phagocytosis is a process by which cells, such as macrophages and neutrophils, engulf and internalize solid particles, such as bacteria, cellular debris, or foreign substances.   The engulfed material is then enclosed within a membrane-bound vesicle called a phagosome, which fuses with lysosomes for degradation and destruction of the engulfed material. Option D: Amoebic autophagy:   Amoebic autophagy refers to the autophagic process observed in amoebae, which are single-celled organisms.   It involves the engulfment and degradation of cellular components or particles by the amoebae to obtain nutrients or eliminate unwanted materials.

questions.question: Acid mucin is stained by:
questions.solution: Correct option B: Alcian blue:   Alcian blue staining is specifically used to detect and visualize acidic mucopolysaccharides, such as acid mucin.   It is often employed to identify mucin-producing cells, mucous glands, and mucin-rich connective tissues.   Alcian blue staining results in a blue or bluish-green color, indicating the presence of acid mucin. Incorrect options: Option A: PAS:   PAS staining is used to detect and highlight the presence of carbohydrates, including glycogen and mucopolysaccharides.   It is commonly used to stain structures such as basement membranes, glycogen granules, and fungal organisms.   PAS staining results in a pink-to-magenta coloration. Option C: Masson trichrome:   Masson trichrome staining is a staining technique used to differentiate various tissue components.   It involves staining collagen fibers blue, cytoplasm and muscle fibers red, and nuclei dark red to black.   While Masson trichrome staining can help visualize connective tissues and collagen, it does not specifically target acid mucin. Option D: Phosphotungstic acid haematoxylin (PTAH):   PTAH staining is commonly used to highlight muscle fibers and fibrin.   It is particularly useful in diagnosing muscle disorders and identifying abnormalities in muscle structure.

questions.question: Which of the following can be prevented by transfusing irradiated RBCs?
questions.solution: Correct option A: Graft versus host disease:   Transfusion of irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) can prevent graft versus host disease (GVHD).   Irradiation of blood products, including RBCs, is performed to prevent the proliferation of lymphocytes in the transfused blood.   The irradiation process damages the DNA of lymphocytes, rendering them unable to divide and mount an immune response.   By inhibiting the activity of donor lymphocytes, irradiation reduces the risk of GVHD in susceptible recipients, particularly those who are immunocompromised or receive blood products from close relatives. Incorrect options: Transfusion of irradiated RBCs does not prevent options B, C, and D.

questions.question: A 24-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after suffering severe injuries in a motorcycle accident. His blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg. Tachycardic with cold clammy skin. An ultrasound examination revealed a ruptured spleen. Arterial blood gas analysis was suggestive of metabolic acidosis. The patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct option C: Hypovolemic shock:   The patient's presentation to the emergency department after suffering severe injuries in a motorcycle accident with low BP, tachycardia, cold extremities and USG showed a ruptured spleen that caused internal bleeding, is suggestive of hypovolemic shock.   Hemorrhage, fluid loss, severe burn, perspiration in excess, and diarrhea are some of the events that lead to hypovolemic shock, which occurs due to significant loss of fluid from the vascular compartment. Incorrect options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.solution: Correct Option B - 2, 5, 3, 4, 1:   The coagulation cascade involves a series of sequential activation and interactions of various clotting factors, leading to the formation of a stable fibrin clot. Incorrect Options:   Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following clotting factor deficiency will not affect clotting in vivo?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Factor XII:   Factor XII, also known as Hageman factor, is not essential for normal clotting in vivo.   It is part of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.   Activation of Factor XII initiates a series of reactions leading to the formation of a blood clot.   In vivo, the absence or deficiency of Factor XII does not significantly affect normal clotting because other factors and pathways compensate for its deficiency. Incorrect Options: Option A - Factor VII: Deficiency of Factor VII, also known as stable factor, leads to impaired clotting in vivo. Option B - Factor V: Deficiency of Factor V, also known as labile factor, results in impaired clotting in vivo. Option D - Factor IX: Deficiency of Factor IX, also known as Christmas factor, leads to impaired clotting in vivo.

questions.question: Why is blood stored in citrate-phosphate-dextrose preferred over acid-citrate-dextrose for hypoxic patients?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - The fall in 2,3-DPG is less:   2,3-DPG is a molecule that binds to hemoglobin and helps facilitate the release of oxygen to tissues.   When blood is stored, the levels of 2,3-DPG gradually decrease over time.   A lower concentration of 2,3-DPG causes a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve, resulting in decreased oxygen release to tissues.   This can be detrimental for hypoxic patients who already have compromised oxygen delivery. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.question: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - PT:   Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.   It measures the time it takes for blood to clot in response to activating agents that initiate the extrinsic pathway, primarily involving factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen. Incorrect Options: Option A - aPTT:   Activated partial thromboplastin time evaluates the intrinsic pathway of coagulation. Option C - TT:   Thrombin time measures the time it takes for fibrinogen to be converted into fibrin by the action of thrombin.   It evaluates the final common pathway of coagulation and is used to assess the activity of thrombin. Option D - Bleeding Time:   Bleeding time assesses the primary hemostasis, specifically the ability of platelets to form a platelet plug and initiate clot formation.   It measures the time it takes for bleeding to stop after a standardized skin incision.

questions.question: A child was brought to the emergency department with a big lesion on his forearm. As a surgery resident, you decide to excise the lesion in the emergency operation theater. Which of the following investigations will test the entire coagulation pathway?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Thromboelastography:   Thromboelastography (TEG) is a coagulation test that assesses the entire coagulation pathway, including both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, as well as fibrinolysis.   It provides a comprehensive evaluation of clot formation, clot strength, and clot lysis.   TEG measures the viscoelastic properties of blood as it clots, allowing for the assessment of various parameters such as clotting time, clot formation time, clot strength, and fibrinolysis.   By analyzing these parameters, TEG provides valuable information about the functionality of the coagulation system and helps guide clinical decision-making during surgical procedures. Incorrect Options: Option A - Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time:   Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) primarily evaluates the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. Option B - Prothrombin Time:   Prothrombin time (PT) primarily assesses the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. Option D - Bleeding Time:   Bleeding time measures the time taken for bleeding to stop after a standardized skin incision.   It primarily assesses platelet function and primary hemostasis.

questions.question: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions?
questions.solution: Correct option A: Leukoreduced RBCs:   The patient's presentation with fever and chills with no evidence of hemolysis is suggestive of a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction.   Leukoreduced red blood cells (RBCs) refer to blood products that have undergone a process to remove or reduce the number of leukocytes.   White blood cells can trigger immune responses and cause transfusion reactions, including febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions.   Leukoreduced RBCs reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions. Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D do not reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions.

questions.question: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis, and his Hb was 5.2 g/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started, and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals were BP: 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate: 110/min. What is the cause?
questions.solution: Correct option B: Transfusion-related circulatory overload:   Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO) occurs when a patient receives blood or fluid too quickly.   In the given case, the patient undergoing dialysis received two blood transfusions. overwhelming the cardiovascular system's capacity to handle the increased volume.   Symptoms of TACO include shortness of breath, hypertension, elevated blood pressure, and fluid overload. Incorrect options: Option A: Allergic reaction: While allergic reactions can occur during transfusions, they typically present with symptoms such as itching, rash, hives, or anaphylaxis. Option C: Transfusion-related acute lung injury:   TRALI is a rare but potentially serious complication of blood transfusion characterized by acute respiratory distress and pulmonary edema.   While shortness of breath is a symptom of TRALI, hypertension and elevated blood pressure are not typically associated with this condition. Option D: Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction: A febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction is characterized by fever and chills during or after a blood transfusion, usually due to antibodies in the recipient's blood reacting to donor leukocytes.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common complication of blood transfusion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Febrile Non-hemolytic reaction Explanation : Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) are the most common complication of blood transfusions. These reactions typically occur when the recipient's immune system responds to the transfused blood product's white blood cells or cytokines. FNHTRs are characterised by fever and chills during or shortly after a transfusion. Pathophysiology: FNHTRs are typically caused by: Management:   Stop the Transfusion.   Supportive Care. TRALI (Transfusion-related acute lung injury) (Option A) is a serious transfusion reaction characterised by acute respiratory distress and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It typically occurs within 6 hours of transfusion and is caused by an immune response to donor antibodies or bioactive substances in the transfused blood. TACO (Transfusion-associated circulatory overload) (Option B) occurs when a transfusion is administered too quickly or when the volume of transfused blood exceeds the recipient's circulatory capacity. It leads to volume overload and pulmonary edema due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary vasculature. Delayed hemolytic reactions (Option C) occur days to weeks after a transfusion and are caused by an immune response to minor antigens on transfused red blood cells. Symptoms may include mild fever, jaundice, and a gradual decline in hemoglobin levels due to hemolysis.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)?

options.A: Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema within 6 hours of transfusion
options.B: Cardiogenic pulmonary edema within 24 hours of transfusion
options.C: Acute onset of fever and chills without respiratory symptoms
options.D: Gradual onset of jaundice and anemia several days after transfusion

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema within 6 hours of transfusion Explanation : TRALI is characterised by acute onset of respiratory distress and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema occurring within 6 hours of a blood transfusion. It is caused by an immune reaction to donor antibodies or bioactive substances in the transfused blood. Characteristics:   Onset: TRALI typically occurs within 6 hours of transfusion.   Symptoms: Sudden onset of dyspnea (shortness of breath). Hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels) Fever. Hypotension. Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on a chest X-ray, indicating fluid accumulation in the lungs without cardiac cause.   Sudden onset of dyspnea (shortness of breath).   Hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels)   Fever.   Hypotension.   Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on a chest X-ray, indicating fluid accumulation in the lungs without cardiac cause.   Sudden onset of dyspnea (shortness of breath).   Hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels)   Fever.   Hypotension.   Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on a chest X-ray, indicating fluid accumulation in the lungs without cardiac cause. acute lung injury (TRALI). Case study, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 06 Dec 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-160043" data-hash="" data-license="NA" data-source="https://radiopaedia.org/cases/transfusion-related-acute-lung-injury-trali" data-tags="" height="3878" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/VWG6XF2CE5cnm8KWnr Dj1736771845.png" width="4167" /> Causes:   Immune-mediated Reaction: TRALI is often triggered by donor antibodies reacting with the recipient's white blood cells, releasing inflammatory mediators that increase pulmonary capillary permeability.   Non-immune Factors: Biological response modifiers like cytokines and lipids that accumulate during blood product storage can also contribute. Prevention:   Using plasma from male or female donors who have never been pregnant (nulliparous) can reduce the risk, as they are less likely to have antibodies that can cause TRALI.   Blood banks may screen donors for antibodies known to cause TRALI. TACO is characterised by a gradual onset of respiratory distress and cardiogenic pulmonary edema within 24 hours of transfusion(Option B). It occurs when a patient receives a transfusion volume that exceeds their circulatory capacity, leading to fluid overload and cardiac dysfunction. Acute onset of fever and chills without respiratory symptoms (Option C) is seen in febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR), which are characterised by fever and chills without respiratory distress. Gradual onset of jaundice and anemia several days after transfusion (Option D) is more indicative of delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions, which occur days to weeks after transfusion.

questions.question: In which following layer of the epidermis would you most likely find the melanin-producing cells of the skin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Stratum basale Explanation: Stratum basale is the basal layer of the epidermis, which contains the melanin-producing melanocytes. Layers of the epidermis: (superficial to deep) 1. Stratum Corneum: 20-30 anucleate squamous cell layers comprised of keratin and dead keratinocytes. (Option A) 2. Stratum Lucidum: 2-3 thin clear cell layers consisting of eleidin (present in areas with thick skin- palms and soles) 3. Stratum Granulosum: contains 3-5 cell layers of cells with granules of Keratohyalin (Option C) 4. Stratum Spinosum: 8-10 layers of irregular, polyhedral cells with cytoplasmic processes extending outward and contacting neighbouring cells by desmosomes. Dendritic cells can be found in this layer. (Option B) 5. Stratum Basale / germinativum: one cell thick layer that contains cuboidal to columnar mitotically active stem cells; it also contains melanocytes (Option 4) Mnemonic: Come Let's Get Sun Burnt (Corneum, Lucidum, Granulosum, Spinosum and Basale)

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a rash on his hands and feet characterised by clusters of small, fluid-filled blisters. Histopathological examination of a skin biopsy reveals intracellular oedema of keratinocytes. Which term best describes this histological finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Ballooning Explanation: The clinical presentation of small, fluid-filled blisters and the biopsy finding of intracellular oedema of keratinocytes are consistent with hydropic swelling, also known as ballooning. This condition is often seen in viral infections. Acanthosis (Option A): Diffuse thickening of the epidermis. Spongiosis (Option C): Intracellular oedema of the epidermis Parakeratosis (Option D): Retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum.

questions.question: A 10-year-old child exhibits rough, scaly skin on the elbows, knees, and trunk, accompanied by hyperkeratotic plaques. Which skin condition is typically associated with this manifestation of excessive keratin buildup?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Ichthyosis Explanation: Ichthyosis is a group of inherited skin disorders characterised by chronic, excessive buildup of keratin (hyperkeratosis), leading to dry, scaly skin resembling fish scales. It results from defective desquamation, causing retention of abnormally formed scales. Freckles (Option A): Freckles (Ephelides) are small, tan-red or light brown macules that appear after sun exposure. They result from increased melanin pigment within basal keratinocytes, not excess keratin. The number of melanocytes is normal, but the degree of pigmentation changes with sun exposure. Lentigo (Option B): Lentigo refers to benign localised hyperplasia of melanocytes. It presents as small, oval, tan-brown macules or patches. Unlike freckles, lentigines do not darken with sun exposure. The key feature is linear melanocytic hyperplasia restricted to the cell layer above the basement membrane without excess keratin. Nevus (Mole) (Option C): Nevi are benign neoplasms of melanocytes, often caused by mutations leading to activation of the RAS signalling pathway. They are typically small, uniformly pigmented macules or papules with well-defined borders. There is no excessive keratin production in nevi.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with a dark, irregularly shaped mole on her back that has rapidly increased in size over the past few months. On examination, the lesion has uneven borders and varying shades of colour. Which of the following is true regarding its pathogenesis?

options.C: Spreads vertically with no metastatic potential
options.D: Associated with mutations that decrease telomerase activity

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Associated with TERT mutations Explanation: Malignant melanoma is characterized by the clinical presentation of a rapidly changing mole with irregular borders and varying color. It is often associated with activating mutation in the TERT gene, which is responsible for telomerase formation. There are three main types of genetic mutations seen in malignant melanoma.   Melanomas show colour variations, and the borders are irregular and notched. They show two patterns of growth.   Radially: Superficial spread on the epidermis and dermis, lack metastatic potential. (Option B)   Vertical spread into the deep dermis, characterised by the appearance of a nodule, has metastatic potential. (Option C) ABCDE of Melanoma:   A - Asymmetry: One half doesn't match the other half in shape.   B - Border: The edges of the mole are irregular rather than smooth and defined.   C - Colour: Uneven colour. It may include different shades of brown, black, or tan.   D - Diameter: Growns larger (about the size of a pencil eraser).   E - Evolving: The mole changes in size, shape, colour, or appearance over time. On microscopy, they have enlarged nuclei and prominent red (eosinophilic) nucleoli with melanin pigment.

questions.question: A 70-year-old woman presents with a finding as shown in the image. A biopsy confirms basal cell carcinoma. Which molecular pathway is primarily involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Hedgehog signaling pathway Explanation: The hedgehog signaling pathway is associated with the pathogenesis of basal cell carcinoma, a locally aggressive cutaneous tumour.   They present as pearly papules containing dilated blood vessels (telangiectasias)   They may ulcerate locally and invade the underlying bone or facial sinuses (rodent ulcers). Histologically, the tumour cells are basophilic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei (basaloid cells) arranged in clusters with a palisading pattern. The stroma sometimes retracts from the malignant cells. Hippo pathway signaling (Option A): It is seen in Neurofibromatosis type 2, an autosomal dominant disease, due to mutations in the NF2 gene causing activation of the protein, merlin. It presents with acoustic schwannoma and meningioma. WNT signaling pathway (Option C): This pathway is implicated in various familial colonic polyps and carcinomas of the stomach, colon, and pancreas, as well as melanomas. It is disrupted by mutations in the APC gene, which result in dysregulation of the adenomatous polyposis coli protein and subsequent abnormal activation of the WNT signaling pathway. RAS/MAPK signaling (Option D): Inhibition of RAS/MAPK signaling is seen in Neurofibromatosis type 1. This is due to mutations in the NF1 gene that produce Neurofibromin-1. It presents with neurofibromas, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumours, neuroblastoma and juvenile myeloid leukaemia.

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with multiple basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) on her face, neck, and back. She also has a history of medulloblastoma, diagnosed during childhood. On examination, she has palmar pits and macrocephaly. Which of the following is not true regarding this syndrome?

options.B: Associated with mutations in the PTCH gene
options.D: Associated with loss of nucleotide excision repair mechanism

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Associated with loss of nucleotide excision repair mechanism. Explanation: Loss of nucleotide excision repair mechanism is associated with Xeroderma pigmentosum and these patients are at increased risk of squamous cell and basal cell skin cancers due to exposure to UV light because of an inability to repair pyrimidine dimers.   The clinical presentation is suggestive of Gorlin syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder (Option C) characterised by the development of multiple basal cell carcinomas before age 20.   It also presents with various other tumours like medulloblastomas, ovarian fibromas, odontogenic keratocysts (Option A) and pits of the palms and soles.   The gene associated is PTCH, a tumour suppressor gene (Option B)   Patients with Gorlin syndrome inherit one defective PTCH allele; the remaining normal allele undergoes UV-induced mutation. This mutation activates SMO and GLI1, contributing to basal cell carcinoma development.

questions.question: A 72-year-old man with a history of extensive sun exposure and recent organ transplant presents with a rapidly growing, painless, reddish nodule on his left cheek over two months. Biopsy shows small, round blue cells with salt and pepper chromatin and positivity for neuroendocrine markers. What marker is typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) CK20 Explanation: The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of Merkel cell carcinoma, a highly aggressive neuroendocrine skin cancer characterised by rapid growth, early metastasis, and a high mortality rate.   Predisposing factors include immune suppression, sun exposure, and advanced age.   Most MCCs involve the clonal integration of Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCPyV), which is crucial for tumour growth.   It typically presents as a fast-growing, reddish, firm nodule on sun-exposed skin.   CK20 is a cytoskeletal protein commonly expressed in Merkel Cell Carcinoma, hence used as a specific marker.   Its characteristic perinuclear dot-like staining pattern is a key diagnostic feature. S-100 (Option A) and Melan-A (Option C) are more useful in the diagnosis of Melanoma and are not typically associated with Merkel Cell Carcinoma (MCC) p40 (Option D) is a marker commonly used in diagnosing squamous cell carcinoma and not useful in Merkel cell carcinoma.

questions.question: An 18-year-old female has multiple itchy silvery scales on her knees and elbows. A biopsy of the lesion revealed the presence of nuclei and neutrophilic infiltration in the stratum corneum. Match the following with their appropriate answers. a. Auspitz sign 1. Nucelated stratum corneum b. Munro’s microabscess 2. Pinpoint bleed after scraping off old lesion c. Spongiform pustules of kogoj 3. Neutrophilic infiltrate in stratum corneum d. Parakeratosis 4. Neutrophilic infiltrate in stratum spinosum a. Auspitz sign 1. Nucelated stratum corneum b. Munro’s microabscess 2. Pinpoint bleed after scraping off old lesion c. Spongiform pustules of kogoj 3. Neutrophilic infiltrate in stratum corneum d. Parakeratosis 4. Neutrophilic infiltrate in stratum spinosum
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1 Psoriasis is an autoimmune chronic inflammatory dermatosis.   In susceptible individuals, this condition can be triggered by local trauma (Koebner phenomenon).   Clinical manifestations include skin changes such as itchy, silvery scales over salmon-pink plaques, with pinpoint bleeding upon scraping (Auspitz Sign).   Nail changes are also common, occurring in approximately 30% of cases, characterised by yellow-brown discolouration, pitting, dimpling, and separation of the nail plate from the underlying bed. Histopathology of psoriasis:   Parakeratosis: Retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum cells.   Munro’s abscess: Collection of neutrophilic infiltrates in the Stratum corneum.   Spongiform pustules of Kogoj: Collection of inflammatory cells in the Stratum spinosum.   Presence of evenly elongated, thin rete ridges with equally long dermal papillae.

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents to the dermatology clinic with an itchy rash on her wrists and ankles. On examination, small, flat-topped, polygonal, purple papules with fine white lines on their surface are noted. Which of the following is a characteristic histological finding in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Sawtoothing of the dermoe-pidermal junction Explanation: The given clinical scenario and histological features point towards the diagnosis of lichen planus, which presents as itchy, violaceous, flat-topped papules with Wickham striae that can coalesce to form plaques.   They are typically distributed symmetrically on the extremities, wrists, and elbows, and oral mucosa is commonly involved.   Histologically, lichen planus is characterised by a dense lymphocytic infiltrate along the dermo-epidermal junction, resulting in a sawtooth appearance. Basal keratinocytes exhibit degeneration, and Civatte bodies (anucleate, necrotic basal cells) are often observed in the papillary dermis. Munro microabscesses (Option A) are histological findings typically seen in psoriasis, not lichen planus. They are collections of neutrophils within the stratum corneum of the epidermis. Spongiform pustules (Option B) are also characteristic histological findings seen in psoriasis. They represent collections of neutrophils within the superficial epidermis, forming interconnected spaces. Follicular lipping (Option D) is a histological finding seen in seborrheic dermatitis, not lichen planus. It refers to mounds of parakeratosis containing neutrophils and serum at the Ostia of hair follicles.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with widespread blistering of the skin and oral mucosa. Skin biopsy reveals acantholysis and intraepidermal blister formation above the basal layer. Which of the following describes the location of the split in this bullous disorder?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Suprabasal split Explanation:   The given clinical scenario is consistent with Pemphigus vulgaris, in which the split occurs above the basal layer of the epidermis, leading to a suprabasal split.   This is due to autoantibodies targeting desmoglein proteins, causing acantholysis (loss of cell adhesion) and blister formation above the basal layer. Subcorneal split (Option A) is a type of split that occurs just below the stratum corneum, the outermost layer of the epidermis. It is characteristic of pemphigus foliaceus, where the blister forms beneath the stratum corneum. Subepidermal split (Option C) is a type of split that occurs beneath the entire epidermis, within the dermis. It is typical of bullous pemphigoid and dermatitis herpetiformis. In bullous pemphigoid, autoantibodies target components of the basement membrane, causing separationat this level. Junctional split (Option D) is a split occurring at the level of the lamina lucida within the basement membrane zone, often seen in junctional epidermolysis bullosa. This condition involves genetic mutations affecting proteins that anchor the epidermis to the dermis, leading to fragile skin that blisters easily.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with a slow-growing, painless nodule on her scalp that has recently enlarged. Examination reveals a firm, well-circumscribed nodule. Histopathology shows ductal differentiation with multiple cysts and papillary projections. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Cylindroma Explanation: The clinical and histological features described in the scenario are consistent with Cylindroma, benign skin tumours that often appear on the scalp and forehead.   They exhibit ductal differentiation and histologically present as basaloid cell islands fitting together like a "jigsaw puzzle" within a fibrous stroma.   These tumours can merge over time to form larger, turban-like growths.   They may be inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion due to mutations in the CYLD gene.   Cylindromas are also associated with Brooke-Spiegler syndrome, characterized by the occurrence of multiple adnexal tumours, including cylindromas, trichoepitheliomas, and spiradenomas. Pilomatrixoma (Option B) are benign tumours derived from hair matrix cells, presenting as hard, subcutaneous nodules, typically on the face or upper limbs. Histologically, they are characterized by basaloid cells and ghost cells indicative of hair follicle differentiation. Syringomas (Option C) are benign tumours of eccrine sweat glands, typically presenting as multiple small, flesh-coloured to tan papules, often around the eyelids. Histologically, syringomas are characterized by comma-shaped or tadpole-like projections when viewed under a microscope. Trichilemmomas (Option D) are benign tumours arising from the outer root sheath of hair follicles, often appearing as flesh-coloured papules, commonly on the face. Histologically, they exhibit clear cells and peripheral palisading, resembling the outer root sheath.

questions.question: A 38-year-old man complains of severe itching and recurrent skin lesions on his elbows, knees, and upper back. His medical history includes occasional gastrointestinal discomfort. Examination reveals bilateral, symmetric lesions with grouped vesicles. Skin biopsy reveals small microabscesses at the tips of dermal papillae. Which of the following is associated with a disease condition?

options.B: IgA deposits at dermal papilla tips

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) IgA deposits at dermal papilla tips Explanation: Based on the given scenario and biopsy findings, the likely diagnosis is Dermatitis herpetiformis, characterized by urticaria and grouped vesicles, often presents with bilateral, symmetric lesions involving the extensor surfaces.   Direct immunofluorescence (IF) in dermatitis herpetiformis shows discontinuous, granular deposits of IgA selectively localized at the tips of dermal papillae, not linear deposits. Associated with Crohn's disease (Option A): Dermatitis herpetiformis is primarily associated with Celiac disease, not Crohn's disease. Subendothelial blisters (Option C): HPE of Dermatitis herpetiformis reveals fibrin and neutrophil accumulation at the dermal papillae tips, forming microabscesses. A subepidermal blister. (Not Subendothelial blisters) Linear deposits in immunofluorescence (Option D): Direct IF in dermatitis herpetiformis shows granular deposits of IgA, not linear deposits.

questions.question: A 3-year-old child has a chronic, non-healing scalp rash, showing red-brown papules and plaques with crusting on examination. Electron microscopy reveals tennis racket-like structures in histiocytes cytoplasm, and immunohistochemical staining confirms CD1a and S100 protein presence. Which mutation is likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) BRAF mutation The clinical presentation and electron microscopy findings suggest the diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), a rare inflammatory and neoplastic condition involving myeloid dendritic cells.   The BRAF gene produces B-Raf, a component of the MAPK pathway essential for cell division and differentiation.   In Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), the BRAF V600E mutation is prevalent in 55-60% of cases, establishing the neoplastic nature of the disease.   For diagnosis, light microscopy reveals eosinophils, which appear as orange-looking cells, and nuclei with a coffee bean appearance.   Immunohistochemistry (IHC) tests show these cells are positive for CD1a, CD207 (langerin), S100, and HLA-DR.   Electron microscopy, considered the gold standard for diagnosis, reveals the characteristic tennis racket appearance of Birbeck granules.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with tense blisters on his abdomen and extremities, filled with clear fluid. The skin appears normal between the blisters, which are painful but not itchy. A skin biopsy reveals a subepidermal blister with linear IgG and complement deposition along the basement membrane on direct immunofluorescence as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Bullous Pemphigoid Bullous pemphigoid typically presents with tense blisters and is common in older adults. The blisters are subepidermal and characterized by linear IgG and complement deposition along the basement membrane on immunofluorescence, consistent with the findings in this case. Commonly seen in :   Flexor aspect of the forearm   Axilla   Groin Micrograph of bullous pemphigoid. Subepidermal blistering [solid arrows in (A,B)] and influx of inflammatory cells including eosinophils and neutrophils in the dermis [solid arrow (C)] and blister cavity [dashed arrows (C)]. In (C) also deposition of fibrin is noted (asterisks). Morphology:   The lesions are tense bullae filled with clear fluid involving erythematous or normal-appearing skin.   The bullae are usually less than 2 cm in diameter but occasionally may reach 4 to 8 cm in diameter.   They do not rupture easily, unlike the blisters seen in pemphigus, and heal without scarring unless they become infected secondarily. Pathogenesis:   Autoantibodies cause bullous pemphigoid, and most antibody deposition occurs in a continuous linear pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction, where specialized structures called hemidesmosomes link basal keratinocytes to the underlying basement membrane.   Bullous pemphigoid antigens (BPAGs) are components of hemidesmosomes.   Antibodies against one such component called BPAG2 are proven to cause blistering.   Pathogenic autoantibodies also activate complement, leading to the recruitment of neutrophils and eosinophils, inflammation, and disruption of epidermal attachments.   A subepidermal split is seen. Under Immunofluorescence: Linear Immunofluorescence/ Ribbon candy appearance Linear deposition of complement along the dermo-epidermal junction in bullous pemphigoid Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita (Option A): Typical presentation includes trauma-induced blistering, and direct immunofluorescence would show IgG targeting type VII collagen. Bullous pemphigoid v/s Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita: Bullous Pemphigoid Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita Subepidermal split Subepidermal split Linear appearance is at the roof of the bulla The linear appearance is at the floor of the bulla direct immunofluorescence showing linear deposition of IgG along the basement membrane zone Direct IMF displaying linear deposition of IgG, IgA, and C3 at the basement membrane zone. Pemphigus Vulgaris (Option C) is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by intraepithelial blisters and often presents with painful mucosal lesions. Direct immunofluorescence would show intercellular IgG deposits, which is not the case here. Dermatitis Herpetiformis (Option D) is associated with celiac disease and presents with grouped vesicles, often itchy, on extensor surfaces. Direct immunofluorescence shows granular IgA deposits at the dermal papillae. The patient’s presentation of tense blisters and the biopsy findings do not support this diagnosis.
